<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-pathology-for-medical-students">GENERAL PATHOLOGY FOR MEDICAL STUDENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-pathology-for-medical-students" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Paleopathology View project</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-is-pathology">WHAT IS PATHOLOGY?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{P}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">P</span></span></span></span></span>athology is the science which deals with the study of diseases (abnormalities in structure &amp; function). It is the study of abnormal anatomy, abnormal histology, abnormal biochemistry and abnormal physiology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathology-comprises-the-study-of">Pathology comprises the study of:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-comprises-the-study-of" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Definition and epidemiology: name of the disease, its incidence, prevalence in a population and its geographic distribution</li>
<li>Etiology (cause): Etiology means the causes of the disease and pathogenesis (mechanism): The aetiology includes:
a) Predisposing factors: Factors which help the development of the disease.
b) Exciting factor: Is the direct cause of the disease.
c) Pathogenesis: The mechanism by which the causative agent produces the pathological changes in the tissues.</li>
<li>Manifestations :Pathology entails the description of any deviation from normal on the tissue as well as the body level:
a) Organ morphology (gross pathology and microscopic pathology): deals with changes in the appearance of an organ (gross or macroscopic) and on the level of the tissue forming that organ (microscopic).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Gross picture (macroscopic picture): These are the changes in the tissues and organs detected on naked-eye examination.</li>
<li>Microscopic picture (histopathology): These are the changes in the tissues and organs detected on light microscopic examination.</li>
<li>Electron microscopic, immunohistochemical, cytogenetic and molecular are modes of study of diseased tissues and organs
b) Body reaction: Is the effect of damage in a particular organ affecting other body systems which are also involved in the process and this includes the clinical picture</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Sequelae: course or progress of the disease</li>
<li>Fate is the disease outcome or end result, which may be recovery with return to normal, or complications (unhealthy effects). These are additional pathological changes which may occur during or after the termination of the usual course of the disease. They may occur at the site of disease &amp; away from the site (spread to other organs).</li>
<li>Prognosis( prediction of the course of a disease)</li>
</ol>
<p>Good prognosis: cure or recovery
Bad prognosis: progression of disease (morbidity) or death (mortality)</p>
<p>Normal cell <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>&nbsp;Injury&nbsp;</mtext></mpadded></mover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\xrightarrow{\text { Injury }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1113em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1003em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">&nbsp;Injury&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
 11 8 0 13.2-.8 15.5-2.5 2.3-1.7 4.2-5.5 5.5-11.5 2-13.3 5.7-27 11-41 14.7-44.7
 39-84.5 73-119.5s73.7-60.2 119-75.5c6-2 9-5.7 9-11s-3-9-9-11c-45.3-15.3-85
-40.5-119-75.5s-58.3-74.8-73-119.5c-4.7-14-8.3-27.3-11-40-1.3-6.7-3.2-10.8-5.5
-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67

Pathologic lesion
Clinical picture</p>
<ul>
<li>Function:biochem+physiology</li>
<li>Structure:anatomy+histology</li>
</ul>
<p>Diagnosis
Treatment
Follow up
Prevention</p>
<p>Damage at site
Local
Body reaction
General (systemic)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-1-etiology-pathogenesis">1.1 ETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-etiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-582f723e.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-cell-injury">1) CELL INJURY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-cell-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Physical &amp; chemical
Microbial
Hormonal
Mechanical
Vascular &amp; circulatory
Immunological
(antibodies &amp; cell-mediated)
Nutritional</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-genetic">B. GENETIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-genetic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1-Normal genes
Susceptibility genes
Blood group genes
2- Abnormal genes (Mutations) 3) CIRCULATORY DISTURBANCE
Congenital: at birth
Hereditary: passed on from parents
Malformations(Hereditary &amp;congenital)
C. MULTIFACTORIAL <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(A+B)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-growth-disturbances">4)GROWTH DISTURBANCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-growth-disturbances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adaptations
Neoplasia (tumors)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-immunopathology">5) IMMUNOPATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-immunopathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-2-manifestations-of-disease-lesions">1.2 MANIFESTATIONS OF DISEASE-LESIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-manifestations-of-disease-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-20b1cae0.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Please I: Functional disturbance stage: At this level of affection, samples obtained from body fluids reveal mostly functional changes, which can be diagnosed by hematology, chemical pathology or by molecular and genetic methods.</li>
<li>Phase II: Functional and early morphologic changes: At this level, cellular changes may be diagnosed from body fluids by hematology, chemical pathology and cytology or in tissue by biopsy and submitted for molecular and genetic methods as well as electron microscopy.</li>
<li>Phase III: Functional and morphologic changes diagnosed from body fluids submitted to hematological, cytological, molecular and genetic evaluation or tissue biopsy, to be evaluated like phase II of diseases, by microscopic examination in addition to gross organ or tissue evaluation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-3-doctor-s-approach-to-patient">1.3 DOCTOR'S APPROACH TO PATIENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-3-doctor-s-approach-to-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-clinician">1) CLINICIAN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-clinician" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>History taking to determine epidemiological data and symptoms of the patient</li>
<li>Clinical examination to determine signs of the disease discovered on examination</li>
<li>Provisional diagnosis &amp; differential diagnosis are based on signs &amp; symptoms</li>
<li>Final diagnosis usually after requesting special investigations or sample taking</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-pathologist-other-specialties">2) PATHOLOGIST/other specialties:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-pathologist-other-specialties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations: ------------x-ray, ultrasound, CT scan etc ...</li>
<li>Laboratory work out ------pathologists</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathology-sample">PATHOLOGY SAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-sample" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluids">Fluids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood or bone marrow (hematology lab)</li>
<li>Stools or urine (chemical pathology-microbiology)</li>
<li>Body fluids (cytology lab)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="organ-tissue-autopsy-biopsy">Organ/tissue (autopsy-biopsy)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organ-tissue-autopsy-biopsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Surgical pathology
(histopathology)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="role-of-pathologist">ROLE OF PATHOLOGIST:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#role-of-pathologist" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Making the final diagnosis, monitoring of treatment and follow up of patients</p>
<p>BIOPSY: tissue removed during surgery from living patient
CYTOLOGY: study of cells derived from body fluids
AUTOPSY: tissue removed after death i.e. during a post mortem</p>
<p>IF diagnosis is difficult, pathologists resort to special staining:</p>
<ul>
<li>cyto/histochemistry</li>
<li>Immuno cyto/histochemistry</li>
<li>Molecular pathology &amp; Cytogenetics</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinician-recieves-report-starts-treatment-based-on-final-diagnosis">CLINICIAN RECIEVES REPORT &amp; STARTS TREATMENT BASED ON FINAL DIAGNOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinician-recieves-report-starts-treatment-based-on-final-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>TREATMENT is either curative (cures) or palliative (can't cure but helps symptom relief)</p>
<p>Treatment depends on diagnosis &amp; prognosis and follow up may be required in some cases even after recovery e.g. recurrent tumour</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-response-to-injury">CELL RESPONSE TO INJURY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-response-to-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>REVERSIBLE (cell can revert to normal state) intracellular changes</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Adaptive mechanisms: atrophy-hypertrophy-hyperplasia-metaplasia</li>
<li>Degeneration</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>IRREVERSIBLE (cell death) intracellular changes</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Apoptosis</li>
<li>Necrosis</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>DEPOSITIONS - ABNORMAL PIGMENTATION- ABNORMAL CALCIFICATION</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Extracellular depositions: Amyloid .</li>
<li>Extra &amp; intracellular depositions accumulations: Protein (hyalinosis), Mucin (myxomatous change), pigment disorders &amp; abnormal calcification.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="injurious-agents">INJURIOUS AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#injurious-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-environmental">1. ENVIRONMENTAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-environmental" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Physical: Excessive heat - Excessive cold (frost bite) - Irradiation</li>
<li>Chemical: toxins - free radicals - acids - alkalis</li>
<li>Infections: bacteria, viruses, parasites</li>
<li>Immunological: self antigen (autoimmunity) - foreign proteins (antigens)</li>
<li>Circulatory: hypoxia or ischemia</li>
<li>Nutritional: protein calorie deficiency-vitamin deficiency</li>
<li>Mechanical: trauma</li>
<li>Hormonal</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-genetic">2. GENETIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-genetic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Congenital: Down's syndrome</li>
<li>Hereditary: metabolic enzyme disorders</li>
<li>Mutations: cancer</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-multifactorial">3. MULTIFACTORIAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-multifactorial" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-action-of-injurious-agent">Mechanism of action of injurious agent:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-action-of-injurious-agent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypoxia: deficient oxygenation to tissues</li>
<li>Toxic: free radicals and other poisonous chemicals</li>
<li>Direct: injury to cell</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="type-of-damage-depends-on-tissue-type-severity-duration-of-injurious-agent">Type of damage depends on tissue type, severity &amp;duration of injurious agent:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-of-damage-depends-on-tissue-type-severity-duration-of-injurious-agent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Type of tissue:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Labile cells (rapid regeneration e.g. skin) divide continuously.</li>
<li>Stable cells (cells of parenchymatous organs &amp; connective tissue) divide only when injured.</li>
<li>Permanent cells (never divides e.g. striated muscle-neurons).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Severity of injury &amp; its duration:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Short mild-moderate injury results in reversible damage</li>
<li>Severe short or mild to moderate &amp; prolonged injury results in irreversible damage</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminology">TERMINOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Degenerations: Concentration of metabolites or changes which occur inside metabolically active cells (parenchymatous epithelial cells) i.e. not in macrophages or other connective tissue cells or lymphoid cells e.g. hydropic &amp; fatty change.</li>
<li>Accumulations: Concentration of material formed outside the cell (carbohydrate, protein or lipid), inside any cell (epithelial or mesenchymal), due to deranged metabolism or excess storage e.g. hyalinosis &amp; storage diseases.</li>
<li>Depositions: Concentration of material outside cells i.e. on fibers, basement membranes e.g. amyloidosis, necrotic material, products of inflammation &amp; organizing thrombus e.g. dystrophic calcification.</li>
</ul>
<p>ACCUMULATIONS &amp; DEPOSITIONS</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Intracellular</th><th style="text-align: left;">Extra+intracellular</th><th style="text-align: left;">Extracellular</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Water=hydropic/vacuolar</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Fat =fatty change &lt;br&gt; lipid storage disease &lt;br&gt; atherosclerosis</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">CHO =mucoid change</td><td style="text-align: left;">myxomatous change</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Glycogen = storage disease</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Amyloid</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Protein =hyaline change</td><td style="text-align: left;">Hyaline change</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Pigment = lipochrome &lt;br&gt; Melanin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Carbon (tattoo) &lt;br&gt; Hemosiderin/hemochromatosis &lt;br&gt; Jaundice (bilirubin) &lt;br&gt; Calcium(dystrophic&amp;metastatic)</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MOST FORMS OF DAMAGE are usually accompanied by a BODY REACTION and both together (damage + body reaction), form a pathologic lesion or disease (5 main disease patterns:</p>
<p>Inflammatory, degenerative, circulatory disorders, growth disturbances, immunological)</p>
<p>Subcellular response to injury (reversible &amp; irreversible) (plate 1.2)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-first-line-of-injury">1. First line of injury:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-first-line-of-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Mitochondria: Are respiratory organelles (ATP energy source) &amp; source of some lipids. They are altered in acute cell injury or death</p>
<ul>
<li>Increased Number =Hypertrophy ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> cell size)</li>
<li>Decreased Number = Atrophy ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> cell size)</li>
<li>Large size =Hydropic change &amp; Oncocytoma (a tumour)
B. Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum (RER)</li>
</ul>
<p>Injury causes loss of ribosomes affecting protein synthesis, whilst dilatation of the RER produces vacuolar change.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-second-line-ofinjury">2. Second line ofinjury:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-second-line-ofinjury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum (SER):</p>
<p>Important in cell adaptation, lipid synthesis &amp; drug storage</p>
<ul>
<li>Drug tolerance results in swelling of SER leading to cell hypertrophy</li>
<li>Injury releases heat &amp; shock (stress) proteins these can protect from tissue damage i.e. limitation of damage</li>
<li>Lipid accumulation: fatty change &amp; storage disorders
B. Cytoskeletal abnormalities:</li>
</ul>
<p>Result in loss of support with change in cell shape and decreased cell motility</p>
<ul>
<li>Defective cell movement diminishes migration of inflammatory celis with subsequent decreased phagocytosis</li>
<li>Defective organelle movement results in decreased ciliary action e.g. in respiratory tract this encourages infection Mitotic spindle abnormalities in spermatozoa result in infertility</li>
<li>Defective intracellular accumulation of fibrils e.g. Alzheimer neurofibrillary tanglesn replacing functioning brain tissue and resulting in dementia
C. Lysosomal catabolism: they contain digestive enzymes</li>
</ul>
<p>1ry lysosomes fusion with membrane bound vesicles of endocytosisis (pinocytosis or phagocytosis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> 2ry lysosome or phagolysosome
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-3712a02d.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="residual-body-e-g">Residual body e.g.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#residual-body-e-g" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. undigested debris (lipochrome)
b. undigested pigment (tattoo)</p>
<p>Lysosomes normally can sequester or store material which cannot be metabolized but in case of enzyme deficiencies (metabolic disorders) producing lysosomal storage disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-final-step">3. Final step<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-final-step" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Plasma &amp; nuclear membrane damage occurs in cell death i.e. necrosis</p>
<ul>
<li>Nucleus is important in mitosis &amp; protein synthesis</li>
<li>Plasma membrane is important in carrying receptors that recognize environment <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\&amp;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">&amp;</span></span></span></span></span> is responsible for the passage of molecules to &amp; from the cell (phagocytosis-pinocytosis-selective permeability)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="loss-of-these-functions-results-in-cell-death">LOSS OF THESE FUNCTIONS RESULTS IN CELL DEATH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#loss-of-these-functions-results-in-cell-death" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plate-1-1">PLATE 1-1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-1-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a85057d0.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<p>Cell Ultrastucture from homepage.smc.edulwissmann_paul/cell/Default.html</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plate-1-2">PLATE 1.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-1-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagram-of-subcellular-changes-in-cell-injury">Diagram of SUBCELLULAR CHANGES in cell Injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagram-of-subcellular-changes-in-cell-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-9ad78ddd.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> Ribosomes in RER <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> of protein synthesis</li>
<li>Dilatation of SER <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> lipid accumulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span> Fatty change</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> plasma membrane demage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow \uparrow \uparrow \mathrm{Ca}^{++}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶↑↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ca</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">++</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>influx</li>
</ul>
<p>Loss of ptn:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f6747d32.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
a. Coenzmes
b. RNA + metabolites
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f03e3a99.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-reversible-cell-changes">I) Reversible cell changes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-reversible-cell-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-cell-adaptation-of-growth-size-or-number-differentiation">A. CELL ADAPTATION of growth (size or number) &amp; differentiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-cell-adaptation-of-growth-size-or-number-differentiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cells adapt to acceptable changes in their environment by modification of their metabolism &amp; growth pattern (increased or decreased cell activity or altered structure)
A. PHYSIOLOGIC: A physiologic ability to maintain normal function according to demand as changes that occur under the effect of hormones e.g. breast enlargement during lactation due to increased cell activity &amp; altered cell morphology.
B. PATHOLOGIC: Severer changes in cell environment outside an acceptable range of normality. This involves the following:</p>
<ol>
<li>Synthesis of new proteins e.g. stress proteins</li>
<li>Over production of specific proteins e.g. in chronic inflammation with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> collagen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\&amp; \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">&amp;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> extracellular matrix proteins.</li>
<li>Adaptation in cell growth ( see growth disturbances)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Atrophy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">=↓</span></span></span></span></span> cell size resulting in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> weight &amp; size of organ</li>
<li>Involution <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">=↓</span></span></span></span></span> cell number resulting in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> weight &amp; size of organ (occurs in physiological process of apoptosis)</li>
<li>Hypertrophy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">=↑</span></span></span></span></span> cell size resulting in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> organ weight &amp; size</li>
<li>Hyperplasia <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">=↑</span></span></span></span></span> cell number resulting in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> organ weight &amp; size</li>
<li>Metaplasia <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">=↑</span></span></span></span></span> cell number &amp; change in cell type e.g. columnar cells : Changes to squamous or vice versa (see growth disturbances)</li>
</ul>
<p>NB: Hypoplasia &amp; agensis are also decreased cell numbers, bur of developmental origin</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrophy-plate-2">ATROPHY (plate 2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrophy-plate-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Decrease in size of cells with decrease in size &amp; weight of organ after organ had reached its adult size.
A. Physiologic:
a) Localized atrophy as thymus after puberty &amp; breasts after menopause.
b) Generalized atrophy in case of senility. aging results in diminution in organ size &amp; function e.g brown atrophy of the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-pathologic">B. Pathologic:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-pathologic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a) Generalized atrophy: It affects all organs. Heart is small, skin is wrinkled due to loss of elastic fibers, bones and muscle are week, teeth fall ... etc. Causes include:
i. Decreased anabolism in cases of chronic malnutrition and starvation.
ii. Increased catabolism as in advanced stages of malignancy (cachexia) &amp; thyrotoxicosis.
b) Localized atrophy: Mechanism &amp; types</p>
<ol>
<li>Hormonal atrophy / endocrinal (due to loss of hormonal stimulation) e.g. breast atrophy following bilateral excision of ovaries &amp; pituitary deficiency with diminished hormone production e.g. atrophy of thyroid, gonads &amp; adrenals.</li>
<li>Vascular atrophy: e.g.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis of renal artery <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> narrowing of lumen &amp; renal atrophy.</li>
<li>Pressure atrophy due to compression of blood vessels from outside example aneurysm <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> atrophy of the underlying vertebral bodies.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Pressure atrophy: same mechanism as vascular atrophy</li>
<li>Neuropathic atrophy: Atrophy of limb muscles due to loss of innervation as in poliomyelitis activity or diminished function ends in atrophy of muscle</li>
<li>Disuse atrophy: e.g. muscles after prolonged immobilization after a fracture of bone.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="brown-atrophy-of-the-heart">BROWN ATROPHY OF THE HEART:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brown-atrophy-of-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Aging results in wear and tear and an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> in the wear &amp; tear pigment (lipochrome) as well as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> function resulting in atrophy and dark brown coloration of cardiac muscle.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Gross</th><th style="text-align: left;">Microscopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Size &amp; wt : Decreased</td><td style="text-align: left;">Size of muscle fibers: Decreased &lt;br&gt; Paranuclear yellow-brown pigment</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Surface:</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Loss of pericardial fat, which is</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">replaced by jelly like material</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Tortuous coronaries</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Color: dark brown</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ageing">AGEING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ageing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. True aging: Aging not complicated by disease i.e. aging under minimal stress. The main controlling mechanism is intrinsic (genetic?) mitochondrial DNA changes:</p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> mitochondrial oxidative enzymes results in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> energy</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> synthesis of enzymes &amp; protein receptor responsible for metabolism &amp; growth</li>
</ul>
<p>NB: most cases are accelerated &amp; aggravated by 2 groups of extrinsic factors:</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> stress of infection - degenerative diseases (e.g. cardiac)-accidents-wear &amp; tear with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> free radical especially if exposed to irradiation- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> antioxidants e.g. vitamin E &amp; or / glutathione peroxidase.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> immune response with inability to respond to stress.</li>
</ol>
<p>Aging alone rarely causes death and usually one or more of the above accelerating or aggravating factors are present causing death.
B. Premature aging (progeria): Early aging is due to an error in DNA replication &amp; improper repair with DECREASED cell viability</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypertrophy-plate-2">HYPERTROPHY (Plate 2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypertrophy-plate-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Increased size &amp; weight of organ due to increase in size of its cells, which have synthesized actively metabolic structural components, necessary for increasing the metabolism.</p>
<p>Physiologic: Pregnant uterus due to hormone stimulation &amp; muscle hypertrophy in athletes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathologic">Pathologic:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathologic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Adaptive type: It affects the muscle coat of hollow organs due to increased intra-luminal pressure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Left ventricular hypertrophy due to hypertension or aortic valve stenosis.</li>
<li>Urinary bladder hypertrophy due to stricture of the bladder neck</li>
</ul>
<p>b) Compensatory type: If one of a paired organ is out of function or surgically removed, the other organ undergoes compensatory hypertrophy e.g. kidney enlargement when the other kidney is surgically removed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyperplasia-plate-2">HYPERPLASIA (plate 2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperplasia-plate-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition Increased size &amp; weight of organ due to Increase in number of its cells (Increased cell division). Hyperplasia can occur in any cell type capable of division.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Physiologic</th><th style="text-align: center;">Pathologic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1) hormonal hyperplasia <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> mammary glands&amp; genitalia at puberty due to estrogen stimulation.</td><td style="text-align: center;">1) hormonal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> endometrial hyperplasia in repeated anovulatory cycles &amp; benign prostatic hyperplasia due to estrogen stimulation.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2) compensatory <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> bone marrow hyperplasia after hemorrhage.</td><td style="text-align: center;">2) lymphoid hyperplasia in response to antigenic stimulation</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metaplasia-plate-2">METAPLASIA (plate 2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metaplasia-plate-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Transformation of 1 mature differentiated cell type to another of the same histologic type( i.e epithelium to epithelium) in response to an injurious agent, which is more resistant to chronic injury it involves an increase in number of cells &amp; change in their morphology.
N.B.: Like hyperplasia it is precancerous.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clerk-2">CLERK 2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clerk-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plate-2-adaptations-from-webpath">PLATE 2 Adaptations from WebPath<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-2-adaptations-from-webpath" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-69a6219a.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>Endometrial hyperplasia Prostatic gland hyperplasia Esophageal metaplasia</p>
<p>PLATE 3 CELL DEATH FROM WebPath
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-9c61fa79.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg"></p>
<p>Coagulative Necrosis
heart Infarction</p>
<p>Liquifactive
Necrosis (pus)</p>
<p>Apoptotic bodies
arrows (liver)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="etiology-pathogenesis-types">Etiology, Pathogenesis &amp; Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology-pathogenesis-types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-epithelial-metaplasia">A. Epithelial Metaplasia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-epithelial-metaplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Squamous Metaplasia: transformation of columnar or transitional cells to squamous epithelium which is tougher e.g. bilharzial epithelial urinary bladder changes &amp; chronic cervicitis. This is sometimes followed by leukoplakia.
b) Leukoplakia : columnar or transitional cells <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Keratinized squamous epithelium, which is tougher e.g. Bilharzial epithelial UB changes &amp; chronic cervicitis</p>
<p>Gross: Thick irregular white mucosal patches related to chronic irritation
Microscopic: Squamous epithelium + keratinization+ chronic inflammation in subepithelium
c) Intestinal Metaplasia: columnar cells change into mucous secreting cells like those of intestine e.g. gastritis and at the edges of peptic ulcers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-mesenchymal-metaplasia">B. Mesenchymal Metaplasia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-mesenchymal-metaplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fibroblasts exposed to chronic injury change <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Osteoblasts
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c37f20c7.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg">
e.g. Myositis ossificans: muscle fiber injury causing necrosis results in granulation tissue. The fibroblasts of which undergo osteoblastic metaplasia to bone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-intracellular-changes">B. INTRACELLULAR CHANGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-intracellular-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="degeneration">DEGENERATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#degeneration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Acute reversible cell injury to parenchymatous cells, (i.e. metabolically active e.g. epithelial organs &amp; muscle) resulting in an accumulation of water or fat. (Carbohydrates &amp; proteins may also accumulate intracellularly).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-hydropic-swelling-cloudy-swelling-vacuolar-change">1. HYDROPIC SWELLING (cloudy swelling) &amp; VACUOLAR CHANGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-hydropic-swelling-cloudy-swelling-vacuolar-change" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION Accumulation of water intracellularly. Hydropic swelling, formerly called cloudy swelling then proceeds to VACUOLAR CHANGE (dilatation of mitochondria &amp; RER with water leading to vacuoles).</p>
<p>PATHOGENESIS: Injurious agent (see before), of a toxic or hypoxic nature produce mitochondrial damage with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> ATP production. This causes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> plasma membrane <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump action (ATP energy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+\mathrm{Na}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9279em;
