vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>enters the cell drawing with it water <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span>osmosis) &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> leave cells. The cell swell &amp; the beaded mitochondria give the cell the granular or cloudy appearance. More injury causing mitochondrial + RER swelling resulting in VACUOLAR CHANGE.</p>
<p>SITES: Parenchymatous organs e.g. liver, kidney tubules, heart and other glandular epithelium of organs.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">GROSS</th><th style="text-align: left;">MICROSCOPIC</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Surface: Smooth-capsule stretched</td><td style="text-align: left;">a) Hydropic swelling: Cells swell &amp; have a &lt;br&gt; granular pale pink cytoplasm</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Size &amp; weight : increased</td><td style="text-align: left;">b) Hydropic vacuolation: Cells swell &amp; &lt;br&gt; have vacuolated cytoplasm</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Color: Pale grey or pale brown</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cut section: Round edges &amp; bulging cut &lt;br&gt; surface</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Consistency: Soft (water)</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-fatty-change-steatosis-plate-4">2. FATTY CHANGE (Steatosis) (Plate 4)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-fatty-change-steatosis-plate-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Accumulation of neutral fat intracellularly in parenchymatous organs as a result of reversible cell injury e.g. in viral hepatitis C</p>
<p>AETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS (see list of injurious agents)
E.G. HEPATIC STEATOSIS (Fatty change liver)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Liver</th><th style="text-align: center;">Mechanism of injury</th><th style="text-align: center;">Subcellular change</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Central zone</td><td style="text-align: center;">- Hypoxic injury</td><td style="text-align: center;">- Damage + dilatation of &lt;br&gt; 1. Mitochondrial &lt;br&gt; 2. RER &lt;br&gt; 3. SER</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Peripheral zone</td><td style="text-align: center;">- Toxic injury: Bacteria, chemical or viral e.g. viral hepatitis C. &lt;br&gt; - Specific hepatocellular causes (site of fat metabolism) &lt;br&gt; 1) Deficiency of lipotropic factors (choline-methionine) &lt;br&gt; 2) 2) Starvation &amp; Diabetes mellitus due to tfat mobilization from stores &lt;br&gt; 3) Obesity &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> fat diet due to overloading of hepatocyte with free fatty acids &lt;br&gt; 4) Alcohol due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> free fatty acid synthesis (hepatotoxin): <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> fatty acid oxidation with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> fat mobilization from stores.</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">GROSS</th><th style="text-align: left;">MICROSCOPIC</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Specimen: liver</td><td style="text-align: left;">Fat appears as empty vacuoles</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Surface: Smooth - capsule stretched</td><td style="text-align: left;">Microvesicular: small vacuoles</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cut section: round edges-bulging cut &lt;br&gt; surface.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Signet ring cell: large vacuole which &lt;br&gt; causes cell swelling with pushing of nucleus &lt;br&gt; to one side i.e. eccentric nucleus.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Color: Yellow &lt;br&gt; Consistency: Soft</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>FATTY INFILTRATION: Excess adipose tissue in-between parenchymal cells e.g. in obesity there is both fatty infiltration as well as fatty change. Sites other than liver or heart become yellow, enlarged &amp; flabby-Kidney becomes yellow, enlarged &amp; soft.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sequlae-complications">SEQULAE &amp; COMPLICATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sequlae-complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Temporary disturbance in function.</li>
<li>If injury persists, fatty change may end in necrosis &amp; fibrosis with organ failure.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-irreversible-cellular-changes">II) Irreversible cellular changes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-irreversible-cellular-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="necrosis-cell-death-plate-3">NECROSIS &amp; CELL DEATH (plate 3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#necrosis-cell-death-plate-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definitions-of-cell-death">DEFINITIONS OF CELL DEATH:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definitions-of-cell-death" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Necrosis: Irreversible injury, resulting in death of groups of cells, in a living tissue. It is accompanied by an acute inflammatory reaction.</li>
<li>Necrobiosis (apoptosis &amp; autophagy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>1</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ): programmed single cell death in a living tissue. It is not accompanied by inflammation.</li>
<li>Autolysis death of groups of cells and tissues because of death of the host. Dead cells release lysosomal enzymes, which cause further cell breakdown. It is not accompanied by inflammation but by decomposition (from bacteria escaping the gut).</li>
</ol>
<p>1 autophagy is another form of programmed cell death whereby the cell digests its internal organelles which are damaged.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-necrosis">TYPES OF NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Coagulative or ischaemic necrosis: Dead tissue appears firm &amp; pale, e.g. renal, splenic or myocardial infarction. It is characterized by outline preservation since protein denaturation more than enzyme denaturation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Liquefactive or colliquative necrosis: Dead tissue appears liquid &amp; pale e.g. pus &amp; brain infarction with loss of cell detail since enzyme denaturation more than protein denaturation. The necrotic area softens and becomes turbid fluid (gross and microscopic features of pus see Inflammation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Caseous necrosis: Dead tissue appears soft &amp; creamy e.g. tuberculosis (TB) is a type of coagulative necrosis rich in lipids from the bacterial wall giving it a semi solid cheesy appearance (gross &amp; mic TB).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gummatous necrosis: Dead tissue appears firm &amp; rubbery e.g. syphylis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gangrenous necrosis e.g. Dry &amp; wet gangrene = ischaemic necrosis + putrefaction (see circulatory disturbances).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fat necrosis &amp; enzymatic fat necrosis: Foci of hard yellow material in adipose tissue e.g. Traumatic fat necrosis of breast &amp; enzymatic necrosis of the omental fat in pancreatitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrinoid necrosis e.g. Muscle in toxemia, Aschoff nodule &amp; wall of blood vessels in arteritis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemorrhagic necrosis: Dead tissue is full of extravasated RBC's when the cause is venous obstruction.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aetiology-pathogenesis">AETIOLOGY &amp;PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>See causes of cell injury
Severe irreversible damage with loss of nuclear &amp; cell membranes</p>
<ul>
<li>Lethal Injury results in loss of RNA &amp; protein denaturation responsible for the homogenous dark pink cytoplasm.</li>
<li>Sustained sublethal injury: The damaged cell membrane causes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>&amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span></span></span></span></span> entry into the cell. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Osmotic pressure inside cell causes swelling of necrotic cells. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> enzymes escape from the cell due to loss of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>pump mechanism and lysosomal membrane damage causes escape of enzymes and high level of enzymes in the blood.</li>
<li>Organelle breakdown also increased intracellular osmotic pressure,decreased mitochondrial RNA &amp; increased cytosolic calcium which activates protein kinases, proteases &amp; phosphokinases.</li>
<li>Nuclear membrane damage results in: Karyopyknosis - Karyorrhexis- Karyolysis
N.B.: Increased enzymes a) in the blood are the first signs of necrosis b) At site of injury, the enzymes &amp; chemical mediators released into the tissue cause irritation of the living tissues resulting in an acute inflammatory reaction and degenerative changes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-coagulative-necrosis-ischaemic-necrosis">1. COAGULATIVE NECROSIS (ischaemic necrosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-coagulative-necrosis-ischaemic-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: death of parts of tissues. It is usually secondary to lack of blood supply i.e. no oxygenation. e.g. infarction of solid organs: heart, spleen &amp; kidney.</p>
<p>TYPES: Pale &amp; Red infarctions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-recent-infarction">A) Recent Infarction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-recent-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>GROSS Pale: in most solid organs since the blood cells can be squeezed by the swollen necrotic cells. Such infarctions are usually swollen and bulge from surface.</p>
<p>Red (haemorrhagic): in loose tissue (intestine-lung) since blood cells can't be squeezed by the swollen necrotic cells so they accumulate in the alveoli. This can also occur in solid organs e.g. spleen if there was previous chronic venous congestion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Homogenous dark pink cytoplasm of necrotic cells (protein denaturation).</li>
<li>Swelling of cells(damaged plasma membrane allows Na &amp; H20 into the cell).</li>
<li>Nuclear membrane damage results in.</li>
</ul>
<p>Karyopyknosis: shrunken dark nucleus due to condensation of chromatin.
Karyorrhexis: fragmentation of nucleus.
Karyolysis: disappearance or lysis of nucleus or simply a pale fading nucleus.</p>
<ul>
<li>NECROTIC AREA IS PINK AND GRANULAR CONTAINING NUCLEAR DEBRIS. The more resistant connective tissue and cells retain some of their outlines and appear as ghosts. (BR).
B) Healed Infarctions (BR): Are pale, formed of fibrous tissue, which causes shrinkage of the lesion and thus the healed, infarcted area is depressed below the surface. They still retain the original pyramidal shape.
N.B.: Infarctions do not occur in healthy lungs or liver since both organs have a double blood supply.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-liquefactive-necrosis">2. LIQUEFACTIVE NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-liquefactive-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Pus: see chapter of inflammation (abscess)</li>
<li>Cerebral infarction: due to occlusion of cerebral arteries. It is rapidly liquefied due to the high fat content in the brain, which on cutting of tissue will leave a cavity</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>CASEOUS NECROSIS: see tuberculosis (combination of coagulative &amp; liquifactive)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-fat-necrosis">4. FAT NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-fat-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Enzymatic fat necrosis e.g. in pancreatitis release of pancreatic enzymes act on the omentum &amp; mesentery resulting in necrotic fat cells which release triglycerides producing fatty acids which unite with calcium producing insoluble soapy material. This appears white in color.
b) Traumatic fat necrosis occurs in the fat of the breast, resulting in a granulomatous reaction to the necrotic fat cells which release their irritating contents and produce an acute inflammatory reaction. This is followed by a localized form of chronic inflammation characterized by lakes of fat surrounded by lipid laden macrophages (foam cells) + lymphocytes, plasma cells, giant cells and fibrous tissue.
c) FIBRINOID NECROSIS: is a type of necrosis of connective tissue especially muscle fibers e.g. in immunological disorders arteritis &amp; rheumatic fever. The affected wall of the blood vessels becomes a swollen dark pink homogeneous mass with narrowing of the lumen. In Toxemia, the anterior abdominal wall muscle becomes a homogeneous pink mass with swelling of the muscle fibers.
d) GANGRENOUS NECROSIS: ischaemic necrosis associated with putrefaction (see circulatory disturbances) (combination of coagulative &amp; liquefactive).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-necrotic-tissue">Fate of necrotic tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-necrotic-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="this-depends-on-amount-of-necrosis">(This depends on amount of necrosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#this-depends-on-amount-of-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Minimal necrosis</th><th style="text-align: left;">The few necrotic cells are surrounded by &lt;br&gt; inflammation and the macrophages and &lt;br&gt; PNLs remove the debris.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Excessive necrosis</td><td style="text-align: left;">The cells &amp; the connective tissue are both &lt;br&gt; damaged resulting in healing by &lt;br&gt; organization with replacement fibrosis.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>N.B.: If there is no organization or incomplete organization, the remaining necrotic tissue (alkaline medium) helps deposition of calcium salts (dystrophic calcification) e.g. TB and atherosclerosis.</p>
<p>OTHER FORMS OF CELL DEATH</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">AUTOLYSIS</th><th style="text-align: center;">APOPTOSIS (plate3)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Postmortem change</td><td style="text-align: center;">During life</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Self digestion of cells and tissues</td><td style="text-align: center;">Single cell suicide (programmed cell death) which occurd during life.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Depends on role of enzyme activity after death</td><td style="text-align: center;">1. Occurs in physiologic conditions as Embryogenesis, menstruation &amp; thymus involution. &lt;br&gt; 2. Pathologic states e.g in viral hepatitis &amp; defective apoptosis genes leading to tumor formation.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>APOPTOTIC CHANGES: are said to occur as a result of stimulation of endogenous endonucleases.</p>
<ul>
<li>Cells shrink because of organellar condensation, their cytoplasm also becomes deep pink. The chromatin in nucleus condenses beneath nuclear membrane</li>
<li>Shrunken cells form surface outgrowths called blebs, which contain some organelles and possibly nuclear fragments.</li>
<li>Blebs detach from cell surface with a complete plasma membrane around them. Some contain nuclear fragments others are devoid (Apoptotic bodies).</li>
<li>Macrophages phagocytose these bodies &amp; quickly get rid of them.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-responses-range-from-reversible-damage-to-irreversible-necrosis">CELL RESPONSES RANGE FROM REVERSIBLE DAMAGE TO IRREVERSIBLE NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-responses-range-from-reversible-damage-to-irreversible-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If damage is minimal cell can recover after removing stimulus. Damaged protein &amp; organelles are removed by cell stress response &amp; self digestion autophagy &amp; new structural components are synthesized.</p>
<p>If stimulus is sublethal &amp; cell cant recover or stimulus is lethal from start, a set of structural damage involving cell, organellar &amp; nuclear membrane damage occurs as well as protein coagulation(necrosis).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-depositions-abnormal-pigmentation-abnormal-calcification">III) Depositions-abnormal pigmentation- abnormal calcification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-depositions-abnormal-pigmentation-abnormal-calcification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-extracellular-depositions">A. EXTRACELLULAR DEPOSITIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-extracellular-depositions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amyloid-glycoprotein-plate-4">AMYLOID (glycoprotein) (plate 4)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amyloid-glycoprotein-plate-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Waxy extracellular deposit of abnormal protein (B pleated fibrils) and nonfibrillary glycoproteins (normal serum amyloid protein P (SAP) +carbohydrate heparan <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{SO}_{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">SO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (glycosaminoglycans GAG), on basement membranes of blood vessels &amp; epithelial acini, as well as on connective tissue reticular fibers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aetiology-pathogenesis">AETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Old terminology: Primary amyloidosis: unknown cause &amp; Secondary amyloidosis: 2ry to chronic disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="new-terminology">New terminology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#new-terminology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-systemic-amyloidosis">A. Systemic Amyloidosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-systemic-amyloidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Systemic amyloidosis has been classified into three major types that are very different from each other. These are distinguished by a two-letter code that begins with an A (for amyloid). The second letter of the code stands for the protein that accumulates in the tissues in that particular type of amyloidosis. The types of systemic amyloidosis are currently categorized as primary (AL), secondary (AA), and hereditary (ATTR).</p>
<ol>
<li>Primary amyloidosis: or AL, occurs when a specialized cell in the bone marrow (plasma cell) spontaneously overproduces a particular protein portion of an antibody called the light chain. e.g. multiple myeloma.</li>
<li>Secondary amyloidosis: When amyloidosis occurs "secondarily" as a result of another illness, such as chronic infections (e.g, tuberculosis or osteomyelitis), or chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g, rheumatoid arthritis), the condition is referred to as secondary amyloidosis or AA.</li>
<li>Hereditary or Familial amyloidosis: Familial amyloidosis, or ATTR, is a rare form of inherited amyloidosis. The amyloid deposits in familial amyloidosis are composed of the protein transthyretin, or TTR, which is made in the liver. Familial amyloidosis is an inherited autosomal dominant in genetics terminology.</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Hemodialysis associated Amyloidosis: Beta-2 microglobulin amyloidosis occurs when amyloid deposits develop in patients with longstanding kidney failure on dialysis, The amyloid deposits are often found around joints.
C. Localized amyloidoses: Amyloid deposit restricted to one organ or tissue. The cause is unknown. The deposit occurs mainly in:</p>
<ol>
<li>Laryngeal wall forming small tumour-like nodule s</li>
<li>Skin, bronchi, lung, heart and urinary bladder.</li>
<li>Tumours of endocrine glands as medullary carcinoma of thyroid,</li>
<li>Cerebral grey matter in senile dementia. The amyloid deposit is amyloid protein (AB2).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathology-general-features">PATHOLOGY GENERAL FEATURES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-general-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross">GROSS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimen: liver, kidney, spleen, any tissue
Size: Increased size &amp; weight
Surface smooth-capsule stretched
Cut section: sharp edges flat surface
Consistency: firm
Color: pale brown</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-stains">Gross Stains:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-stains" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lugol's lodine2:amyloid (starch-like): stains brown &amp; rest yellow color.</li>
<li>Iodine +H2504: stains amyloid blue.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>H&amp;E: Homogenous pink material deposits on basement membranes &amp; BV Congo red stain: amyloid appears orange red which gives green birefrengence by polarizing light.
Metachromatic stains e.g. (methyl &amp; cresyl violet) .Amyloid stains rose red &amp; rest of tissue is violet
Electron microscopy: Extracellular, haphazardly arranged as non-branching fine fibrils <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \mathrm{~A}^{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8873em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>2 Although amyloid is mostly protein in nature yet due to its blue color with iodine &amp; sulfuric acid it was termed starch-like. This pattern of staining is attributed to the small carbohydrate portion of the molecule (heparan sulphate glycoseaminoglycans GAG)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sequelae-complications">SEQUELAE &amp; COMPLICATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sequelae-complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Pressure on adjacent tissue results in pressure atrophy</li>
<li>Blood vessels get narrowed with decreased blood flow and hypoxia induced fatty change.</li>
<li>Increased permeability of kidney tubules due to amyloid deposits produces excessive leakage of proteins (proteinuria) and casts in kidney.</li>
</ul>
<p>AMYLOID DEPOSITS IN DIFFERENT ORGANS: Almost any tissue can be affected without serious functional impairment except if fibrous tissue replacement of amyloid occurs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kidney">KIDNEY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Gross</th><th style="text-align: left;">Microscopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Pale-firm, waxy with glomeruli &lt;br&gt; appearing as brown dots with iodine</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Deposits mainly on basement &lt;br&gt; membranes of glom capillaries &amp;tubules &lt;br&gt; with thickening of basement membranes &lt;br&gt; which are totally replaced by &lt;br&gt; homogenous pink amyloid and</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">- Gomeruli become swollen and tufts &lt;br&gt; replaced by acellular glassy pink &lt;br&gt; material (amyloid).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">- Tubules with thick BM become atrophic. &lt;br&gt; - <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> permeability of glomeruli causing &lt;br&gt; leaking of protein Into lumen &amp; forming &lt;br&gt; protein casts which indicate heavy &lt;br&gt; proteinuria. This ends in nephrotic &lt;br&gt; syndrome.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gastrointestinal-tract">GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastrointestinal-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amyloid deposits on BM of capillaries producing diarrhea &amp; protein loss, ALSO MALABSORPTION, NUTRITIONAL DEFICIENCY &amp; ELECTROLYTE IMBALANCE.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heart">HEART<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deposition occurs on BM of capillaries and around muscle fibers, causing heart enlargement &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ventricular wall thickness.</p>
<p>Effects: Heart failure occurs mainly due to mechanical effect of amyloid preventing proper muscular contraction + malnutrition due to poor blood supply to muscle fibers ending in muscle atrophy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="liver">LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Amyloid deposits mostly in BM of sinusoids. Sinusoids by time they become occluded with homogenous pink material (amyloid) producing pressure atrophy on hepatocytes + vascular atrophy due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. Gross changes (describe basic reaction BR), but amyloid appears as brown streaks in a yellow background of fatty degeneration (since many hypoxic liver cells undergo hypoxic fatty change).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spleen">SPLEEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spleen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Diffuse type: Amyloid deposits in basement membranes (BM) of sinusoids. Spleen is markedly enlarged (marked splenomegaly).</p>
<p>Sago spleen: Amyloid deposits in central arteriole of white pulp (WP) resulting in its atrophy. This atrophic WP appears grossly as brown dots of amyloid. Spleen is moderately enlarged (moderate splenomegaly).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-intra-extracellular-depositions-accumulations">B. INTRA &amp; EXTRACELLULAR DEPOSITIONS /ACCUMULATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-intra-extracellular-depositions-accumulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-protein-deposit-or-accumulation-hyaline-change-hyalinosis">1. PROTEIN DEPOSIT or ACCUMULATION = HYALINE CHANGE (hyalinosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-protein-deposit-or-accumulation-hyaline-change-hyalinosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Accumulation of intracellular protein or deposition of a glassy pink homogeneous protein in dead or dying tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenesis">PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intracellular">Intracellular<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracellular" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Excess protein is presented to cell e.g. kidney tubules in states of proteinuria.</li>
<li>Increased cell synthesis e.g. plasma cell full of immunoglobulin e.g. Russell body as in rhinoscleroma &amp; liver cell e.g. Mallory body in alcoholic hepatitis.</li>
</ol>
<p>Extracellular: Protein is deposited on: dead or dying tissue:</p>
<ol>
<li>Collagen in scars.</li>
<li>Muscle wall of arterioles in systemic hypertension &amp; diabetes Mellitus.</li>
<li>Mesenchymal tumors.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-mucin-accumulation-deposition-carbohydrates">2. MUCIN ACCUMULATION / deposition (CARBOHYDRATES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-mucin-accumulation-deposition-carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Intracellular mucin accumulation is known as mucoid change where as extracellular deposition= myxomatous change.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mucoid-change-intracellular">Mucoid change (intracellular)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucoid-change-intracellular" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Catarrhal inflammation</li>
<li>Cells of mucoid carcinoma</li>
<li>Cells of mucinous cystadenoma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myxomatous-change-extracellular">Myxomatous change (extracellular)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myxomatous-change-extracellular" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In mesenchymal (connective tissue) tumors</p>
<p>Gross: soft jelly like translucent material
Microscopic: clear swollen cells
Microscopic: stellate cells with outgrowths With signet ring appearance forming a loose network</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-storage-diseases">3. STORAGE DISEASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-storage-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Glycogen (pompe's, McArdle,Von Gierke's disease)
Fat . (Gaucher's disease &amp; Nieman Pick's disease)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenesis">PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Enzyme deficiency leads to accumulation of glycogen or fat in connective tissue (CT) histiocytes as well as in parenchymatous cells</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-pigment-disorders-plate-4">4. PIGMENT DISORDERS (Plate 4)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-pigment-disorders-plate-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endogenous">Endogenous<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endogenous" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>MELANIN: Normally found in: skin, adrenals &amp; choroid plexus and abnormally in neoplasms Melanin is synthesized in melanocytes in the basal layer of epidermis. Pigment is then transported by macrophages called melanophores and remains in dermis giving the skin its color. This process is under the stimulatory effect of UV rays direct action on melanocytes which in turn stimulate pituitary melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH), which regulates the amount of pigment synthesized under the inhibitory effect of adrenocortical hormones. Adrenal medullary hormones, on the other hand, have a direct inhibitory effect on skin melanocytes bypassing the pituitary.</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Local pigmentation</th><th style="text-align: left;">Generalized</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Nevi (hamartoma)</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Suntan</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Malignant neoplasms: Melanoma</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Addison's disease &lt;br&gt; - Chloasma of pregnancy</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="n-b-hypopigmentation-absent-low-melanin-e-g-albinism-leukoderma">N.B.: HYPOPIGMENTATION (Absent / low melanin) e.g. Albinism &amp; Leukoderma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b-hypopigmentation-absent-low-melanin-e-g-albinism-leukoderma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-blood-components">2. BLOOD COMPONENTS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-blood-components" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hemoglobin breaks (in splenic reticuloendothelial cells) into.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f06626cd.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-hemoglobin">a) Hemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Incompatible blood transfusion results in haemolysis which is responsible for tubular necrosis and acute renal failure. Hb is excreted in urine (haemoglobinuria) giving it a red colour.
b) Bilirubin (Non Fe containing pigment): Jaundice
c) Hemosiderin (Fe containing pigment):</p>
<p>Haemosiderosis: environmental
Hemochromatos: genetic
Haemosiderosis: It is the presence of excess iron in the form of hemosiderin. May be local or visceral.
A. Local Haemosiderosis: in local chronic venous congestion of the lung (heart failure cells) &amp; at sites of local trauma e.g. black eye. The RBC's break down in the tissue.</p>
<p>Area is at first red (extravasated RBC's), these become phagocytosed by macrophages (greenish blue color) . haemosiderin &amp; bilirubin are THEN released giving yellowish brown color.
B. Visceral siderosis: seen in liver &amp; spleen, in cases of haemolytic anemia &amp; in patients requiring repeated blood transfusion. The liver becomes deep brown. Fe is found in liver cells &amp; Kupffer cells (Fe can be demonstrated by a +ve Prussian blue reaction)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemochromatosis-bronzed-diabetes-or-primary-hemochromatosis">Hemochromatosis (bronzed diabetes or Primary hemochromatosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemochromatosis-bronzed-diabetes-or-primary-hemochromatosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: This is a genetic defect in the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Fe}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Fe</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>absorption from the intestine, which becomes uncontrolled. This causes the system to be overloaded with Fe , which is deposited as haemosiderin in many sites. NB: ALL Organs become brown</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">MECHANISM:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal mechanism: Fe in diet is taken up by intestinal epithelium, where some are bound to ferritin and returns to the lumen to be excreted. The rest according to body need is not combined and passes to blood, where it is transported on the protein transferrin to reach bone marrow, liver &amp; spleen i.e. sites of Fe utilization. The ferritin content of intestinal epithelium, Fe saturation of plasma, stores of Fe (in the liver, spleen &amp; bone marrow) &amp; t demand for Fe are considered as balancing mechanisms.</p>
<p>Pathological mechanism: Uncontrolled absorption of Fe from the intestine which overloads ferritin system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manifestations-of-hemochromatosis-clinical-picture-cpu">Manifestations of hemochromatosis (clinical picture (CPU))<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations-of-hemochromatosis-clinical-picture-cpu" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pancreas: Pigment in islet cells is associated with fibrosis which ends in diabetes mellitus due to loss of islets.</p>
<p>Liver: deposits in hepatocytes &amp; Kupffer cells, associated with fibrosis ending in cirrhosis
Skin: deposits of haemosiderin around sweat glands &amp; with melanin results in bronze color</p>
<p>Heart: haemosiderin within cytoplasm of cardiac muscle fibers
Mesenteric lymph nodes pigment deposits in reticuloendothelial cells (REC).
Secondary hemochromatosis is a very severe deadly form of hemosiderosis.
d) Haematin: An Fe containing pigment in an unreactive form such as in bilharziasis and malaria.</p>
<p>Malaria parasite &amp; Bilharzia worm ingests <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Hb} \longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7054em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Hb</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> Haematin (altered Hb ) which is phagocytosed by blood monocyte and goes to spleen &amp; liver.
3. LIPOCHROME (lipofuscin): is a wear &amp; tear pigment with a high lipid content. It is found in liver, heart, and testis e.g.: Brown atrophy of heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exogenous">EXOGENOUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exogenous" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>INHALATION: Coal dust pigment which is carbon (anthracosis), blackens tissue Stone dust which is silica (silicosis) gives a grey coloration.</p>
<p>Particles are ingested by pulmonary macrophages get deposited in lung tissue and drained to regional lymph nodes.</p>
<p>Sequelae: fibrosis (Pneumoconiosis) i.e. dusts induced fibrotic diseases of the lung.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ingestion">INGESTION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ingestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Metals like mercury, silver &amp; lead produce a blue line in gums</li>
<li>Carrot eating produces a yellowish or orange skin pigmentation (carotinaemia)</li>
</ul>
<p>INJECTION: In skin tattoo carbon particles are injected into the skin forming a special design.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-pathological-calcification-plate-4">5. PATHOLOGICAL CALCIFICATION (plate 4)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-pathological-calcification-plate-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: deposition of calcium in tissues other than bone &amp; teeth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types">TYPES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-dystrophic-calcification">A. Dystrophic calcification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-dystrophic-calcification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Ca deposition in dead or dying tissues in presence of normal serum Ca levels.</p>
<ol>
<li>Deposition in dead fetus.</li>
<li>Old mesenchymal tumors.</li>
<li>Products of inflammation &amp; necrosis e.g. TB</li>
<li>Old thrombus.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-metastatic-calcification">B. Metastatic calcification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-metastatic-calcification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition Deposition in living tissues in_cases of high levels of serum <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ca</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ca</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>deposits in interstitial tissue, i.e. connective tissue &amp;lungs, kidney, stomach &amp; wall of arteries.</p>
