<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gross-chalky-white-granular-material-br">Gross: chalky white granular material (BR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-chalky-white-granular-material-br" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Microscopic: Blue deposits: intracellular in dead mitochondria or extracellular in connective tissue (collagen fibers).</p>
<p>PLATE 4 accumulations &amp; depositions from WebPath
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-07266086.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg"></p>

<p>Dystrophic calcification in artery &amp; stomach submucosa</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: center;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Basic reactions</td><td style="text-align: center;">All basic reactions</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Cell response to injury &lt;br&gt; Accumulations &amp;depositions All basic reactions.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Causes &amp; effects of cell injury &lt;br&gt; Mechanisms &lt;br&gt; Hydropic &amp; vacuolar &lt;br&gt; Fatty Change &lt;br&gt; Hyalinosis &lt;br&gt; Amyloidosis &lt;br&gt; Mucoid &amp;myxomatous change &lt;br&gt; Pigmentations &lt;br&gt; Pathological calcification &lt;br&gt; Necrosis &amp; apoptosis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inflammation">INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: It is a reaction of living tissue to injury. The reaction consists of a local tissue reaction (vascular &amp;cellular) in addition to a systemic response. Such a reaction is important to kill &amp; remove the injurious agent, making way for repair.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aetiology-types-pathogenesis">AETIOLOGY, TYPES, PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology-types-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-62b097f0.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-inflamation">Types of inflamation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-inflamation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;"></th><th style="text-align: center;">Acute</th><th style="text-align: center;">Subacute</th><th style="text-align: center;">Chronic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Onset</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rapid</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Gradual</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Duration</td><td style="text-align: center;">Short (days)</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Prolonged (3 mths/ more</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-inflammation-plate-5">ACUTE INFLAMMATION (plate 5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-inflammation-plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: It is the first reaction to injury of living tissue, which is characterized by a rapid onset ( less than 48 hrs ) &amp;short duration. The reaction consists of a local tissue reaction (vascular &amp; cellular) in addition to a systemic response. Such a reaction is important to kill &amp; remove the injurious agent, making way for repair.</p>
<p>1 In diagnosis of inflammation should include: Type (Acute/Chronic) + Organ/ tissue+ itis e.g. Acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis (see terminology at end of chapter)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathogenesis">PATHOGENESIS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A- LOCAL REACTION (VASCULAR &amp; CELLULAR RESPONSE)</p>
<ol>
<li>Hyperemia: Increased blood flow. This proceeds in 3 steps:</li>
<li>Temporary vasoconstriction (direct injury) followed by capillary dilatation (chemical mediators).</li>
<li>Arteriolar dilation: 2ry to nerve reflex (direct stimulus).</li>
<li>Wheal formation as a result of exudation of fluid.</li>
</ol>
<p>This is compatible with Lewis's triple response: injurious stroke <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> transient white line (vasoconstriction), followed by dull red line or flush (capillary dilatation) 2-flare or bright red zone around the line (arteriolar dilatation), 3-wheal Injury to normal tissue results in: a) direct vascular injury b) axon (nerve) reflexes acting on arterioles &amp; c) toxic, chemical mediator release from damaged cells. All 3 actions, produce vascular dilatation with increase in blood flow ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text {st }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> step of acute inflammation).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-redness-hotness">Clinical: redness &amp; hotness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-redness-hotness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>Formation of fluid exudate i.e. Exudation: leakage of fluid exudate results in swelling of area.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">Mechanism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Transudation: very early, since there is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> in hydrostatic pressure due to vasodilatation only produces fluid plasma, poor in protein &amp; large molecules (no cells) &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> specific gravity.
b) Exudation: occurs after <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> permeability allowing fluid + large protein molecules (fibrinogen &amp; immunoglobulins i.e. antibodies) with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Sp.gr. to come out. Later, this is followed by cellular exudate, which increases the swelling.</p>
<p>Chemical mediators cause endothelial swelling &amp; contraction (increasing gaps), direct injury to endothelium &amp; leukocyte dependent injury produces gaps which result in increased vascular permeability.</p>
<p>Factors helping the exudation process:</p>
<ul>
<li>Increased Capillary hydrostatic pressure</li>
<li>Chemical mediator effect on wall ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> permeability)</li>
<li>Increased tissue osmotic pressure OP (from cell breakdown) which pulls fluid out from vessels.</li>
</ul>
<p>Importance of exudates. (see later)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-swelling-or-wheal">Clinical: swelling or wheal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-swelling-or-wheal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate">Fate:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Lymph flow &amp; venous drainage of exudate with return of area to normal (resolution)</li>
<li>Spread of organisms in fluid exudate to lymphatics produces lymphangitis &amp; to blood stream causing thrombophlebitis which is responsible for: toxemia (toxin in circulation), pyaemia (pus in circulation), bacteremia (few bacteria in circulation) or septicemia (bacteria multiplying in pus &amp; producing toxins in the circulation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-formation-of-cellular-exudate">3. Formation of cellular exudate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-formation-of-cellular-exudate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>With exudation of fluid blood becomes more viscous &amp; the flow slows (congestion or stasis). Axial stream &amp; plasmatic zones are disturbed. Cells are thrown outwardsv&amp; line up against the endothelial wall, which is known as margination (pavementation). These cells carry surface adhesion molecules (integrins, selectins &amp; immunoglobulins) to help them stick to the endothelium &amp; so they do not get washed away by blood stream.</li>
<li>Emigration: polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PNLs) &amp; blood monocytes leave blood vessels to go to site of injury resulting in more swelling (importance, see later). Chemical mediators cause swelling of endothelium increasing gaps between cells. The PNLs find openings through which they send pseudopodia &amp; emigrate outwards, pulling with them some RBCs by diapedesis.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chemotaxis: Is the directed movement of PNLs (later macrophages) to site of injury under the effect of chemotactic chemical mediators e.g. C5a</p>
<ul>
<li>Diapedesis: Is the passive escape of red blood cells (RBCs) through the endothelial gaps widened by the migration of neutrophils</li>
<li>Phagocytosis: Process by which PNLs (microphages)&amp; macrophages (blood monocytes &amp; tissue histiocytes) engulf injurious agent. Destruction of agent by two mechanisms 02 dependent with H20 2 ! free radicle formation or 02 independent as lysosomal enzyme release.
a) Recognition + attachment: cells carry surface receptors for opsonins (antibodies) which attach to antigen &amp; complement. This facilitates the engulfment of the antigen and prevents its escape from the phagocytic cell by ensuring its proper attachment
b) Engulfment: pseudopodia form around antigen-antibody &amp; complement attached to receptor on cell surface.</li>
</ul>
<p>c) Degradation: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> &amp; lysosomal enzymes degrade the contents of the phagosome containing the antigen (after lysosomes fuse with the phagosome, forming a phagolysosome).
N.B.: Cell, may die (e.g. when neutrophil dies it becomes a pus cell) or live with bacteria inside it (e.g. macrophages containing TB bacilli). With exudation into tissue, the blood becomes more viscous with slowing of the flow (stasis). This process is called congestion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical">Clinical:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>More swelling (fluid + inflammatory cells)</li>
<li>Pain: from direct injury-swelling-chemical mediators released from necrotic cells</li>
<li>Loss of function resulting from pain &amp; loss of tissue (necrosis)</li>
</ul>
<p>CHEMICAL MEDIATORS: are vasoactive amines &amp; polypeptides, which are chemical factors released during tissue injury from necrotic cells and cells of acute inflammation. They also include plasma complement, bacterial toxins as well as others.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-cellular-factors">A. CELLULAR FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-cellular-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vasoactive amines (histamine and serotonin released from Mast cells &amp; platelets).</li>
<li>Cytokines: lymphokines (from activated lymphocytes &amp; cytokines from other cells) e.g. (IL-1, TNF, IL-8, IL-12)</li>
</ul>
<p>Fibrinolytic system which dissolves fibrin</p>
<ul>
<li>Arachidonic acid metabolites</li>
</ul>
<p>Prostaglandins (released from most cells)
Leukotrines (produced by neutrophils)</p>
<ul>
<li>Platelet activating factor (PAF)</li>
<li>Nitric oxide (vasodilator, cytotoxin)</li>
<li>Lysosomal constituents of leukocytes</li>
<li>Oxygen derived free radicals
B. PLASMA FACTORS</li>
<li>Plasma factors</li>
</ul>
<p>Kinin system eg bradykinin
Complement system especially C3a &amp; C5a
Coagulation system changes fibrinogen to fibrin</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="they-are-capable-of">They are capable of:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#they-are-capable-of" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Vasodilatation (hyperemia) e.g. prostaglandin E, nitric oxide &amp; prostacyclins</li>
<li>Increased permeability (exudation) e.g. C3a, C4a, C5a, bradykinin</li>
<li>Cell emigration, chemotaxis (C5a) &amp; phagocytosis (C3b acts as an opsonin)</li>
<li>Fever &amp; leukocytosis e.g. interleukin 1&amp; 6 , prostaglandins &amp; TNF alpha</li>
<li>Tissue damage (a leukocyte exudation): Neutrophil and macrophage lysosomal enzymes-Oxygen metabolites-Nitric oxide</li>
<li>Pain: -Prostaglandins&amp; Bradykinin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-microbial-killing-in-acute-inflammation">Steps of microbial killing in acute inflammation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-microbial-killing-in-acute-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>PNLs &amp; macrophages (phagoicytosis).</li>
<li>Immune response: non specific opsonization or specific humoral or cell mediated immunity.
(specific responses occur only on 2nd exposures, see immunopathology)
IMPORTANCE OF INFLAMMATORY REACTION: The inflammatory reaction comprises the formation of the fluid + cellular exudate. Increased vascularity &amp; increased vascular permeability are important in:</li>
<li>cellular exudate: bringing important cells as PNLs &amp; monocytes (in addition to CT histiocytes &amp; PNLs) for phagocytosis &amp; elimination of the injurious agent. These cells also remove necrotic debris &amp; the blood; provides the</li>
<li>fluid exudate which: a) contains fibrinogen, which changes to fibrin in tissue. This is important for</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>preventing spread of infection (by surrounding the site &amp; blocking the lymphatics).</li>
<li>It also forms a scaffold (area outline) which helps bring phagocytic cells to site &amp;</li>
<li>later, binds the tissues and helps repair (by allowing more fibroblasts into the area) brings antibodies &amp; any circulating antibiotic or important drugs to the area. Fluid exudate also dilutes toxins &amp; irritants as well as decreasing their effect.
N.B.:The inflammatory exudate is composed of
A. fluid exudate is rich in the protein fibrinogen. This changes into fibrin threads in tissue outside BV).
Fluid in tissue is called edema but if it collects in serous membranes of body cavities e.g. pleura, pericardium &amp; peritoneum, it is called effusion. (plate 5)
B. Cellular exudate: PNLs &amp; macrophages</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="local-basic-reaction-br-for-all-types-of-acute-inflammation">LOCAL BASIC REACTION (BR) for all types of acute inflammation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-basic-reaction-br-for-all-types-of-acute-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">Microscopic:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Damage (cell injury) in the form of necrosis around injurious agent
Reaction around necrotic area in the form of acute inflammation
1-Acute inflammatory cells from connective tissue &amp; inflammatory cellular exudate from the blood =PNLs &amp; macrophages (tissue histiocytes or blood monocytes)
2-Dilated hyperemic BV
3-Inflammatory fluid exudate: edema &amp; fibrin
Gross: Redness &amp; swelling</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-general-or-systemic-reaction">B- GENERAL OR SYSTEMIC REACTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-general-or-systemic-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Fever: from pyrogens released from injurious agent or chemical mediators e.g. prostaglandins. These act on temperature regulating centers in brain stem.</li>
<li>Blood changes</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Changes in white blood cells (leukocytosis i.e. Increased white blood cells in circulation).</li>
<li>Changes in plasma proteins:</li>
<li>High erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)</li>
<li>Increased acute phase reactant proteins as C-reactive protein &amp; Alpha 1antitrypsin.</li>
<li>Immunoglobulins &amp; T lymphocytes</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-acute-inflammation-sequelae-complications">FATE OF ACUTE INFLAMMATION (SEQUELAE + COMPLICATIONS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-acute-inflammation-sequelae-complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) HEALING: When body resistance takes upper hand over injury this will result in
a) Resolution: cure i.e. return to normal This occurs if there is minimal tissue damage, rapid removal of organism linjurious agent &amp; rapid removal of inflammatory exudate. e.g. lobar pneumonia.</p>
<p>Mechanism: after the bacteria are killed, the following occurs:</p>
<ol>
<li>Fibrin is lysed by PN Ls enzymes, fibrinolysin</li>
<li>Fluid exudate is removed by blood vessels (BV) &amp; lymphatics (LV)</li>
<li>Debris (dead fragments) are removed by PNLs &amp; macrophages &amp; drained to lymph nodes (LN)
4.Decreased hyperemia &amp; return to normal</li>
</ol>
<p>b) Regeneration or fibrosis: depends on extent &amp; type of tissue damage (see repair)
II) PROGRESSION: Body resistance &lt; injury <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Progression with more damage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo>−</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+/-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord">−</span></span></span></span></span> suppuration.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-20926299.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></p>
<p>COMPLICATIONS of acute inflammation</p>
<ol>
<li>Chronicity: Acute proceeds to chronic inflammation</li>
<li>Repair by organization with complications of healing by fibrosis (see repair). e.g. stenosis, adhesions</li>
<li>Spread (see above in progression &amp; chapter of infections): direct to surrounding organs &amp; distant by lymphatics or blood
III) CHRONICITY: When body resistance is of equal strength to injury, the lesion becomes chronic with tissue damage + repair (an ongoing processes of destruction &amp; healing) e.g. granulomas (TB) Complications: of repair by fibrosis &amp; chronicity (ulcer-sin us- fistulae, amyloidosis, neoplastic change, and see later).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-acute-inflammation-plate-5">TYPES OF ACUTE INFLAMMATION (plate 5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-acute-inflammation-plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-suppurative-inflammation">A. Suppurative Inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-suppurative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Localized acute inflammation e.g. acute abscess: localized area of suppuration.</li>
<li>Diffuse acute inflammation e.g. cellulitis: diffuse suppuration e.g. cellulitis of limbs &amp; acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-others-non-suppurative">B. Others (Non-Suppurative)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-others-non-suppurative" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Catarrhal inflammation: occurs in mucous membranes e.g. common cold</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exudative inflammations: serous: e.g. burns, serofibrinous e.g. serous membrane as pleurisy or fibrinous e.g. lobar pneumonia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pseudomembranous occurs on mucous membranes with a dirty grayish false membrane forming on surface e.g. bacillary dysentery &amp; diphtheria</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Haemorrhagic: Inflammatory basic reaction + many RBCs e.g. small pox &amp; acute haemorrhagic pneumonia of influenza</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Necrotizing: Inflammatory basic reaction + much necrosis e.g. necrotizing vasculitis &amp; cancrum oris (if it is complicated by putrefaction it is called gangrene)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Allergic inflammation e.g .. Hypersensitivity e.g. hay fever, bronchial asthma. This reaction IS CHARACTERIZED BY acute inflammatory basic reaction but there is a predominance of eosinophils (cells of allergy) or mononuclear cells e.g. typhoid &amp; much swelling due to edema e.g. urticaria weals, nasal polyps (see later immunopath). This inflammation is the result of an antigen antibody reaction (hypersensitivity) with resultant inflammation due to tissue injury.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-acute-suppurative-inflammation">A. ACUTE SUPPURATIVE INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-acute-suppurative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Is an acute inflammation characterized by pus formation
PUS: is liquefied necrotic tissue secondary mostly to the pyogenic organism injury.
N.B.: pus never contains fibrin since it is liquefied by enzymes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology-characters-of-pus">MORPHOLOGY (Characters of pus)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-characters-of-pus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Gross</th><th style="text-align: left;">Microscopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Yellowish, turbid, opaque</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Fluid exudate + high protein &lt;br&gt; (without fibrin)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Odorless, alkaline fluid</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Cellular exudate large numbers PNL &lt;br&gt; of Which many die and become pus &lt;br&gt; cells</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">- Bacteria, with its pigments &amp; toxins &lt;br&gt; - RBCs &lt;br&gt; - Necrotic host tissue (see BRnecrosis)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS (mechanism of pus formation)
Pyogenic bacteria by direct &amp; toxic effect produce:
a) Marked necrosis &amp;
b) Attraction of large numbers of neutrophils &amp; death of many them from the high virulence of the organism this forms more pus cells. Release of PNL enzymes causes liquefaction of necrotic tissue &amp; fibrin (No fibrin in pus).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-localized-suppurative-inflammation">1. LOCALIZED SUPPURATIVE INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-localized-suppurative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abscess">ABSCESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abscess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION an abscess is a localized collection of pus commonly caused by pyogenic (pus forming) organisms e.g. Staph aureus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="etiology-pathogenesis">ETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Pyogenic Bacteria by direct &amp; toxic effects produce pus (see above mechanism).</li>
<li>Staph aureus releases coagulase enzyme, which changes fibrinogen protein into fibrin threads, thereby localizing the area and walling it off from spread of infection (WALL).
N.B.: There are particular forms of abscesses e.g. furuncle (boil)-carbuncle.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross">GROSS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1 Small: yellow swollen area surrounded by a zone of redness (congestion).
4 Large: cavity with irregular wall, rough lining &amp; yellow in color. Its contents are liquid pus (describe BR above). The cavity is surrounded by a zone of congestion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Early: 2 zones: central zone of necrosis &amp; peripheral zone of acute inflammation
Later: 3 zones</p>
<ol>
<li>Central zone of pus (see BR of characters of pus, above for description).</li>
<li>Pyogenic membrane: new capillaries, PNLs, macrophages, pus cells, fibrin &amp; few fibroblasts (acute inflammation).</li>
<li>Outer zone of reversible damage or degeneration.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-an-abscess">FATE of an abscess<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-an-abscess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If the abscess is small &amp; superficial, it causes thinning of surface cover (pointing), followed by rupture &amp; discharge of pus producing an ulcer. But If, abscess is small &amp; deep. its contents become absorbed &amp; it heals by fibrosis, leaving a scar.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If large &amp; superficial, it produces an ulcer, which is an area devoid of its surface epithelium, this heals by organization &amp; fibrosis. If large &amp; deep, its contents become thick i.e. inspissiated +/- dystrophic calcification and the wall becomes fibrotic(see repair, healing by secondary intention &amp; chronic abscess)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deep abscesses tend to track their pus to the surface to evacuate or into another hollow organ producing fibrous tracts called sinus tracts or fistulae(see repair complications)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Excessive damage
a) Spread of infection</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Direct (local)
Systemic (blood ego toxemia, septicemia etc.. )
b) Putrefaction on top of the necrosis resulting in gangrene</p>
<ul>
<li>Persistence of injurious agent produces a chronic abscess &amp; complications.</li>
<li>Hemorrhage with complications of anemia or shock, if bleeding is severe.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="boil-furuncle">BOIL (Furuncle):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#boil-furuncle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Staph aureus infection produces a small abscess related to hair follicle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbuncle">CARBUNCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbuncle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Multiple deep subcutaneous abscesses communicating with each other &amp; forming one cavity but open on the surface by separate openings. It occurs in special sites e.g. back of neck, scalp &amp; buttocks where subcutaneous fat is divided by fibrous septae perpendicular to surface. It is common in diabetics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-acute-diffuse-suppurative-inflammation">2. ACUTE DIFFUSE SUPPURATIVE INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-acute-diffuse-suppurative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Diffuse pus &amp; inflammation with no localization e. g.: cellulitis of arm &amp; Acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis.</p>
<p>CAUSE: Streptococcus hemolyticus
MECHANISM
Streptococci secrete streptokinase (fibrinolysin), an enzyme, which dissolves fibrin &amp; hyaluronidase enzymes, which liquefies the extracellular matrix, helping the spread of the organism and spread of pus. This is common in loose connective tissue.</p>
<p>Strept. hemolyticus produces thin sanguinous( bloody) pus &amp; large necrotic areas of tissue (sloughs) All layers of tissue are affected by the diffuse suppurative inflammation (grossly &amp; microscopically).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-diffuse-suppurative-appendicitis">Acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-diffuse-suppurative-appendicitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gross: Appendix swollen- yellow (pus) with reddish areas of hemorrhage &amp; congestion Surface rough yellowish (septic peritonitis) Cut section shows necrotic, rough, yellow mucosal lining. Lumen contains pus Wall thick, yellow (pus) with areas of reddish (congestion)</p>
<p>Microscopic: Mucosal layer ulcerated with pus in lumen (describe pus) Acute inflammation &amp; pus in all layers of wall reaching serosa (describe acute inflammation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{BR}+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">BR</span></span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span> pus cells).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-acute-non-suppurative-inflammation-plate-5">B. ACUTE NON-SUPPURATIVE INFLAMMATION (plate 5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-acute-non-suppurative-inflammation-plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>CATARRHAL INFLAMMATION e.g. rhinitis (common cold)</li>
</ol>
<p>DEF: Acute non-suppurative inflammation of mucous membranes (respiratory, GIT)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology">MORPHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>GROSS
Swollen mucosa (edema)
Redness (congestion)
Increased Mucus discharge
CP: blocked runny nose</p>
<p>MICROSCOPIC
Swollen columnar cell with mucin (mucoid change)
Acute Inflammation in mucosal connective tissue (BR)
Increased mucus on epithelial cell surface</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-exudative-inflammation">2) EXUDATIVE INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-exudative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Occurs in body cavities and on skin surfaces
N.B.: lung alveoli may be considered as microscopic body cavities</p>
<ol>
<li>Serous inflammation: Acute inflammation characterized by more fluid than fibrin e.g
A. Surfaces: e.g. burn bleb (on skin)- Herpes simplex vesicle (on mucosa/skin). Burn bleb on surface of skin: epidermis is raised and full of inflammatory fluid exudate. Dermal CT contains acute inflammatory reaction (acute inflammatory cells congested BV + edema + minimal amounts of fibrin (BR)
B. Lining of cavities (pericardium, pleura, peritoneum, joints &amp; meninges) e.g. effusions.</li>
<li>Fibrinous Inflammation e.g. lobar pneumonia &amp; rheumatic pericarditis more fibrin than fluid
e.g. lobar pneumonia &amp; rheumatic pericarditis</li>
<li>Serofibrinous inflammation: fibrin = fluid e.g. effusions (pleural &amp; pericardial effusion &amp; ascitis in peritoneum).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="br-of-exudative-inflammation">BR of exudative inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#br-of-exudative-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Microscopic:
a- fluid in a cavity (amount depends on type of inflammation)
b- acute inflammation (BR) in submesothelial CT
c- fibrin forms a network on surface of visceral and parietal layers, entangling acute inflammatory cells (amount depends on type of inflammation i.e. fibrinous or serofibrinous).</p>
<p>Gross: thick opaque rough serous membrane. The roughness is caused by the cotton-like yellowish white fibrin on surface, (BR).</p>
<p>Fate of exudative inflammation:
Serous <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> resolution: return to normal after fluid is totally absorbed
Serofibrinous <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> organization by fibrosis (adhesions) except in lobar pneumonia Fibrinous <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> total resolution occurs.
3) HEMORRHAGIC: Inflammation basic reaction + many RBCs e.g. small pox &amp; acute hemorrhagic pneumonia of influenza &amp; hemorrhagic tracheitis. Virus damages BV severely with loss of many RBCs.
4) NECROTIZING: Inflammatory basic reaction (BR) + extensive necrosis e.g. necrotizing tracheitis &amp; if necrosis is associated with putrefaction it is called gangrene.
5) PSEUDOMEMBRANOUS Severe acute inflammation caused by exotoxins of bacteria (Shigella or Diphtheria). This causes inflammation of mucosa &amp; submucosa. The denuded surface mucosa is covered by fibrin derived from submucosa. This network entangles the organisms, toxins, acute inflammatory cells (PNLs, macrophages), necrotic columnar cells and some RBCs forming a pseudomembrane. The underlying tissue shows the basic reaction of acute inflammation. Grossly, the pseudomembrane is characterized by its rough dirty greyish yellow color and its adherence (since, when pulled it leaves a raw bleeding surface).</p>
<p>Bacillary dysentery is due to Shigella infection, like diphtheria, it is another pseudomembranous type of inflammation where the organism cannot penetrate the tissue but sends its toxins to the submucosal blood vessels and produces the same picture as diphtheria. Complications: Toxins (toxemia) produce shock + systemic organ degeneration &amp; necrosis as well as local acute inflammation</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>ALLERGIC e.g. urticaria &amp; nasal polyp characterized byt edema, eosinophils, plasma cells or lymphocytes (see Immunopathology)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-inflammation-plate-5">CHRONIC INFLAMMATION (plate 5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-inflammation-plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Reaction of living tissues to injury, which has a gradual onset (more than 48 hrs ) &amp; prolonged duration. The cell injury goes hand in hand with the repair process.
N.B.: In chronic inflammation, cellular exudate is more than the fluid component. The fluid is minimal as the vessels are very thick walled &amp; have narrow lumen (endarteritis obliterans).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-reaction-br">Basic reaction (BR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-reaction-br" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Systemic</th><th style="text-align: center;">Local reaction</th><th style="text-align: center;"></th><th style="text-align: center;"></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Fever</td><td style="text-align: center;">Tissue destruction + Chronic inflam</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Repair(FT)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Malaise</td><td style="text-align: center;">necrosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lymphocytes</td><td style="text-align: center;">fibrous tissue:</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Blood changes</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">plasma cells</td><td style="text-align: center;">fibroblasts collagen</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Lymphocytosis</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">macrophages</td><td style="text-align: center;">+ BV (endarteritis</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Plasma cells <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">+/- giant cells</td><td style="text-align: center;">obliterans)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Monocytosis</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aetiology">AETIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Following acute inflammation(secondary): same injurious agents (see acute inflammation) which if not removed continue to cause damage e.g. chronic abscess</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-starts-as-chronic-from-the-start-primary">2. Starts as chronic from the start (primary)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-starts-as-chronic-from-the-start-primary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) if organism has low toxicity e.g. TB or
b) long exposure to non-degradable material as silica or hemosiderin
c) autoimmunity (body reacts against its own tissues) e.g. rheumatoid arthritis (see later, immunopathology)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenesis">PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cell injury of a continuous, persistent nature, produces necrosis of tissue associated with healing by fibrosis at the same time, since the process occurs over a prolonged period. Necrosis results in release of chemical mediators and uncovering of cellular antigens (antigens hidden in cytoplasm), these excite a chronic cell population (see above), narrow thick walled BV (endarteritis obliterans &amp; endophlebitis) also granulation tissue &amp; fibrous tissue of repair.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types">TYPES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Non-specific (mostly after acute 2-Specific (chronic from the start) inflammation).</p>
<ul>
<li>Suppurative (chronic abscess)</li>
<li>granuloma</li>
<li>Non-suppurative (chronic ulcer)</li>
<li>diffuse (rare)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-non-specific">1) Non-specific<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-non-specific" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) Chronic abscess</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Gross</th><th style="text-align: left;">Microscopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Well defined round cavity</td><td style="text-align: left;">Central pus (see acute inflammation)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Wall is regular, smooth &amp;white cells,</td><td style="text-align: left;">surrounded by chronic inflammatory</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cavity contains thick pus</td><td style="text-align: left;">Endarteritis obliterans &amp; FT</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Lining smooth as it is formed of fibrous &lt;br&gt; tissue</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>II) Chronic ulcer (see repair)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-specific-granuloma-plate-5">2) Specific (Granuloma) (plate 5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-specific-granuloma-plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Localized collection of chronic inflammatory cells forming granules, nodules or a tumor-like mass. Such lesions have a predominance of macrophages &amp; have diagnostic microscopic picture i.e. specific features indicative of type of injurious agent. The macrophages may be modified &amp; have a pink ill-defined cytoplasm (hence called epithelioid cells) &amp; some types of granulomas have central necrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-granuloma">TYPES OF GRANULOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-granuloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Infectious: bacterial(TB &amp; leprosy) - parasitic(bilharziasis) - fungal (histoplasma).</li>
<li>Foreign body type: e.g. reaction to surgical sutures, wood splinters, glass or sand.</li>
<li>Inorganic: reaction to inorganic material as silica &amp; asbestosis.</li>
<li>Granulomas of unknown etiology e.g. sarcoidosis &amp; Chron's disease.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="basic-reaction-br-of-granuloma">Basic reaction (BR) of GRANULOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-reaction-br-of-granuloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>GROSS: whitish firm tumor-like mass
MICROSCOPIC: e.g. TB tubercle which consists of:</p>
<ol>
<li>Central zone of necrosis (caseation).</li>
<li>Many macrophages of the epithelioid type in TB, surround the necrotic center.
N.B.: epithelioid cells are formed if the injurious agent persists &amp; is not destroyed within the macrophage, thereby changing its appearance to an epithelial like cell with abundant, foamy pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with unclear cell outlines. The nucleus is oval and pale. This cell is an activated macrophage with the ability to produce lysozyme as well as other enzymes but have poor phagocytic abilities.</li>
<li>Lymphocytes, few plasma cells</li>
<li>Giant cells: Large cells with many nuclei, they may be produced due to the fusion of several macrophages or the division of the nucleus of a macrophage repeatedly without the division of the cytoplasm. In TB they are called Langhan's giant cells with peripherally placed horse shoe like nuclei. In other granulomas as foreign body granulomas they are large cells with centrally placed multiple nuclei &amp; are called foreign body giant cells.
5)Zone of capillaries, fibroblasts &amp; chronic inflam cells i.e. granulation tissue.</li>
<li>Outer zone of fibroblasts + collagen fibers + endarteritis obliterans. (fibrous tissue)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-complications-of-chronic-inflammation">FATE &amp; COMPLICATIONS OF CHRONIC INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-complications-of-chronic-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Small area or treated lesion, undergoes fibrosis and with or without dystrophic calcification ending in scar tissue (see complications of scar repair) producing stenosis, obstruction, pressure atrophy on adjacent organs, dilatation or rupture</li>
<li>Complications of chronicity (chronic tissue destruction):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hemorrhage, organ failure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chronic ulcer with repeated attacks of secondary infection. Such ulcers in certain areas may undergo MALIGNANT transformation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sinus: a sinus is a tract opened at one end (blind ended tract), lined by granulation tissue or FT resulting from opening of a chronically inflamed deep abscess cavity onto a surface. It is caused by the persistence of pus or the presence of a foreign body e.g. a) sinus of osteomyelitis: a suppurative inflammatory disease of bone &amp; b) pilonidal sinus: a nest of hairs which have penetrated deeply under the skin of the midline of sacrum and are associated with chronic inflammation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fistula: is a track open at both ends, through which abnormal communication occurs i.e. 2 cavities or a body cavity &amp; surface.(a tract between 2 surfaces)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plate-5">PLATE 5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f9ec7458.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<p>Serofibrinous pericarditis
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f73c186d.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
<p>Pseudomembranous inflammation. Larynx
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-3359de60.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg"></p>
<p>Pleural effusion (webPath)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-278ae174.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg"></p>
<p>Acute inflammation larynx(WebPath)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-4b6d897d.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<p>Chronic inflammation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-b3af2990.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg"></p>
<p>Granuloma (webPath)</p>
<p>a) congenital fistula: due to developmental abnormality
b) acquired due to trauma (e.g. postoperative biliary fistula), inflammation (gastrocolic fistula) or necrosis especially due to tumor (e.g. vesico-vaginal fistula following radionecrosis in treatment of cancer cervix).</p>
<ul>
<li>Systemic amyloidosis (AA): chronic tissue destruction resulting in abnormal fibrillary protein (8 pleated protein fibrils) + non fibrillary serum ptn. (SAP, circulating in blood) with CHO heparan sulphate.</li>
<li>Malignant transformation (rare) e.g. Marjolin ulcer</li>
<li>Distant spread of infection: by lymphatics &amp; may result in generalized lymphadenopathy. Spread may also occur by blood stream (bacteremia, pyaemia, toxemia or septicemia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-complications-of-healing-by-fibrosis-see-repair">3. Complications of healing by fibrosis (see repair)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-complications-of-healing-by-fibrosis-see-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminology-in-inflammation">TERMINOLOGY IN INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminology-in-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rule: latin name of organ + itis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> inflammation of this organ. There are some exceptions to this rule e.g. pneumonia and pleurisy.</p>

style="text-align: center;">Male genital tract</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Testis - orchitis Epididymis = epididymitis</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Glans penis &amp; prepuce <span class="math math-inline"><span <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
