<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="healing-repair">HEALING &amp; REPAIR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#healing-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="healing-repair">Healing &amp; repair<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#healing-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Healing &amp; repair follow most forms of cell injury.
Tissue destruction &amp; inflammatory reactions are followed by healing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="healing-occurs-by">HEALING OCCURS BY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#healing-occurs-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-resolution">1. RESOLUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Return of tissue to normal Occurs with.
a- minimal damage
b- rapid removal of injurious agent &amp; products of inflammation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="or">or<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#or" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-repair">2. REPAIR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Replacement of damaged tissue by a new &amp; healthy one This may be:</p>
<p>REGENERATION ORGANIZATION</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Regeneration</th><th style="text-align: center;">Organization</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Replacement by same cell type Only with minimal damage i.e. only cells.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Replacement by fibrous I glial tissue Occurs with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> damage (cells + Connective tissue-CT frame).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Cell types affected: &lt;br&gt; 1- Labile cells e.g. epithelial cells, haemopoetic &amp; lymphopoetic cells These cells divide regularly during life. &lt;br&gt; 2- Stable cells: e.g., epithelium of glands, connective tissue cells &amp; peripheral nerves These cells only divide if damaged.</td><td style="text-align: center;">1- Labile &amp; stable if extensive damage to cells &amp; framework has occurred. &lt;br&gt; 2- Permanent cells e.g. striated muscle fibers (cardiac&amp;skeletal) &amp; CNS neurons.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cell-cycle-and-types-of-cells">Cell cycle and types of cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-cycle-and-types-of-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The four main stages of the cell cycle are:
M phase: mitosis when the cell divides (about 1 hour)
Gl phase: gap 1, the preparation for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> phase
S phase: DNA synthesis
G2 phase: gap 2 during which assembly of the apparatus for the distribution of chromosomes occurs.</p>
<p>Go phase: This phase is non-proliferative and is known as growth arrest. Cells in Go may re-enter the cell cycle at G1, thereby regaining the proliferative state. Locally</p>
<p>active small-molecular-weight proteins called growth factors are important in stimulating this re-entry.</p>
<p>Cells can undergo terminal differentiation, in which case they cannot re-enter the cell cycle (non dividing cells). In a permanent cell population, all the cells are terminally differentiated.</p>
<p>Premeiotic phase
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-f486e725.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-cell-cycle">Control of the cell cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-cell-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a) Growth factors.</p>
<p>These are low-molecular-weight proteins which have a similar mechanism of action to hormones. In general, the growth factor is produced by a cell, for example a macrophage, and acts either on the cell itself (autocrine action) or on a neighbouring cell (paracrine action) by linking to cell surface receptors. This interaction activates the receptor and triggers a series of cytoplasmic events usually involving phosphorylatinn-dephosphorylation of proteins.</p>
<p>Ultimately, a signal reaches the nucleus where genes are switched on, new proteins produced and cell growth and division is initiated. Growth factors are thought to be particularly important in stimulating stable, non-proliferating (GO) cells to enter the cell cycle at G1 and undergo mitosis.
b) Cyclins</p>
<p>The cyclins are a family of proteins which seem to coordinate the journey of cells through the different phases of the cell cycle. They form complexes with a protein kinase (phosphorylating) enzyme. The cellular concentration and activity of different cyclins varies through the cycle.</p>
<p>FACTORS RESPONSIBLE FOR REPAIR (stimulatory - inhibitory</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">1. Stimulatory factors</th><th style="text-align: left;">2. Inhibitory factors</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Growth factors (GF)</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Growth factors -GF</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Extracellular matrix proteins (ECM)</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Others:</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased glucocorticoids, interferes with PNLs &amp; macrophages, thereby increasing the patient's susceptibility to infection.</li>
<li>Diabetes mellitus causes bad circulation &amp; high risk of infection.
A. Stimulatory factors:</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Growth factors (GF)
Macrophage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> GF act on resting cell (Go into mitotic phase) ending in mitosis Platelets <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Presynthetic phase</p>
<p>Epithelial cell injury causes Cytokine release
Types of GF</p>
<ul>
<li>EGF =epidermal growth factor</li>
<li>PDGF=platelet derived GF</li>
<li>FGF = fibroblast GF</li>
<li>PDGF &amp; FGF act on fibroblasts,smooth muscle of BV wall &amp; endothelial cells</li>
<li>TGFa =transforming GF acts on fibroblast chemotaxis</li>
<li>IL-1 = interleukin -1 (cytokine) with stimulation of collagen synthesis</li>
<li>TNF = tumor necrosis factor acts on fibroblast chemotaxis &amp; stimulation of collagen synthesis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-extracellular-matrix-proteins-ecm-glycoproteins">2- Extracellular matrix proteins (ECM glycoproteins)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-extracellular-matrix-proteins-ecm-glycoproteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>FN = fibronectin stimulates: migration, proliferation, differentiation,&amp; adhesion of the fibroblast</li>
<li>Laminin (same as FN)</li>
</ul>
<p>Cell matrix interaction (ECM)
The extra cellular matrix is formed of interstitial matrix (glycoproteins embedded in a gel of proteoglycans and fibrous proteins (collagens and elastin). The matrix is organized as a basement membrane around epithelial, endothelial and smooth muscle cells as well as in the supportive tissues. This provides a substrate where cells can adhere, migrate and proliferate. ECM with growth factors regulate cell growth, movement and differentiation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-inhibitory-factors">B. Inhibitory factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-inhibitory-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>TGF <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> : stimulates collagen degradation.</li>
<li>TGF <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> : inhibits cell growth.</li>
</ul>
<p>Mechanism of cell-cell interaction: When cells are injured, healthy nearby cells proliferate to fill the gap. When these are exposed to each other, they stimulate the inhibitory receptors, which are carried on the surface of cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regeneration">REGENERATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regeneration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Replacement of damaged cells by the same cell type
AETIOLOGY: Any injurious agent (see cell injury) causing damage + acute inflammation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">MECHANISM:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Labile cells: these are cells which proliferate continuously during life</p>
<ul>
<li>Epithelial: surface cells e.g. skin abrasion &amp; superficial skin ulcer lining cells e.g. mucous membrane (catarrhal infl.) &amp; serous membranes (serous &amp; serofibrinous inflam.)</li>
<li>Haemopoietic(bone marrow) cells &amp; lymphopoietic(lymphoid) cells of lymph nodes, spleen &amp; thymus
B. Stable cells: These are cells which proliferate only if stimulated i.e. injured</li>
<li>Epithelial cells of parenchymatous organs i.e. cells with specialized function: e.g.liverpancreas - kidney (so long as the connective tissue framework is intact)e.g., acute hepatitis heals by regeneration &amp; similarly after partial hepatectomy.</li>
<li>Connective tissue (CT): fibrous tissue (FT)-bone - cartilage &amp; smooth muscle fibers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Dead cells at the site of damage are absorbed through the lymphatics and blood vessels &amp; healthy cells, surrounding the area of injury, proliferate to fill the gap.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="organization-or-healing-by-fibrosis">ORGANIZATION OR HEALING BY FIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organization-or-healing-by-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION :Replacement of damaged cells /tissue by a stronger different tissue type (fibrous tissue or glial tissue in CNS healing)</p>
<p>MECHANISMS: This type of healing depends on:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-cell-type">A. Cell type:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-cell-type" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Labile or stable but with extensive damage to cells + framework e.g.:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Liver cirrhosis: hepatocytes have limited regeneration in the presence of diffuse destruction; therefore heal by regeneration &amp; fibrosis</li>
<li>Wound healing by 1ry &amp; 2ry intention</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Permanent: cells, which are unable to divide as striated muscle fibers (cardiac &amp; skeletal) and CNS neurons e.g.:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac muscle e.g. myocardial infarction heals by myocardial scarring</li>
<li>CNS e.g. cerebral infarction heals by gliosis
B. Presence of structureless material e.g. products of inflammation- thrombus inside a BV
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑↑</span></span></span></span></span> Inflammatory exudate rich in cells, fibrin and fluid
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Organization
Large thrombus inside lumen of BV
Organization BY Fibrosis is the end result of wound healing &amp; chronic inflammation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-ft-formation-stages-of-scar-formation">Steps of FT formation (Stages of scar formation)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-ft-formation-stages-of-scar-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Platelets, macrophages &amp; injured epithelial cells result in the release of peptide growth factors &amp; cytokines (chemical mediators), producing:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-143f6e19.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Migration of fibroblasts &amp; myofibroblasts + new capillaries (angiogenesis) = granulation tissue (GT).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proliferation of fibroblasts &amp; myofibroblasts which synthesize collagen fibers (first type III then type I) in addition to proliferated BV forming fibrous tissue (FT).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Fibrocytes &amp; primitive cells in CT &amp; around capillaries are stimulated to enlarge and become active fibroblasts. These are responsible for:
a) Protein synthesis (proline &amp; hydroxyproline).
b) Secretion of ground substance {extracellular matrix (ECM)} adhesive glycoprotein, FN which provides a framework for the tissue defect &amp; contributes to repair.
c) Secretion of procollagen (very fine fibrils seen only by EM). Procollagen condenses to form collagen III, further condensation to collagen I occurs.
3. Fibroblasts decrease whilst collagen I increases and is acted upon by a remodeling enzyme in addition to bonding of fibers resulting in high tensile mature tissue over a long period of time. This causes pressure on the BV shutting them down producing avascular fibrous tissue or SCAR.
4. Old scars undergo hyalinosis or dystrophic calcification.</p>
<p>Best example of a scar is myocardial scarring or healed myocardial infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Angiogenesis: formation of new capillary vessels. Basement membrane (BM) of vessel is digested by proteolytic enzymes &amp; endothelial cells proliferate under the GF effect producing solid buds of endothelial cells, which grow out of the basement membrane gap. With maturation, a tube is formed and collagen type IV deposits reforming BM &amp; a new blood vessel (BV) is formed.</li>
<li>Myofibroblast: is a cell with both fibroblastic &amp; muscle contraction abilities leading to wound contraction with decrease in wound size in addition to collagen synthesis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-influencing-healing-by-fibrosis">FACTORS INFLUENCING HEALING BY FIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-influencing-healing-by-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-local">1. Local<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-local" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Infection.</li>
<li>Poor blood supply.</li>
<li>Excessive movement (interferes with GT).</li>
<li>Presence of foreign body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-general">2. General<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-general" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Vitamin C deficiency.</li>
<li>Deficiency of zinc &amp; amino acids (in malnutrition).</li>
<li>Adrenal glucocorticoids.</li>
<li>Debilitating (disabling) chronic disorders.</li>
</ul>
<p>The general causes are responsible for failure of proper collagen synthesis, with delayed healing and weak easily ruptured scars.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="healing-special-situations">HEALING - SPECIAL SITUATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#healing-special-situations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-repair-by-regeneration">A. REPAIR BY REGENERATION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-repair-by-regeneration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) Skin: healing of a superficial ulcer (abrasion)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>ABRASION: Is a superficial ulceration or absence of the epidermis; it heals by regeneration.</li>
<li>ULCER': is a defect in the surface covering as well as underlying tissue as a result of necrosis and it is covered by inflammatory products.</li>
</ul>
<p>Healing of a superficial simple ulcer on skin or mucous membranes is by regeneration whereas deep ulcers will heal by fibrosis i.e. organization.</p>
<p>Mechanism: cells of the surface epithelium which have been lost as a result of necrosis, will be replaced by active mitosis in the cells at the healthy edge of the ulcer. The proliferating cells creep over the floor of the ulcer, which is composed of fibrin and debris. These are actively removed by the acute inflammation in the base. The result is a completely normal area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If the irritant persists this ulcer proceeds into chronicity i.e. chronic ulcer. The base will contain chronic inflammatory cells &amp; FT, resulting in a fibrous scar on healing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-ulcers">Types of ulcers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Simple or inflammatory ulcers</li>
<li>Traumatic ulcers</li>
<li>Malignant ulcers</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-bone-healing-of-fractures">II)Bone: healing of fractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-bone-healing-of-fractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A fracture is usually accompanied by damage to or hemorrhage into the surrounding soft tissues, which are repaired by the process of organization, whereas the bone fragments repair by regeneration and are reunited.</p>
<ol>
<li>Immediate effects: Haematoma</li>
<li>Inflammatory reaction (first 4-5 days)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A haematoma forms between the 2 edges of fractured bone as well as in the surrounding soft tissue.</li>
<li>Both fractured ends of bone undergo necrosis.</li>
<li>The fractured ends of bone develop an acute inflammatory reaction providing the area with macrophages &amp; osteoclasts to phagocytose the debris &amp; necrotic tissue.</li>
<li>Invasion of the soft tissue haematoma by granulation tissue (capillaries &amp; fibroblasts) i.e. early stage of organization.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-early-bone-regeneration-after-1st-week-provisional-callus">3. Early bone regeneration (after 1st week) (PROVISIONAL CALLUS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-early-bone-regeneration-after-1st-week-provisional-callus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A provisional callus bridges the gap between the fractured ends of bone. It is composed of osteoblasts) osteoid tissue +non-mineralized bone). This callus is also present under the periosteum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-well-formed-callus-after-3-weeks">4. Well formed callus (after 3 weeks)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-well-formed-callus-after-3-weeks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calcium &amp;phosphates are deposited in the area, with resultant mineralization of the osteoid into osseous tissue (woven bone trabeculae).
5. Remodeling of definitive callus &amp; bone marrow regeneration (weeks- months)</p>
<p>This phase is characterized by osteoblastic &amp; osteoclastic activity, to get rid of extra callus in subperiosteal &amp; medullary layers in addition to strengthening the prevailing callus changing it into lamellar bone.
6. Final reconstruction with return of bone to normal appearance (months later). Dense lamellar bone with trabeculae oriented along lines of stress is now present with scanty osteoblasts &amp; osteoclasts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Bad healing results in pathological fracture</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Loss of function. This may be due to either non-union or weak union (fibrous union)
Causes of bad healing:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inadequate mobilization.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Soft tissue interposition.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Infection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>2ry to previous bone disease as osteoporosis, malignancy or due to compound.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type of fracture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>General causes of improper healing (see above)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-peripheral-nerve-damage-heals-by-regeneration-e-g-spinal-motor-nerve">III) Peripheral nerve damage heals by regeneration e.g. spinal motor nerve:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-peripheral-nerve-damage-heals-by-regeneration-e-g-spinal-motor-nerve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cutting of axon and myelin sheath causes rapid degeneration of distal segment whilst proximal zone suffers minimally since the central neuron in the spinal cord is not directly damaged &amp; it just loses its pigment (Nissel granules).</li>
<li>Proximal segment changes (chromatolysis i.e. loss of Nissel substance in the neuron). These are mild degenerative neuronal changes and are reversible.</li>
<li>Distal segment changes(Wallerian Degeneration) Axon disintegrates, myelin disintegrates and only Schwann cells survive.</li>
<li>Motor end plates and muscle fibers: damage to distal segment results in neurogenic atrophy of supplied muscle fibers.</li>
<li>Regeneration begins by Schwann cell proliferation producing a continuous neurilemal tube. This is accompanied by phagocytosis of any debris and sprouting ofaxons from proximal segment with growth along track of the empty tube. Finally, the myelin sheath is reformed.</li>
</ul>
<p>Complications: poor apposition of the nerve ends, results in irregular sprouting ofaxons and proliferation of Schwann cells in the CT, forming a mass of tangled nerves called TRAUMATIC NEUROMA in addition to severe neurogenic muscle atrophy and the distal nerve segment fragment disappears.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b-only-cns-heals-by-gliosis">N.B.: only CNS heals by gliosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b-only-cns-heals-by-gliosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>IV) Regeneration of stable cells following cell damage with survival of the supporting reticular framework</p>
<ul>
<li>Tubular necrosis of the kidney: necrosis of tubular epithelium only. The necrotic cells are replaced by proliferation of the surviving cells</li>
<li>Acute hepatitis: focal necrosis of hepatocytes are replaced by survivi ng cells with return of liver to normal</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-repair-by-fibrosis-organization">B. REPAIR BY FIBROSIS (organization)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-repair-by-fibrosis-organization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-limited-regeneration-fibrosis">1. Limited REGENERATION + FIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-limited-regeneration-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs when gross damage occurs in solid epithelial organs containing stable cells and including their supportive tissue e.g.:</p>
<ul>
<li>Liver cirrhosis e.g. post -viral hepatitis B. The virus causes destruction of diffuse areas of liver cells &amp; supportive tissue. Regeneration of surviving cells is minimal &amp; irregular producing regeneration nodules and areas of dense fibrosis surrounding these nodules(see special).</li>
<li>Wound healing:epidermis regenerates whilst dermis&amp; subcutis heal by FT</li>
<li>Chronic or deep ulcer: ulcers involving mucosa &amp; submucosa or epidermis &amp; dermis.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Healing by 1ry intention (surgical incision)</th><th style="text-align: center;">Healing by 2ry intention</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">- Clean &amp;small wound &lt;br&gt; - Minimal necrosis &lt;br&gt; - <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> Inflammation &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> scar &lt;br&gt; - Short time to heal &lt;br&gt; - Few or no complications</td><td style="text-align: center;">- Large or infected wound &lt;br&gt; - Much necrosis &lt;br&gt; - <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> inflammation &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> scar &lt;br&gt; - Longer since tnecrosis/infection &lt;br&gt; - Complications common (depends on size &amp; amount of damage)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">24 hrs Little necrosis-clot-acute inflammation &lt;br&gt; Surface covered by dried clot (Scab)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Much necrosis - raw area - acute inflammation.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">3-7days: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> inflam-GT fills gap &lt;br&gt; - mitosis in basal cells to fill gap. &lt;br&gt; - BM forms on contact of basal cells.</td><td style="text-align: center;">- Wound starts to contract (myofibro blasts in GT)- tacute inflammation &lt;br&gt; - Mitosis in basal layer of epidermis with complete regeneration of epidermis occurs after GT has filled the entire gap</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Weeks: FT &amp; scar with no adenexa Epidermis regenerates by prolifer -ation upward of basal layer to surface GT-FT, followed by scar.</td><td style="text-align: center;">- GT, FT, then scar. Time depends on size of wound &amp; amount of necrosis that has to be removed before healing.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Complications of wound healing
1- Contracture &amp; deformity
2- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> GT (proud flesh) which prevents proper epithelization since it grows above the surface
3- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> GT <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Weak scar tends to rupture (deheisance)
Delayed healing
4- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> hyalinosed collagen is known as Keloid, which is a raised deforming scar with hyalinosed, scar (swollen scar); it occurs in people with a hereditary predisposition. Attempts at surgical removal cause its reappearance. Treatment is by irradiation.</p>
<p>5- Chronic ulcer-fistula-sinus usually occurs if infection is persistent.
6- Epidermal cyst: some epidermal cells become trapped in the dermis during injury, they grow and form a cyst.
7- Malignant transformation (rare)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-repair-by-organization-by-fibrosis-gliosis-in-cns">2. REPAIR by ORGANIZATION by fibrosis (gliosis in CNS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-repair-by-organization-by-fibrosis-gliosis-in-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs when gross damage occurs in solid epithelial organs containing stable cells and including their supportive tissue e.g.:</p>
<p>Infarction kidney (see circulatory disturbances) : necrotic tissue is removed &amp; organization occurs, ending in a scar (GT followed FT then Scar).</p>
<p>Healing of structurless material, i.e. not tissue, e.g. thrombus or products of inflammation (inflammatory exudate), as in serofibrinous or fibrinous inflammation. These heal by fibrosis are called adhesions as the FT causes white, firm bands which glue the two layers of the serous membranes together.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">MORPHOLOGY (BR)</th><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;"></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">GROSS</td><td style="text-align: left;">MICROSCOPIC</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">GT</td><td style="text-align: left;">Pink granular, bleeds easily.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Fibroblasts+new capillaries &lt;br&gt; (+/-inflammatory cells)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">FT</td><td style="text-align: left;">White, firm, smooth tissue causes &lt;br&gt; shrinkage.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Fibroblasts+ BV +collagen</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Scar</td><td style="text-align: left;">Same as FT</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> fibroblasts +tcollagen (no BV)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Gross Appearance of FT / Scar: depends on site</p>
<ul>
<li>Body cavities <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> adhesions (white firm, smooth, bands joining visceral to parietal layer)</li>
<li>Abscess cavity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> smooth thick white wall around cavity</li>
<li>Hollow structure (intestine - urinary tract etc.) resulting in Stricture, which causes narrowing of lumen i.e. stenosis. If a stricture doesn't form, the whole wall may be thinned out and dilates, producing a pouch, i.e. dilatation or aneurysm (if in a vessel wall). This area is usually weak and may rupture.</li>
<li>Solid organs e.g. liver: bands or irregular patches of white firm, smooth tissue which shrinks and causes surface depression (irregularity or nodularity on surface).</li>
</ul>
<p>PLATE 6
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a7041201.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-3953dd19.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-edbcb951.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>SUMMARY OF FATE &amp; COMPLICATIONS
OF CHRONIC INFLAMMATION &amp; REPAIR BY FIBROSIS
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-37eb6b89.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-complications-of-chronic-inflammation">A. COMPLICATIONS OF CHRONIC INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-complications-of-chronic-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>LOCAL TISSUE DESTRUCTION</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Hemorrhage</li>
<li>Organ failure (loss of function due to tissue destruction)</li>
<li>Dystrophic calcification</li>
<li>Systemic amyloidosis</li>
<li>Malignant transformation due to chronic irritation</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>SPREAD
(a) Direct</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Spread of the inflammation &amp; necrosis resulting in ulcer, sinus or fistula formation.</li>
<li>Transluminal (respiratory or biliary tract spread etc... )</li>
<li>Transcoelomic e.g. septic peritonitis i.e. in body cavities
(b) Distant</li>
<li>Lymphatic spread: at first regional lymphangitis and regional lymphadenitis then generalized lymphadenopathy.</li>
<li>Blood stream spread: bacteremia-septicemia-toxemia-pyaemia (see infections).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-complications-of-healing-by-fibrosis">B. COMPLICATIONS OF HEALING BY FIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-complications-of-healing-by-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>In solid organs with loss of function e.g. liver cirrhosis ends in liver failure.</li>
<li>Surfaces: Skin: deformity or contracture.</li>
<li>Body cavities e.g. pleura etc... leads to adhesions.</li>
<li>Hollow structure e.g. intestine etc... <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> stenosis (narrowing of lumen/obstruction) or dilatation (bronchiectasis lor pouch formation with weakening &amp; thinning of wall (vascular aneurysms)</li>
</ol>
<p>N.B.: dilated areas may cause pressure on surrounding structures or may rupture e.g. aneurysms (see special).
5. Keloids (increase in hyalinosed collagen) &amp; proud flesh (increased GT).
6. Epiderrmal cyst.
7. Dystrophic calcification.
8. Weak surgical scar may rupture under pressure (wound deheisance) or inscisional hernia may occur (see special).</p>
<p>SUMMARY OF CELL INJURY - INFLAMMATION &amp; REPAIR
Irreversible or reversible INJURY
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-29e1c05c.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></p>
<p>Vascular + cellular responses of A.lnfl are followed by resolution, regeneration or fibrosis.
Vascular + cellular responses + repair by fibrosis &amp; or regeneration occur during C.infl.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="healing">HEALING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#healing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="resolution">RESOLUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Injurious agent destroyed quickly</p>
<p>Little or no necrosis.
Healing depends on amount of products of inftammation.
Little exudate
resolves
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-696d41d6.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg"></p>

e.g.</p>
<p>Lobar pneumonia
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-58b51586.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stem-cells">Stem Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stem-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Stem cells are the master cells of the human body. They can divide to produce copies of themselves and many other types of cell. They are found in various parts of the human body at every stage of development from embryo to adult. Stem cells taken from embryos that are just a few days old, can turn into any of the 300 different types of cell that make up the adult body.</li>
<li>Stem cells are unspecialized cells that are thought to be able to reproduce themselves indefinitely and, under the right conditions, to develop into mature cells, e.g., nerve, skin, pancreas, with specialized functions. They are found in embryos at very early stages of development (see figure) and in some adult organs, e.g., bone marrow and brain.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="importance-of-stem-cells">Importance of stem cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#importance-of-stem-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because stem cells are so versatile, they could potentially be used to repair and replace damaged human tissue. In future it is hoped that stem cells could be used to treat and cure a variety of diseases and injuries including Parkinson's disease, stroke and diabetes.</p>
<p>Unlike muscle cells, blood cells, or nerve cells-which do not normally replicate themselves-stem cells may replicate many times.</p>
<p>Under certain physiological or experimental conditions, they can be induced to differentiate. This means that they can divide into cells with special functions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-stem-cells-fig-1">Types of Stem Cells: (Fig. 1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-stem-cells-fig-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Totipotent cells. In mammals, totipotent cells have the potential to form an entire body ie a single cell can divide and produce all the differentiated cells (from ectoderm, endoderm &amp; mesoderm), including extraembryonic tissues (yolk sac &amp; trophoblast)</li>
<li>Pluripotent stem cells. These are true stem cells, with the potential to make any differentiated cell in the body. A pluripotent cell can create all cell types except for extra embryonic tissue, Three types of pluripotent stem cells have been found:</li>
</ol>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Embryonic Stem (ES) Cells. These can be isolated from the inner cell mass (ICM) of the blastocyst - the stage of embryonic development when implantation occurs. For humans, excess embryos produced during in vitro fertilization (IVF) procedures are used.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Embryonic Germ (EG) Cells. These can be isolated from the precursor to the gonads in aborted fetuses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Embryonic Carcinoma (EC) Cells. These can be isolated from teratocarcinomas, a tumor that occasionally occurs in a gonad of a fetus. Unlike the other two, they are usually aneuploid.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>All three of these types of pluripotent stem cells can only be isolated from embryonic or fetal tissue.
3. Multipotent stem cells. These are true stem cells but can only differentiate into a limited number of types. For example, the bone marrow contains multipotent stem cells that give rise to all the cells of the blood but not to other types of cells. Multipotent stem cells are found in adult animals and in most organs in the body where they can replace dead or damaged cells.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-2df6d33e.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 1 Types of stem cells</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-adult-stem-cells">4. Adult Stem Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-adult-stem-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Many adult tissues (such as the bone marrow, liver and gut) contain stem cells. Like embryonic stem cells, adult stem cells can make identical copies of themselves for long periods of time (self renewal). At the same time, they can give rise to mature cell types that have characteristic shapes and specialized functions e.g. hematopoietic cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stem-cell-plasticity">Stem cell plasticity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stem-cell-plasticity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Stem cells from one tissue may be able to give rise to cell types of a completely different tissue. This phenomenon is known as 'stem cell plasticity'. Examples of such plasticity include bone marrow stem cells becoming neurons, or pancreatic islet cells that are capable of producing insulin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-to-obtain-stem-cells">How to obtain Stem Cells?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-obtain-stem-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Aborted fetuses or fertilized eggs:</li>
<li>Bone marrow, peripheral blood or umbilical cord blood: These sources for stem cells are ethical and legal.</li>
<li>Skin,pulp of milk teeth, fat cells: recent sources of adult stem cells</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="potential-therapeutic-applications-of-stem-cells">Potential Therapeutic Applications of Stem Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#potential-therapeutic-applications-of-stem-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Generation of different types of neurons for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease, spinal cord injuries, or Parkinson's disease.</li>
<li>Production of heart muscle cells for heart attack survivors may also be possible.</li>
<li>Generation of insulin-secreting pancreatic islet cells for the treatment of type-1 diabetes.</li>
<li>Generation of hair follicle stem cells for the treatment of certain types of baldness.</li>
<li>Production of complete organs including livers, kidneys, eyes, hearts, or even parts of the brain.</li>
<li>Drug testing,</li>
<li>Cancer research.</li>
<li>Fundamental research on embryonic development.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Basic reactions</td><td style="text-align: left;">All basic reactions</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Repair</td><td style="text-align: left;">All definitions</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">All Acute &amp; chronic infl</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Factors affecting repair</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Types of repair</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Repair of bone</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Repair in CNS &amp;PNS</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Healing by fibrosis &amp; healing Qf</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">wounCfS</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Healing of serofibrinous inflammation</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Control mechanisms in repair</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Cell cycle</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Stem cells: definition&amp; types rest</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">category c</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunopathology">IMMUNOPATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunopathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunity-immune-response">IMMUNITY-Immune response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunity-immune-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Immunity is our protection from foreign macromolecules or invading organisms and our response to them, these include viruses, bacteria, protozoa, or even larger parasites and tumor antigens. The immune response is vital for life since when they are defective as in the immune-deficiency states this can lead to life threatening diseases.</p>
<p>The mechanisms of protection against infection and disease are diverse. Primarily they can be divided into two major categories:</p>
<ol>
<li>Innate immune response.</li>
<li>Adaptive immune response (acquired immunity).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-non-specific-natural-or-innate-immunity">1. Non Specific Natural or innate immunity:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-non-specific-natural-or-innate-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Mechanical (skin).
b) Physical ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> temperature).
c) Chemical (lysozyme-tears-saliva).
d) Cellular (micro &amp; macrophages).
e) Natural killer lymphocytes (non specific cytotoxic cells) &amp; opsonins (antibodies which help phagocytic process by causing roughening of the surface).
2. Acquired (Specific immunity) :Is the second line of defense.</p>
<ul>
<li>Includes humoral and cell mediated responses.</li>
<li>The response is more rapid on re-exposure to the pathogen due to activation of memory cells and improves upon repeated exposure.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Non specific immunity</th><th style="text-align: left;">Specific immunity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Response is antigen independent.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Response is antigen dependant.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">There is immediate maximal response.</td><td style="text-align: left;">There is lag time between exposure and &lt;br&gt; maximal response.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">No antigen specific.</td><td style="text-align: left;">antigen specific.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Exposure results in no immunologic &lt;br&gt; memory.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Exposure results in no immunologic &lt;br&gt; memory.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sources-of-immune-cells">SOURCES OF IMMUNE CELLS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-immune-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Bone marrow stem cells are differentiatted into: T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes and non T &amp; non B lymphocytes (natural killer NK cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These cells go and populate lymphoid organs: lymph nodes and spleen Follicles in cortex contain B cells &amp; Paracortex contains T cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunopathology">IMMUNOPATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunopathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: It is the study of abnormal immune responses
Abnormal Immune Response</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">EXAGGERATED &lt;br&gt; Hypersensitivity</th><th style="text-align: left;">DEFICIENT &lt;br&gt; Immunodeficiency</th><th style="text-align: left;">LOSS OF TOLERANCE &lt;br&gt; Autoimmunity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Types I-V</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> phagocytosis &lt;br&gt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> number or function)</td><td style="text-align: left;">Hypersensitivity Types II-V</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Harmful: tissue destruction</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold-italic">n</mi><mi mathvariant="bold-italic">o</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\boldsymbol{n} \boldsymbol{o}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4444em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord boldsymbol">n</span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord boldsymbol">o</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> immune reaction</td><td style="text-align: left;">Immune reaction to self</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-hypersensitmty">I) HYPERSENSITMTY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-hypersensitmty" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a harmful exaggerated immune response on re-exposure to antigen (i.e. 2nd exposure). This harmful reaction of the immune system in response to entry or presence of a foreign or altered protein (antigen) is in the form of a humoral (antibody), cell mediated (lymphoid cells, T cell) response or both combined in an attempt to destroy the antigen, BUT HOST TISSUE is also destroyed.</p>
