<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-hypersensitivity">TYPES OF HYPERSENSITIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>HUMORAL MECHANISMS</li>
</ol>
<p>Type I: Allergy - Anaphylaxis (systemic) &amp; Atopy (local) (Immediate hypersensitivity).
Type II: Antibody mediated cytotoxicity.
Type III: Immune complex.
2) DELAYED HYPERSENSTIVITY (Cell mediated reaction)</p>
<p>Type IV: e.g. T cell granulomas
Antigen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Humoral immunity</p>
<p>Cell meditated immunity</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-antigens">TYPES OF ANTIGENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-antigens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Foreign antigen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Hypersensitivity &amp; Graft rejection.
Self antigen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Autoimmune disease e.g. connective tissue disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="type-i-hypersensitivity">TYPE I HYPERSENSITIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-i-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Type I reactions involve immunoglobulin E (lgE)-mediated release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells and basophils.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">Mechanism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text {st }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> exposure Antigen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> causes tissue B lymphocytes &amp; plasma cells to produce IgE which attaches on surface of Mast cells/basophils (sensitized cell)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mtext>nd&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{\text {nd }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">nd&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> exposure Antigen <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> antigen attaches to Fab fragment of antibody and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> degranulation of mast cell or basophil---&gt;release of vasoactive amines or chemical mediators (chemotactic to eosinophils &amp; neutrophils). It is an acute inflammation rich in eosinophils.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">ANAPHYLAXIS &lt;br&gt; Systemic reaction &lt;br&gt; In blood stream (injection)</th><th style="text-align: center;">ATOPY &lt;br&gt; Local reaction &lt;br&gt; Hay fever &lt;br&gt; Bronchial asthma &lt;br&gt; grass -pollen &lt;br&gt; mite dust &lt;br&gt; animal fur &lt;br&gt; Wide spread reaction</th><th style="text-align: center;">localized at site of IgE production</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Basophils are in circulation</td><td style="text-align: center;">It has a genetic predisposition. Mast cells are involved</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Edema larynx <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> death &lt;br&gt; Bronchospasm &lt;br&gt; Skin rash(urticaria) &lt;br&gt; Hypotension &lt;br&gt; Vomiting &amp; diarrhea</td><td style="text-align: center;">local sensitization &lt;br&gt; - conjunctiva &lt;br&gt; - nasal passages &lt;br&gt; - upper resp tract &lt;br&gt; bronchospasm &lt;br&gt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> mucus secretions &lt;br&gt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> &lt;br&gt; difficult breathing wheezing.</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Shock</td><td style="text-align: center;">Acute catarrhal Inflammation</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture-of-acute-inflammation">Gross: Picture of acute inflammation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture-of-acute-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">Microscopic:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many eosinophils + macrophages + some PNL+ lymphocytes &amp; plasma cells + vasodilatation + marked edema.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-examples-of-type-i-hypersensitivity">Other Examples of Type I hypersensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-examples-of-type-i-hypersensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Allergic rhinitis &amp; Nasal polyp (see special)
TYPE II HYPERSENSITIVITY antibody dependant cell mediated cytotoxicty ( ADCC)</p>
<p>Type II reactions (ie, cytotoxic hypersensitivity reactions) involve immunoglobulin G or immunoglobulin M antibodies bound to cell surface antigens, with subsequent complement fixation.</p>
<ul>
<li>The antigens are normally endogenous, although exogenous chemicals can attach to cell membranes.</li>
<li>Cytolysis (cell lysis) is primarily mediated by antibodies of the IgM or IgG classes and complement. Phagocytes and K cells may also playa role (ADCC).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hemolytic anemia</li>
<li>Incompatible blood transfusion reactions</li>
<li>Rh incompatibility (erythroblastosis fetalis)</li>
</ul>
<p>Microscopic (BR): <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> eosinophils + macrophages + some PNL, lymphocytes &amp; plasma cells + vasodilatation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> edema</p>
<p>TYPE III HYPERSENSITIVITY-IMMUNE COMPLEX DISORDERS (Arthu5 type)
Type III reactions involve circulating antigen-antibody immune complexes that deposit in postcapillary venules, with subsequent complement fixation.</p>
<p>Mechanism: Antigen + Antibody (lgG/lgM) (Immune complex), circulate in blood then get trapped in blood vessel basement membrane &amp; activate the complement (anaphylatoxin &amp; PNL chemotaxis) resulting in VASCULITIS. This produces damage to endothelium with platelet aggregation &amp; THROMBOSIS. Ischemia occurs ending in NECROSIS of surrounding tissue</p>
<p>Examples:</p>
<ul>
<li>Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis-Rheumatic fever</li>
<li>Acute serum sickness</li>
</ul>
<p>1 dose of serum injected produces slow release of antigenic proteins (long exposure) produces urticaria-fever-glomerulonephritis-joint pains-lymph node enlargement.</p>
<ul>
<li>Arthus reaction</li>
</ul>
<p>Repeated injections e.g. insulin causes vasculitis-necrosis-edema &amp; hemorrhage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parasitic-infestation">- Parasitic infestation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parasitic-infestation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Microscopic picture: plasma cells &amp; B lymphocytes + macrophages + vasodilatation + edema.</p>
<p>TYPE IV HYPERSENSITIVITY - CELL MEDIATED HYPERSENSITIVITY
Type IV reactions (i.e. delayed hypersensitivity reactions, cell-mediated immunity) are mediated by T cells rather than by antibodies. The term delayed is used to differentiate a secondary cellular response, which appears 48-72 hours after antigen exposure, from an immediate hypersensitivity response, which generally appears within 12 minutes of an antigen challenge. These reactions are mediated by T cells and monocytes/macrophages rather than by antibodies.</p>
<p>MECHANISM: Dendritic cells at site of entry in draining LN, process antigen &amp; present it to T lymphocytes. These become activated T lymphoblasts and divide producing memory cells &amp; sensitized T cells. Sensitized T lymphocytes migrate to the affected area where they recruit other cells (lymphocytes, macrophages, fibroblasts), sensitize local lymphocytes &amp; produce more Iymphokines as well as cause antigen destruction.</p>
<p>Sensitized T lymphocyte subtypes &amp; their functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>cvtotoxic cells CD8+ cause direct cytotoxicity with lysis of cell surface antigens</li>
<li>T helper cells CD4+: these cells produce lymphokine. Lymphotoxin is one of the Iymphokines which destroys antigen, but mostly Iymphokines are geared to recruit other lymphocytes, macrophages &amp; fibroblasts to the area (BR).</li>
</ul>
<p>Microscopic picture: Vasculitis(Fibrinoid Necrosis of blood vessel wall + Acute inflammation of wall with PNLs &amp; macrophages) &amp; Necrosis with acute inflammation of tissue (PNLs -macrophages -vasodilatation- edema).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Granulomas e.g. TB &amp; sarcoidosis</li>
<li>Viral infection with intracellular organism</li>
<li>Contact dermatitis</li>
<li>Insect bite</li>
<li>Parasitic infestation</li>
</ul>
<p>Viral infection: Virus enters cell as an obligate nuclear parasite, replicates &amp; change the DNA sequence of the cell producing a foreign protein. This induces a T cell reaction with killing of virus &amp; the cell containing the virus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="granuloma">Granuloma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#granuloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Bacterial e.g. TB: Bacteria living inside macrophage (e.g. TB bacilli) produce antigens, which is processed in the dendritic macrophages of regional LN. These present the processed antigen to the T lymphocytes to transform them into T lymphoblasts. These cells divide &amp; produce memory T &amp; sensitized T cells. On arrival of the sensitized T cells at site of antigen, they produce lymphokines (MAF, MF&amp; others) which lead to further accumulation &amp; activation of macrophages, lymphocytes, and fibroblasts as well as synthesis of collagen. The TB or any type of granuloma is thus formed with central destruction due to cytotoxic lymphokines released from CD4+ cells or the direct cytotoxicity of CD8 + T lymphocyte subsets.
B. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is an immune system disorder of unknown cause. It is characterized by multisystemic affection that involves lung in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases. Usually occurs in 20-40 year old males and females, but it is more common in females.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patholgical-lesions">Patholgical lesions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patholgical-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas . Virtually any organ can be affected; however, granulomas most often appear in the lungs or the lymph nodes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gaft-rejection-pathology-of-transplantation">Gaft rejection (pathology of transplantation)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gaft-rejection-pathology-of-transplantation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tissue cells carry specific surface antigens, called Major Histocompatibility Antigens) MHC). These can evoke Type IV reactions also the RBC content with its ABO system can evoke in addition a Humoral type II reaction &amp; type III reactions to any complexes in blood.</p>
<p>This rejection can be suppressed by -cyclosporins (drugs), Irradiation or surgical removal of thymus (source of T cells)</p>
<p>Microscopic: T Cytotoxic (CD8+), T helper (CD4+ which attack graft cells) + B cells (antibodies) + macrophages</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-reaction-in-t-cell-responses">GENERAL REACTION IN T CELL responses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-reaction-in-t-cell-responses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Granulomatous: Lymphocytes + epithelioid macrophages + giant cells + FT &amp; endarteritis oblterans. OR
B. Diffuse reaction e.g. in graft rejection &amp; contact dermatitis Perivascular lymphocytes &amp; edema.
C. Patchy e.g. in insect bites</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="autoimmune-disorders">AUTOIMMUNE DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autoimmune-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Immune system of the host reacts against its own cells i.e. against selfantigens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Type II</li>
<li>Connective tissue diseases: Autoimmune diseases characterized by injury to collagen especially in blood vessels and tissues around them.</li>
<li>Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Rheumatic fever-Rheumatoid arthritisPolyarteritis nodosa-scleroderma-polymyositis/dermatomyositis mostly Type III.</li>
</ul>
<p>Microscopic: Fragmentation of collagen producing a fibrin-like, pink mass of Fibrinoid necrosis with Inflammation followed by fibrosis.</p>
<ul>
<li>Graves disease Type V IgG, long acting thyroid stimulator (LATS) attaches to TSH surface receptor on thyroid follicle cell &amp; it takes the place of TSH, stimulating the receptor &amp; escaping the control feedback mechanism. This results in the clinical condition thyrotoxicosis</li>
<li>Others (ulcerative colitis-1ry biliary cirrhosis-some types of male infertilityHashimoto thyroiditis Type IV NB see special for disease details.
N.B.: GRAFT VERSUS HOST reaction (GVH): It is a reaction which occurs in immunosuppressed patients where graft lymphocytes evoke an immune response to patient (host) tissue i.e. lymphocytes attacks the host &amp; produces disease.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tolerance">TOLERANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tolerance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-tolerance-self-tolerance">Natural tolerance (self tolerance)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-tolerance-self-tolerance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a process by which the body's immune system prevents itself from reacting to the body's own antigens.</p>
<p>Acquired tolerance: Occurs after neonatal period &amp; throughout adult life when very small doses of foreign antigen are introduced over a long period. This may induce tolerance in an adult &amp; is the basis of desensitization treatments in allergy.</p>
<p>Mechanism of tolerance (not yet well understood) possible hypotheses:</p>
<ol>
<li>Burnet's Forbidden clone theory (clonal selection):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>clonal deletion:In fetal life all lymphoid cells, which could respond immunologically to selfantigens, are eliminated. Self-reactive T lymphocytes are eliminated in the thymus by apoptosis</li>
<li>
<div data-testid="stMarkdownPre" class="st-emotion-cache-acwcvw e1icttdg5"><div class="stCode st-emotion-cache-6ml83 e1xss9yb4" data-testid="stCode"><pre class="st-emotion-cache-1nqbjoj e1xss9yb2"><div style="background-color: transparent;"><code style="white-space: pre;"><span>- clonal anergy:ls the process of inactivation of some of the self-reactive T lymphocytes which have escaped death by apoptosis in the thymus</span></code></div></pre><div class="st-emotion-cache-chk1w8 e1xss9yb3"><button data-testid="stCodeCopyButton" title="Copy to clipboard" data-clipboard-text="- clonal anergy:ls the process of inactivation of some of the self-reactive T lymphocytes which have escaped death by apoptosis in the thymus" style="top: 0px; right: 0px;" class="st-emotion-cache-1lyayqq e1xss9yb5"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><rect x="9" y="9" width="13" height="13" rx="2" ry="2"></rect><path d="M5 15H4a2 2 0 0 1-2-2V4a2 2 0 0 1 2-2h9a2 2 0 0 1 2 2v1"></path></svg></button></div></div></div>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Peripheral T suppressor cell activity: In adults, acquired tolerance is associated with specific antibodies, which inhibit both helper T cells &amp; B cells</li>
</ol>
<p>TOLERANCE thus protects our bodies from developing autoimmune disorders</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mechanism-of-autoimmunity">MECHANISM OF AUTOIMMUNITY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-autoimmunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Genetic or familial defect.</li>
<li>Instability of tolerance mechanism.</li>
<li>Cross reactivity:
a) Foreign antigen may be similar to a body antigen.
b) Antibody produced against a foreign antigen may also react with certain body antigens.</li>
<li>Uncovering of sequestrated (hidden) antigens. Chronic tissue destruction results in:
a) Release of hidden proteins (thyroglobulin or semen or even intracytoplasmic proteins) thereby presenting the immune system with a new antigen.
b)Alteration of surface antigen Altered antigen thereby presenting the immune system with a new antigen.</li>
<li>Absence of T suppressor cell activity</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunodeficiencystates">IMMUNODEFICIENCYSTATES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunodeficiencystates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Failure in either the specific immune response (Humoral/cell mediated) or the nonspecific system (phagocytes-complement) may result in alteration of the immune response, which may be quantitative or qualitative.</p>
<ul>
<li>Primary genetic</li>
<li>Secondary to disease</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Humoral system (Lack of B cells - inability to secrete Ig - activation of suppressors)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell mediated (Di George's syndrome-AIDS)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytic cell deficiencies (Chronic granulomatous disease-Lazy leukocyte syndrome)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complement deficiencies
a) Primary or inherited deficiencies of B or T cells resulting in recurrent respiratory or alimentary tract infections
b) Secondary deficiencies e.g.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Infections: Acute viral-chronic bacterial-chronic protozoal (malaria)</li>
<li>AIDS or acquired immune deficiency syndrome (HIV virus)</li>
<li>Malnutrition particularly protein deficiency</li>
<li>Drug induced e.g. corticosteroids &amp; Cytotoxic drugs which cause immunosuppression</li>
<li>Malignant disease e.g. advanced cancer of lymph nodes (lymphoma/Hodgkin disease)</li>
</ul>
<p>All the above cause impaired immunity which results in intercurrent infection particularly:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="oportunistic-infections">OPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oportunistic-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DEFINITION: These are diseases caused by non pathogenic or low virulence organisms with an impaired immune system and which usually cause death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Congenital immunodeficiencies</li>
<li>Acquired
a) Result of disease e.g. HIV (human Immunodeficiency virus) ( see viral infection) causes the acquired Immunodeficiency disorder AIDS or malignancy (lymphoma).
b) b) 2 ry to treatment in patients on immunosuppressives as cyclosporins or antibiotics which may change intestinal flora.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-manifestations">Types &amp; manifestations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-manifestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Bacteria: Low virulence Strept epidermidis or viridans is responsible for bacterial endocarditis &amp; low-grade septicemia.</li>
<li>Protozoa: Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia with a foamy (frothy pink) alveolar exudates Toxoplasmosis produces pneumonia or CNS damage</li>
<li>Viruses: cause a generalized infection, severe organ damage e.g.: Herpes encephalitis &amp; cytomegaloviral infection, Aquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)( see viral infections).</li>
<li>Fungi: Monilia (candidiasis) of GIT-systemic fungemia-endocarditis Aspergillosis: granulomas in lung - systemic fungemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunology-cancer">IMMUNOLOGY &amp; CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunology-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cancers stimulate immunological reactions since tumor cells have altered genes, which produce altered proteins. On the cell surface, these proteins are considered foreign by the body (tumor associated antigens TAA).</p>
<p>The involvement of the immune mechanism has been recognized since some cancers</p>
<ol>
<li>Tend to regress in some patients</li>
<li>Secondaries are relatively rare in spleen, probably due to the spleen's ability to destroy abnormal cells in the circulation.</li>
<li>In some tumors the presence of lymphocytic response around the tumor is associated with a favorable prognosis</li>
<li>BCG is given in some treatment protocols to increase cell mediated immunity in general i.e. nonspecific boost of immune system</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="applied-immunology">APPLIED IMMUNOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applied-immunology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-diagnosis">A. DIAGNOSIS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- SEROLOGIC ANTIBODY DETECTION METHODS: by detection of circulating specific antibodies using specific antigens.</p>
<p>2- 2-IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY &amp;TUMOR MARKERS (tissue &amp;serum).
Rabbit/mouse is injected with specific antigen e.g. TAA. The animal is left to live long enough to form antibodies against the antigen, then it is bled &amp; the blood containing the specific antibodies is tagged (i.e. labeled) with several dyes as: fluorescine (a fluorescent dye) or with peroxidase (dye with a brown color in tissue) or alkaline phosphatase (red color). Only cells containing the specific tumor antigen will react with the labeled antibody and staining only of the specific tumor cells will occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-prophylaxis-treatment-vaccines-organ-transplantationblood">B. PROPHYLAXIS &amp; TREATMENT VACCINES- ORGAN TRANSPLANTATIONBLOOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-prophylaxis-treatment-vaccines-organ-transplantationblood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transfusion-desensitization">TRANSFUSION- DESENSITIZATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transfusion-desensitization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Vaccination.
a. Passive: Injection sera containing Immunoglobulins specific or non-specific to bacteria or their products e.g. toxins. An important complication is serum sickness or anaphylaxis &amp; shock.
b. Active(modified antigen vaccine)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Killed <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> typhoid</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toxoid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> tetanus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attenuated or weakened e.g. viral vaccines of polio &amp; measles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Organ transplantation-blood transfusion: Proper matching is mandatory to avoid incompatibility reactions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Desensitization: Introduction of small gradually increasing doses of a specific antigen, which is responsible for a certain allergy, may result in tolerance to this antigen. This is a good method of treatment of atopic disorders (Type I hypersensitivity).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Basic reactions</td><td style="text-align: left;">All &lt;br&gt; Immunity &lt;br&gt; Types of immune disorders: &lt;br&gt; Hypersensitivity &lt;br&gt; Autoimmune disorders (lmechanism of &lt;br&gt; tolerance) &lt;br&gt; Graft rejection &amp;GVH &lt;br&gt; Immunodeficiency &lt;br&gt; Opportunistic infections &lt;br&gt; Immunology &amp;cancer &lt;br&gt; Applied immunology</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bacterial-infections">BACTERIAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infection">INFECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Is a form of injury, where the injurious agent is a pathogenic (harmful) organism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infectious-disease">INFECTIOUS DISEASE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infectious-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Is the clinical manifestation resulting from tissue damage + reactions as a result of exposure to pathogenic organism
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-5a150ede.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></p>
<p>TYPES OF INFECTIONS</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Pyogenic infection <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\quad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span></span></span></span></span>| Localized (abscess) |
| :-- |
| Diffuse(acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis) |</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Putrefaction: area of necrosis + saprophytic bacteria (putrefaction) = gangrene</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toxic infections Endotoxin (endotoxic shock)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Exotoxin (bacillary dysentery-cholera-tetanus-diphtheria)
4. Opportunistic infection: low body resistance (defective immune response) will encourage commensals to become pathogenic e.g. E.coli &amp; fungal infections which are common particularly in AIDS patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-acute-bacterial-infections">A) ACUTE BACTERIAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-acute-bacterial-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-acute-suppurative">1- Acute suppurative.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-acute-suppurative" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Localized e.g. Staph aureus e.g. subcutaneous abscess
Diffuse e.g. Strept pyogenes causing cellulitis or acute diffuse suppurative appendicitis also serous membrane suppuration as empyema (sac full of pus) &amp; septic peritonitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-acute-non-suppurative">2- Acute non -suppurative<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-acute-non-suppurative" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Fibrinous</li>
<li>Serofibrinous</li>
<li>Serous inflammation</li>
<li>Pseudomembranous e.g. Diphtheria &amp; Bacillary dysentery</li>
<li>Hemorrhagic e.g. small pox &amp; necrotizing e.g. Hemophilus influenza</li>
<li>Putrefactive e.g. gas gangrene caused by Clostridia organisms</li>
<li>Allergic hypersensitivity to Typhoid (Salmonella) see later</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-chronic-bacterial-infections">B) CHRONIC BACTERIAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-chronic-bacterial-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific">- Non specific<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Specific (granulomas)</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Tuberculosis (TB) and atypical mycobacteria</li>
<li>Leprosy: caused by Mycobacterium leprae</li>
<li>Syphilis: caused by Treponema pallidum</li>
<li>Rhinoscleroma: caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis</li>
<li>Actinomycosis: caused by Actinomycetes israeli</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-etiology">- Mechanisms-Etiology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-etiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A- The injurious agent is bacteria: Saprophytes + necrosis in tissue <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
Commensal + low immunity
Pathogenic
disease
B- Route of infection
Inhalation e.g. TB, pneumonia
Ingestion e.g. Typhoid
Contact or direct e.g. venereal diseases as gonorrhea or syphilis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-related-to-both-organism-host">Factors related to both organism &amp; host<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-related-to-both-organism-host" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-host-organism-interaction">1. Host organism interaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-host-organism-interaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-b3a4329c.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg">
2. Host resistance Natural mechanisms
immunopathology)
Induced immune mechanisms (see immunopath)
3. Factors depending on organism:</p>
<p>Dose i.e. quantity
Virulence i.e. strength or ability to produce disease
This depends on:
a. Ability to resist phagocytosis &amp; attack of enzymes
b. Adhesive properties of organism to cell wall
c. Toxin production
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-bffce5a9.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="course-fate-of-any-infection">COURSE &amp; FATE OF ANY INFECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#course-fate-of-any-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A)Inflammatory reaction:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-1c96b1a1.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg">
B)Immune response (humoral or cell mediated) attacks organism &amp; prepares for healing.
C) Gamma Interferon is important in viral infections
D) Phagocytic activity removes debris &amp; organism to make way for healing
E) Failure of protective mechanisms <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> SPREAD of infection
1.Direct spread
2.Distant spread:
a) Lymphangitis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> regionallymphadenitis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> generalized lymphadenitis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> thoracic duct to reach blood stream.
b) Blood stream spread leads to:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-dfc5cf74.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manifestations-of-distant-blood-stream-spread-of-infection">MANIFESTATIONS of distant blood stream spread of infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations-of-distant-blood-stream-spread-of-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Bacteraemia: circulation of low doses or low virulence organisms in the blood stream may cause no disease or just fever (symptoms only with no lesions) except if there is already an abnormality e.g. diseased heart valves or congenital heart disease, where it produces lesions of subacute infective endocarditis) NB in viral infection it is called viraemia.
b) Toxemia: Organismal toxins in the circulation</p>
<p>Endotoxin: gram negative bacteria release toxins when they die &amp; produce endotoxic shock (see shock)</p>
<p>Exotoxin: gram positive bacteria produce toxins which act on specific sites e.g.</p>
<ol>
<li>Tetanus (clostridium tetani acts on presynaptic junctions locally at site + away from site of infection, producing severe contraction of muscle i.e.spasm)</li>
<li>Diphtheria toxins result in neural malfunction (neuritis) +myocarditis + fibrinoid necrosis of abdominal wall muscle (dark pink coagulated mass of necrotic muscle). Shock (acute circulatory failure) may also occur. Death occurs due to acute heart failure as a result of toxic myocarditis.</li>
<li>Bacillary dysentery i.e. Shigella: like diphtheria it is another pseudomembranous type of inflammation where the organism cannot penetrate the tissue but sends its toxins to the submucosal BV and produces the same picture. Toxins produce shock + degeneration &amp; necrosis + acute inflammation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="common-features-of-toxemia">Common features of toxemia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-features-of-toxemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Effect of toxins on nerves &amp; muscles (fibrinoid necrosis &amp; toxic myocarditis)</li>
<li>Toxic injury to liver &amp; kidneys in the form of fatty change up to necrosis</li>
<li>Bone marrow depression</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-pyaemia">c) Pyaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-pyaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Circulation of insoluble necrotic material containing pyogenic organisms. These circulating insoluble substances are called septic emboli and will circulate until they reach a BV with a small lumen, where they get impacted and an abscess is formed, named.</p>
<p>PYAEMIC ABSCESS</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">GROSS</th><th style="text-align: left;">MICROSCOPIC</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Multiple, small, yellow abscesses</td><td style="text-align: left;">BV with nearby focus of suppuration &lt;br&gt; (describe pus) and surrounded by &lt;br&gt; pyogenic membrane (structure of abscess, &lt;br&gt; see acute inflammation).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">surrounded by a zone of congestion &lt;br&gt; related to a BV.</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types">TYPES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">1) Pulmonary pyaemia</th><th style="text-align: center;">2) Systemic pyaemia</th><th style="text-align: center;">3) Portal pyaemia</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Couses: &lt;br&gt; a. Cellulitis/abscess &lt;br&gt; b. Septic thrombophlebitis of any systemic vein</td><td style="text-align: center;">a. Pulmonary vein Septic thrombophlebitis &lt;br&gt; b. Lt.heart vegetations (acute infective endocarditis) &lt;br&gt; c. Very small emboli which by pass lungs &amp; reach pulmonary Veins &lt;br&gt; d. Emboli which by pass lung through a congenital defect in Rt atrium or Rt Ventricle (ASD &amp; VSD)</td><td style="text-align: center;">septic thrombo phlebitis of GIT veins &lt;br&gt; (tributaries of portal vein)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Mechanism: &lt;br&gt; Emboli reach Rt. Heart to Pulmonary artery &amp; then impact in lung BV</td><td style="text-align: center;">Emboli are distributed to all organs by the aorta.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Emboli reach portal veins to liver.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Fate &lt;br&gt; Pyaemic abscesses In LUNG</td><td style="text-align: center;">Pyaemic abscesses in BRAIN-KIDNEYS etc ...</td><td style="text-align: center;">Pyaemic abscesses in LIVER.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The gross &amp; microscopic picture of pyaemic abscesses is similar to that of acute abscess but they are small, multiple &amp; always related to a BV.</p>
<p>If the septic embolus is LARGE it doesn't produce an abscess, it produces SEPTIC INFARCTION (see circulatory).
d) Septicemia (usually fatal): Circulation of large numbers of bacteria, which are multiplying, in the blood stream &amp; releasing their toxins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="etiology">Etiology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Severe infections i.e. high virulence organisms e.g. meningococcal meningitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="or">Or<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#or" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>2- Ordinary infection with a lowered body resistance e.g. E.coli, abscess, cellulitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manifestations">Manifestations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacteria + Toxins in large doses produce: shock + necrosis + acute inflammation + Toxaemia</p>
<ul>
<li>Septic shock (see circulatory)</li>
<li>Septic inflammation of serous membranes (septic peritonitis etc ... )</li>
<li>Acute splenic swelling: large, soft friable &amp; necrotic spleen (inflammed + necrotic)</li>
<li>Waterhouse-Fridriechsen syndrome: haemorrhagic necrotic adrenals</li>
<li>Toxic injury(toxemia): toxic myocarditis-toxic injury to liver &amp; kidneys-bone marrow depression</li>
<li>Damage to alveoli (DAD) ending in acute respiratory distress syndrome</li>
<li>Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIG): thrombosis in small vessels &amp; capillary hemorrhages (see circulatory)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-chronic-bacterial-infections">EXAMPLES OF CHRONIC BACTERIAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-chronic-bacterial-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-tuberculosis">1. TUBERCULOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Tuberculosis is an infectious granuloma caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.</p>
<p>The disease is common is communities with low standards of health.
Methods of infection are: inhalation, ingestion and skin inoculation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="primary-sites-of-infection">Primary Sites of Infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-sites-of-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lungs: Inhalation of human tubercle bacilli.</li>
<li>Intestine: Ingestion of milk containing bovine tubercle bacilli.</li>
<li>Tonsils: Ingestion of milk containing bovine tubercle bacilli.</li>
<li>Skin By contact.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tissue-reaction-in-tuberculosis">Tissue Reaction In Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissue-reaction-in-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two types of tissue reaction occurs; I-Tubercle (proliferative tissue reaction) IIExudative tissue reaction</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-tubercle-proliferative-tissue-reaction">I) Tubercle (Proliferative Tissue Reaction):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-tubercle-proliferative-tissue-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The tubercle is the basic unit of tuberculosis. It is collection of epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells and lymphocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-tubercle-formation">Mode of tubercle formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-tubercle-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The polysaccharide fraction of tubercle bacilli attracts the neutrophils within few hours. They phagocytose the bacteria but unable to destroy them as the bacteria are protected by lipid cell wall and the neutrophils do not contain the lipase enzyme.</li>
<li>The lipid fraction of the cell wall attracts the macrophages after the first day. They collect and phagocytose the free bacilli and those inside the neutrophils and are now called epithelioid cells. The bacilli are partially digested with the release of</li>
</ol>
<p>tuberculoprotein. The tuberculoprotein stimulate a cell mediated immune response (delayed hypersensitivity) within 10 days. Sensitized T-lymphocytes appear and surround the epithelioid cells.
3) The sensitized lymphocytes release various lymphokines which have the following actions:
a) Chemotactic factor:Attracts more nmacrophages to the area of inflammation.
b) Migration inhibition factor (MIF): Inhibits migration of macrophages from Inflamed area.
c) Mitogenic factor: Stimulates proliferation of lymphocytes.
d) Transfer factor: Transfer sensitization to new lymphocytes.
e) Cytotoxic factor: Causes caseating necrosis.
f) Skin reactive factor: Responsible for positive skin test (tuberculin test).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gross-picture">Gross Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The tubercle is of microscopic size. Number of tubercles fuse together to form small rounded grossly seen grey follicles 1-2 millimeters in diameter. When caseation occurs the lesion appears pale yellow and cheesy in consistency.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is collection of many epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells and lymphocytes.</p>
<ol>
<li>Epithelioid cells derived from macrophages which have phagocytosed the tubercle bacilli and became altered by their lipid fraction. They have an epithelial like shape. The cytoplasm is abundant and pale red.The borders are indistinct.</li>
</ol>
<p>The nuclei are large, oval or comma-shaped and vesicular.
2. Lymphocytes at periphery of tubercle.
3. Langhans giant cell: Formed by fusion of a number of epithelioid cells or repeated division of its nucleus. They have abundant cytoplasm and multiple rounded nuclei arranged around the periphery in a circle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="subsequent-change-in-tubercle-caseation">Subsequent change in Tubercle (caseation):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subsequent-change-in-tubercle-caseation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>With the development of hypersensitivity the centre of the tubercle undergoes caseation by partial liquefaction forming yellow ,pasty like material which appears microscopically as a homogenous, structureless and stains pink with eosin.</p>
<p>Caseation occurs when hypersensitivity to tuberculoproteins of bacilli is developed and it is due to lymphotoxins from sensitized T lymphocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fate-of-tubercle">Fate of Tubercle:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-tubercle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>High immunity:
a) Small lesions are completely fibrosed
b) Large caseous lesions are encapsulated and may be followed dystrophic calcification. Living bacteria may remain in the lesion.</li>
<li>Low immunity: The lesion spreads.( describe).</li>
</ol>
