<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-exudative-tissue-reaction">II) Exudative Tissue Reaction:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-exudative-tissue-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Occurs when large number of tubercle bacilli reach the lung and serous membranes of sensitized individual (high hypersensitivity) and low immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-reaction-is-characterized-by">The reaction is characterized by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-reaction-is-characterized-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Excess serous inflammatory fluid exudate reach in fibrinogen</li>
<li>The exudate contains large number of neutrophils and lymphocytes and small number of epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells.</li>
<li>Caseation is rapid and extensive, may undergo liquefaction by the enzymes of neutrophils.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-54e7b98c.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2 - Microscopic features of tubercle and its fate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spread-of-tuberculous-infection">Spread of Tuberculous Infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread-of-tuberculous-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Direct spread: Macrophages and tissue fluid carry the bacilli to the surrounding tissues.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lymphatic spread: Bacilli free or carried by macrophages pass along ymphatics to regional lymph nodes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood spread: Occurs when caseous focus breaks through the wall of blood vessel.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intracanalicular spread: Spread through the lumen of natural tubes e.g. spread through the bronchi or the ureter.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunity-and-hypersensitivity-in-tuberculosis">Immunity and Hypersensitivity in Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunity-and-hypersensitivity-in-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When the infection by tubercle bacilli occurs, tuberculoprotein is released and stimulates the body to produce both immunity and hypersensitivity.</p>
<p>Immunity: Is the ability of the body to overcome the infection by pathogenic bacteria. It occurs after exposure (sensitization). The reaction is beneficial as it localizes and destroys the antigen without disease production. If the bacilli overcome the immunity, it will multiply resulting in progression from tuberculous infection to tuberculous disease.</p>
<p>Hypersensitivity: Is the change in reaction following re-exposure to the same antigen. When an antigen enters the body for the first time no harmful effect occurs. If the same antigen is reintroduced into the body, cellular damage with sever inflammatory reaction occurs called hypersensitivity. In tuberculous infection a delayed type of hypersensitivity (cell mediated immune reaction) develops within 10 days of first infection with tubercle bacilli. Hypersensitivity decrease with time. It is detected by tuberculin test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cell-mediated-delayed-br-hypersensitivity-reaction-in-tuberculosis">Cell Mediated (Delayed) &lt;br&gt; Hypersensitivity Reaction in Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-mediated-delayed-br-hypersensitivity-reaction-in-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is an exaggerated cell mediated immune response that damages the host cells. The main cell involved is the activated T-Lymphocyte T helper 1 cell (Th1 ).Antibody and histamine play no role in this type. The response is delayed, it starts hours or days after contact with the antigen.</p>
<p>The Th1 cell recognize the antigen and release the cytokines (lymphokines) that result in the accumulation of large number of activated macrophages and tubercle formation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites-of-secondary-tuberculous-lesions">Sites of Secondary Tuberculous Lesions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites-of-secondary-tuberculous-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Primary sites of infection can develop secondary lesions after reinfection or reactivation of the primary lesion.</li>
<li>Other organs of the body can develop secondary tuberculous infection through:
a) Direct extension of infection from primary lesion.
b) Blood borne infection.
E.g.: Pleura, peritoneum, pericardium, heart, lymph nodes, brain, bones, kidney, bladder, etc....</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulmonary-tuberculosis-br-i-primary-pulmonary-tuberculosis-figs-3-4">Pulmonary Tuberculosis &lt;br&gt; I) Primary Pulmonary Tuberculosis (Figs. 3&amp;4)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-tuberculosis-br-i-primary-pulmonary-tuberculosis-figs-3-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Primary pulmonary tuberculosis follows the first infection of the lung with tubercle bacilli by inhalation, usually in young age "childhood type". Three lesions develop: "primary pulmonary complex".</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Ghon's focus: A small caseous focus develops underneath the pleura in the base of upper lobe or apex of lower lobe. Microscopically the lesion consists of tubercles showing caseation. (describe)</li>
<li>Tuberculous lymphangitis: A chain of tubercles develop in walls of draining lymphatics.</li>
<li>Tuberculous lymphadenitis: The tracheobronchial lymph nodes are enlarged and caseous. They are larger in size than the Ghons focus, by the time the infection reaches the draining lymph nodes, the cell mediated immunity ( CMI ) had developed (within a period of about 10 days) this feature is present in primary infections in other sites.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-primary-complex">Fate of Primary Complex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-primary-complex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) Healing: Majority of patients do not develop signs or symptoms. The lesions heal by fibrosis or become encapsulated with or without calcification.
II) Spread (post 1ry complications): Occurs in a minority of cases with low body resistance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-direct-spread">1) Direct spread:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-direct-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Direct spread of Gohn's focus in the lung tissue causing tuberculous pneumonia.
b) Direct spread of Gohn's focus to the pleura causing tuberculous pleurisy.</p>
<p>The reaction is of the exudative type. Serous exudate collects in the sac and scanty fibrin deposits on the pleural surfaces. Healing occurs by organization forming adhesions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-blood-spread">2) Blood spread:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-blood-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Small number of bacilli: Removed by cells of reticulo-endothelial system.
b) Moderate number of bacilli: Settle in one of the favorable sites as brain, meninges, bone or kidney and form tuberculous lesions. Such lesions may be arrested or progress causing isolated organ tuberculosis.</p>
<p>c) Large number of bacilli: Usually results from opening of a caseous focus through large vessel. The bacilli spread with blood to large number of organs forming small uniform tuberculous lesions about 1-2 millimeters .The condition is known as miliary tuberculosis. It is rapidly fatal.
3) Bronchial spread: Gohn's focus or nodal lesion open in a bronchus and the caseous material is aspirated into the adjacent lung tissue causing tuberculous bronchopneumonia.
III) Encapsulation and reactivation: The lung and nodal lesion get capsulated, but with lowering of body resistance the lesion gets reactivated and spread. The spread is either direct, through bronchi or blood spread.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-1326fee9.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 3 - Primary pulmonary tuberculosis in upper lobe progressed to tuberculous pneumonia in middle and lower lobes.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-ac24643c.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 4 - Primary pulmonary tuberculosis in upper lobe progressed to tuberculous pleurisy with effusion.</p>
<p>Second infection of the lung after recovery from primary one, commonly occurs in adult (adult type)</p>
<p>The second infection may be:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Exogenous: Inhalation of human bacilli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endogenous: Reactivated primary lesion.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The post-primary lesion starts always at the apex of the lung (less blood supply and more aeration). The course of the disease depends on the dose of the bacilli and the state of immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="course">Course:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Regression: Occurs with small number of bacilli and high immunity. Heals by fibrosis forming apical scar.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-progresion">2. Progresion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-progresion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Moderate number of bacilli and moderate immunity causes chronic fibrocaseous pulmonary tuberculosis.
b) Large number of bacilli and low immunity causes tuberculous bronchopneumonia and acute caseous tuberculous pneumonia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-chronic-fibro-caseous-pulmonary-tuberculosis-fig-5">1. Chronic Fibro-caseous Pulmonary Tuberculosis (Fig.5)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-chronic-fibro-caseous-pulmonary-tuberculosis-fig-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="this-is-characterized-by">This is characterized by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#this-is-characterized-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>A slow course which spreads over years.</li>
<li>Repeated attempts to check and encapsulate the lesion by fibrosis.</li>
<li>Lymph nodes lesions are insignificant in comparison to those of primary Pulmonary tuberculosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="macroscopic-picture">Macroscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#macroscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Apical Cavity: The apical lesion progresses forming an area of caseation surrounded by tuberculous granulation tissue and fibrosis. When caseation involves a bronchus, the caseous material is evacuated and a cavity is left. The cavity lining is at first yellow irregular and caseating but later it becomes smooth due to fibrosis.</li>
</ol>
<p>The blood vessels in the wall are thickened due to endarteritis. The bronchi and blood vessels are more resistant to caseation so they appear as cords or ridges in the wall. The fibrous wall of the cavity is progressively destroyed by caseation but it reforms again a little further out and in this way the cavity enlarges gradually.
2. Acinar lesions: Part of caseous material is aspirated in distal bronchioles leading to small caseating lesions of clover leaf shape (acinar lesion) mainly at the base of the lung.
3. Nodal lesion: Lymph nodes involvement is insignificant as the bacilli reaching the nodes inside the macrophages are few because of the presence of the migration inhibition factor (MIF).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Large areas of homogenous pink caseation surrounded by fibrous tissue. Recent tubercles are present. (describe tubercle)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Haemoptysis from tuberculous granulation tissue or eroded blood vessel</li>
<li>Spread of infection:
a. Blood causing isolated organ tuberculosis or miliary tuberculosis.
b. Direct to pericardium and mediastinum.
c. Direct to the pleura causing sero-fibrinous pleurisy or empyema.</li>
<li>Rupture cavity causing pneumothorax or pyopneumothorax.</li>
<li>Infected sputum causes infection of other lung, tonsils, larynx, or tongue</li>
<li>Swallowing of infected sputum causing intestinal tuberculosis.</li>
<li>Lung fibrosis and right sided heart failure.</li>
<li>Secondary amyloidosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="signs-and-symptoms">Signs and Symptoms:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-and-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Loss of weight, sweating and night fever due to toxemia.</li>
<li>Chest pain due to pleurisy and dyspnea due to pleural effusion.</li>
<li>Haemoptysis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-tuberculous-bronchopneumonia">2. Tuberculous Bronchopneumonia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-tuberculous-bronchopneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rare fatal condition develops as a complication of primary or secondary pulmonary tuberculosis. The lesion is caused by large dose of bacilli in a patient with high hypersensitivity and low immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The tuberculous lesion progress rapidly by direct extension or by bronchial aspiration.</li>
<li>Tracheobrobchial lymph nodes are caseous and enlarged.</li>
<li>The course is rapidly fatal with or without miliary tuberculosis.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-81b1a349.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></p>
<p>APICAL LESION TRACHEDBRONCH. NODES FREE
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-847d689f.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></p>
<p>APICAL CAVITY DISTAL BRONCHOPNEUMONIC LESIONS</p>
<p>Fig. 5 - Chronic fibrocaseous pulmonary tuberculosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications-of-pulmonary-tb">COMPLICATIONS OF PULMONARY TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-pulmonary-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chronic destruction + Healing (Chronic inflammation)</p>
<ol>
<li>Hemoptysis i.e. coughing of blood due to hemorrhage into bronchus</li>
<li>Alveolar or bronchial rupture into pleura---bronchopleural fistula or pneumothorax (air in pleural cavity)</li>
<li>Respiratory failure in diffuse caseous pneumonia or miliary TB</li>
<li>Right sided heart failure secondary to diffuse lung fibrosis, since this would elevate he pressure in the pulmonary artery producing corpulmonale (right sided heart failure 2 ry to lung disease)</li>
<li>2ry or systemic amyloidosis &amp; dystrophic calcification (see cell injury)</li>
<li>Bronchieclasis i.e. dilatation of bronchi</li>
<li>Apical fibrosis may produce Horner's syndrome due to affection of peripheral nerves and blood vessels of the region.</li>
<li>Spread</li>
</ol>
<p>Direct Lung: confluence of acinar lesions produces confluent pneumonia Pleura: 1ry effusion (no Caseation)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="caseous-empyema-br-dense-adhesions">Caseous empyema &lt;br&gt; Dense adhesions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caseous-empyema-br-dense-adhesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Spread to pericardium &amp; mediastinum leading to adhesive mediastinopericarditis
Transbronchial spread: Caseous material if aspirated. Producing TB bronchopneumonia in one or both lungs &amp; if swallowed in sputum it may lead to intestinal, tonsillar or laryngeal TB</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distant">Distant:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Generalized lymphadenopathy
Blood stream: Isolated organ TB or Miliary TB</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tuberculous-lesions-in-other-organs">Tuberculous Lesions in Other Organs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tuberculous-lesions-in-other-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-intestinal-tb-lesious-in-other-ovsams">1. INTESTINAL TB lesious in other ovsams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-intestinal-tb-lesious-in-other-ovsams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. 1ry complex:</p>
<ul>
<li>Small intestinal tubercle formation in Peyer's patches of terminal ileum. The tubercles coalesce forming 1 small nodule (granuloma) which may ulcerate on the mucosa resulting in a single tuberculous ulcer.</li>
<li>Lymphangitis: tiny tubercles along the course of the lymphatics.</li>
<li>Mesenteric draining lymph nodes are studded with multiple small tubercles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-primary-spread">Post primary spread:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-primary-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mesenteric lymph nodes are enlarged, undergo caseation and fuse, forming a yellowish amalgamated mass with central caseation (Tabes mesenterica).
Blood spread lesions of Miliary TB in intestine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secondary-intestinal-tb">Secondary intestinal TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-intestinal-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Small intestine is studded with multiple TB ulcers secondary to swallowing infected sputum or 2 ry to lymphatic or blood stream spread or reinfection with infected milk.</p>
<p>Gross:
Multiple, transverse ulcers (since spread occurs along lymphatics of Peyer's patches)
Edges: undermined i.e. hang over the defect in the underlying tissue since there is more submucosal destruction than mucosal.</p>
<p>Floor: yellow caseous material
Base: tuberculous granulation tissue</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-intestinal-tb">COMPLICATIONS OF INTESTINAL TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-intestinal-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhage: altered blood in stools (Melena)</li>
<li>Stenosis of lumen &amp; intestinal obstruction</li>
<li>Fistulae between adjacent intestinal loops</li>
<li>Ulcer perforation leading to TB peritonitis</li>
<li>Secondary amyloidosis 2ry</li>
<li>Spread: Direct to peritoneum (TB peritonitis) &amp; or pelvic organs Distant same as before</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-tonsillar-tb">2. TONSILLAR TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-tonsillar-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1ry TB primary tonsillar complex: granuloma in tonsil (describe) + lymphangitis + cervical lymphadenitis.</p>
<p>2ry Tonsillar TB from swallowing infected sputum or reinfection by contaminated milk.</p>
<p>Marked caseation of the tonsil, which may present with TB ulcer or a cold abscess containing, liquefied caseous material, which simulates pus. A cold abscess is not a true abscess since it is not hot, nor does it contain pus cells (dead PNL's).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications-of-tonsillar-tb">COMPLICATIONS OF TONSILLAR TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-tonsillar-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhage: blood tinged sputum</li>
<li>Dysphagia: inability to swallow due to obstruction</li>
<li>Cold abscess in cervical LN which may result in skin sinus formation</li>
<li>Secondary amyloidosis</li>
<li>Spread (see before local &amp; distant, blood &amp; lymphatic): Infected material if swallowed may produce intestinal TB &amp; if aspirated may produce pulmonary TB lesions.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-tuberculous-lymphadenopathy">3. Tuberculous lymphadenopathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-tuberculous-lymphadenopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1ry TB: as part of the primary complex only regional lymph nodes (hilar, cervical or mesenteric) are affected in the form of tiny tubercles which coalesce &amp; cause LN enlargement.</p>
<p>Post primary lymphatic spread results in generalized tuberculous lymphadenopathy. E.g. Tabes mesenterica: grossly: matted (fused) LN with extensive caseation.</p>
<p>Microscopically: a homogenous structureless (no ghosts of tissue or nuclear debris) pink area of granular caseation surrounded by epithelioid cells, some Langhan's giant cells &amp; an outer layer of lymphoid cells &amp; the LN capsule.</p>
<p>In <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mtext>nd&nbsp;</mtext></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">T</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{\text {nd }} \mathbf{T B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">nd&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">TB</span></span></span></span></span></span>, there is no <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">L</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{L N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">LN</span></span></span></span></span></span> enlargement: These reactions are due hypersensitivity. They will they become large only if the lymph nodes are the source of reactivation or they are draining diffuse caseous TB (the amount of destruction is more than the drainage ability or immunity is low) (gross &amp; microscopic see before)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">COMPLICATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cold abscess (cold since no hyperemia to cause heat- abscess since contents are yellow and liquefied by -enzymes released in large areas of necrosis Le. similar to pus) Sinus draining on the skin Spread (direct, lymphatic &amp; blood).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-tb-of-skin">4. TB OF SKIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-tb-of-skin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1ry TB: rare usually in laboratory workers handling infected material
1ry complex: skin tubercles form a skin nodule + lymphangitis + regional (axillary lymphadenitis)
2ry TB skin also called Lupus vulgaris
Consists of a nodule, which may ulcerate producing a tuberculous skin ulcer. This condition is precancerous and may cause squamous cell carcinoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tb-in-any-other-site-other-than-1-5-lis-secondary-tb">TB in ANY OTHER SITE (OTHER THAN 1-5 lis secondary TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tb-in-any-other-site-other-than-1-5-lis-secondary-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-genito-urinary-tb">5. GENITO-URINARY TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-genito-urinary-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source of infection: direct, Transcanalicular or blood stream spread</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-tuberculosis">RENAL TUBERCULOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lesions (2ry TB) &amp; Post 1ry or complicated 2ry TB</p>
<ol>
<li>Fibrocaseous or fibro-cavitary renal TB (similar to fibrocaseous lesion of lung)</li>
<li>Diffuse caseation of kidney tissue</li>
<li>TB pyonephrosis: direct spread of caseation from kidney tissue to pelvicalyceal system &amp; ureter, which becomes stenotic causing proximal dilatation. The pelvicalyceal system and part of ureter above obstruction becomes swollen and transformed into a sac full of caseous material.</li>
<li>Tuberculoma of kidney as a part of isolated organ TB resulting from blood spread</li>
<li>Miliary TB from blood spread (describe)</li>
<li>Kidney fibrosis (fibrotic type) resulting in shrunken kidney</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-renal-tb">Complications of renal TB:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-renal-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhage into pelvicalyceal system producing hematuria (blood in urine)</li>
<li>Organ damage and fibrosis resulting in chronic renal failure &amp; 2ry hypertension</li>
<li>Spread: Direct mostly transcanalicular, through ureters to urinary bladder Distant blood stream: isolated organ TB or Miliary TB</li>
<li>Complications of chronic tissue damage e.g. 2ry amyloidosis etc ... (see before) &amp; complications of healing by fibrosis as urinary tract obstruction due to stenosis (TB pyonephrosis) &amp; vesico-rectal or vesico-vaginal fistulae.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="urinary-bladder-ub">URINARY BLADDER (UB)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-bladder-ub" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Same source as kidneys but mostly direct spread from renal TB (descending infection)
Lesion: Fibrosis
TB ulcers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1-Hemorrhage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> Hematuria
2-Fibrosis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> Contracted UB
3-Spread of infection:
a) blood spread
b) ascending spread to kidneys through ureters</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epididymis-testis">EPIDIDYMIS &amp; TESTIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epididymis-testis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source: blood spread
Lesion: Fibrotic lesion, fibrocaseous or caseous types
Caseous necrosis of epididymis produces a sinus on posterior aspect of scrotum</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhage hemospermia (blood in seminal fluid)</li>
<li>Fibrosis results in Infertility (obstruction to the flow of semen)</li>
<li>Spread: a) direct to testis- extensive caseation with liquefaction producing: testicular cold abscess and scrotal sinus formation b) blood spread</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fallopian-tubes">FALLOPIAN TUBES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fallopian-tubes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source mostly blood stream affecting both tubes
Lesion: TB pyosalpinx: tubes get obstructed with dilatation proximal to obstruction and both tubes become sacs full of caseous material</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Fibrosis leads to Infertility</li>
<li>Spread: Direct to peritoneum through tubal fimbria, endometrium &amp; cervix Blood.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-bones-joints">6. BONES &amp; JOINTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-bones-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="joints">JOINTS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source: Direct from bone
Blood spread</p>
<p>Lesion: commonly occurs in knee joints or hip joints in the form of:</p>
<ul>
<li>joint effusion rich in lymphocytes.</li>
<li>Fragmented joint cartilage.</li>
<li>Fibrous adhesions in synovial membranes resulting in joint ankylosis and difficulty in movement i.e. loss of function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Complications: Fibrosis of joint with loss of function due to adhesions (Ankylosis)
Spread: Direct to ligaments causing their destruction
Blood spread
Cold abscess and sinus formation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bones">BONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Source: blood spread to long bones or vertebrae (Pott's disease of vertebral column)</p>
<ul>
<li>POTT'S disease of vertebrae: comprises a triad of Kyphosis, cold abscess &amp; paraplegia). Caseation of vertebrae (especially lower thoracic &amp;upper lumbar, followed by cervical) &amp;the intervening discs causes vertebral collapse &amp; deformity (kyphosis)</li>
</ul>
<p>Cold abscess: caseous material collects under the vertebral ligament &amp; is squeezed into different places according to site of accumulation a) TB of thoracic vertebrae: abscess in posterior mediastinum b) Lumbar vertebrae: caseous material reaches the sheath of the psoas muscle &amp; appears in femoral triangle (Psoas cold abscess) c) Cervical vertebrae: caseous material reaches retropharyngeal area &amp; appears at posterior border of sternomastoid. Pressure of caseous material on peripheral nerves &amp; on spinal cord producing paraplegia (paralysis lower limbs) this is accentuated by the associated endarteritis obliterans (little blood supply to area) &amp; easy fracture of the bones, also causing damage to nerves.</p>
<ul>
<li>Long bones (tuberculous osteomyelitis) bones undergo caseation and pathological fracture is common. Direct spread to the adjacent joint is also common. Such fractures undergo faulty union e.g. fibrosis or weak union.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-tb-peritonitis">7. TB PERITONITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-tb-peritonitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source: Direct from genitourinary tract or caseous mesenteric lymph nodes Blood spread &amp; lymphatic spread from generalized lymphadenopathy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types">Types:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Serous or wet type associated with peritoneal small tubercles and minimal adhesions.</p>
<p>b) Adhesive or dry type. The excess fibrosis causes omentum to roll on its self (frozen abdomen) causing intestinal obstruction or intestinal fistulae. Peritoneal fluid is caseous.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8-tb-of-cns">8. TB OF CNS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-tb-of-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Source: blood stream
Lesions: Tuberculoma = caseous necrotic mass in brain surrounded by gliosis
TB MENINGITIS= TUBERCLES ON MENINGES + MUCH EXUDATE rich in lymphocytes &amp; fibrin but poor in epithelioid cells &amp; Langhan's giant cells. CSF is under high pressure. The pia &amp; arachnoid mater are mainly affected as well as the lining of the ventricles.</p>
<p>Manifestations: Local:gross &amp; microscopic picture of lesions
General: e.g. fever &amp; blood changes i.e. clinical picture</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="progress-fate">Progress &amp; fate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#progress-fate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Recovery &amp; healing</li>
<li>Persistence of organism: Acute changes to chronic (chronicity</li>
<li>Complications:
a. Tissue damage &amp; necrosis with loss of function of organ.
b. Spread (no localization)</li>
</ol>
<p>Direct (local spread) Distant -Bloodstream
c. Complications of healing by fibrous tissue according to site</p>
<ol>
<li>Fibrosis with cranial nerve paralysis due to compression</li>
<li>Hydrocephalous due to obstruction of CSF flow</li>
<li>Spread mostly direct producing encephalitis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-tb-summary">1) TB SUMMARY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-tb-summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1ry-tb-complex">1RY TB COMPLEX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1ry-tb-complex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proliferative lesion (granuloma) with minimal exudative reaction (late in the disease with onset of hypersensitivity)</li>
<li>Lymphangitis</li>
<li>Regional lymphadenitis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2ry-tb">2RY TB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2ry-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Exudative (hypersensitivity reaction) characterized by caseous necrosis (no lymph node enlargement)</li>
<li>Minimal proliferative reaction</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="post-1ry-spread-or-complicated-2ry">POST 1RY spread or COMPLICATED 2RY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-1ry-spread-or-complicated-2ry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Proliferative &amp; exudative reaction with generalized lymphadenopathy (enlargement) LESIONS</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">PROLIFERATIVE</th><th style="text-align: center;">EXUDATIVE</th><th style="text-align: center;">FIBROTIC</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Granuloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Caseation or lymphocyte rich effusion.</td><td style="text-align: center;">FT/scar</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">C.inflam + immune reaction. (late)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Hypersensitivity reaction (harmful immune reaction)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Healing</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1ry -post 1ry complications</td><td style="text-align: center;">2ry - post 1ry complications</td><td style="text-align: center;">1ry &amp; 2ry</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Activated lymphocytes &amp; epithelioid cells.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Necrotic cheesy caseation</td><td style="text-align: center;">White -firm tissue that shrinks</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1. Tubercles e.g.: &lt;br&gt; - Multiple Miliary TB &lt;br&gt; - Single Gohn's focus &lt;br&gt; 2. Tuberculoma (isolated organ TB) 1-5 cm formed of fused tubercles with central caseation.</td><td style="text-align: center;">1-TB pneumonia &lt;br&gt; 2-Serous effusions &lt;br&gt; 3-Cold abscess &lt;br&gt; 4-Caseous empyema &lt;br&gt; 5-Pott's disease</td><td style="text-align: center;">1ry-healed Gohn's &lt;br&gt; 2ry -apical fibrosis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-syphylis">2) SYPHYLIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-syphylis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: infective granuloma caused by Treponema pallidum. It is one of the venereal diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-infection">Mode of infection:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Direct method: during sexual contact. Bacteria can penetrate intact skin or mucous membranes.</p>
<p>Congenital method: bacteria can cross the placenta from the mother to her fetus.
It is important to mention that once the bacteria enter the body, they pass to the lymph vessels then lymph nodes and finally the blood stream before the development of any lesion at site of entry.</p>
<p>Tissue reaction: syphilitic granulation tissue [SGT] formed of dense perivascular infiltrate of plasma cells, lymphocytes and few giant cells. Characteristically there is prominent end arteritis obliterans while the reaction is still early and cellular [in other inflammations, end arteritis obliterans appear late when the reaction is fibrous].</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lesions-or-stages">Lesions or Stages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lesions-or-stages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="primary-stage-hard-chancre">Primary Stage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> Hard Chancre:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-stage-hard-chancre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Appears 2 weeks after infection at site of entry of bacteria.</li>
<li>Site may be genital or extragenital [fingers, lip, tongue].</li>
<li>Grossly: single raised red papule which ulcerates after few days. The ulcer is rounded, superficial and has flat edgeshclean floor firm margin and firm base. The ulcer is painless &amp; very infective. It heals by thin atrop ic scar. The draining lymph nodes appear enlarged, separate, mobile and painless [lymphadenitis].</li>
<li>Microscopic: the covering epithelium is absent. The subepithelial tissues show syphilitic granulation tissue. The lymph nodes show reactive hyperplasia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secondary-stage">Secondary Stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Appears 2 months after the primary stage.</li>
<li>Affects mainly tissues of ectodermal origin.</li>
<li>Lesions are also very infective and are accompanied by fever, headache, weakness and joint pains.</li>
<li>Skin rash: painless rash formed of macules, papules and pustules all over the body. Micro: the usual SGT.</li>
<li>Condyloma lata (warts): bulky skin papules at areas of moist skin as axilla and under the breast.
Micro: the usual SGT with hyperplastic covering epithelium.</li>
<li>Scaly desquamation of palms and soles, leucoderma and alopecia</li>
<li>Mucous patches: lesions similar to skin rash on mucous membranes of mouth, pharynx, vagina, anus. They may ulcerate → snail track</li>
<li>Generalized lymphadenitis: especially epitrochlear &amp; posterior cervical.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tertiary-stage">Tertiary Stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tertiary-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Appears 2 years after the primary stage.</li>
<li>Gumma: localized area of syphilitic granulation tissue which under-goes slow caseous necrosis. It can affect any organ as liver, heart, brain, bones &amp; tongue. Gross: single or multiple, small or large mass with yellow center [necrosis] &amp; gray periphery [fibrosIs]. Microscopic: three zones: central zone of necrOSIS, ouetr zone of fibrosIs and mid zone of sypnilitic granulation tissue formed of. Fate: gumma in solid organs heals by fibrosis. Gumma on surface epithelia [tongue] ulcerates resulting in gummatous ulcer with sharp edges and necrotic floor, it has a punched out appearance &amp; is pre-cancerous.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-gumma">Examples of gumma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-gumma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>In the liver: multiple foci of necrosis surrounded by radiating fibrotic scars causing lobulation of the surface (Hepar lobatum).</li>
<li>In the heart: gumma of the septum leading to heart block.</li>
<li>In the testis: testicular enlargement followed by fibrosis.</li>
<li>In the skull: worm eaten appearance of skull bones.</li>
<li>Perforated palate and saddle nose.</li>
<li>In the tongue: gummatous ulcer.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Diffuse syphilitic inflammation: there is diffuse infiltration by syphilitic granulation tissue with minimal necrOSIS, It leads to diffuse fibrous thickening ofthe affectea organ. It is more common and develops very slowly.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="congenital-syphilis">Congenital Syphilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-syphilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The untreated mother can transmit syphilis to her fetus especially after the 4th month of pregnancy [after disappearance of Langhan's layer of placenta]. Abortion may result, the infant may die soon after birth or the baby may survive and syphilitic lesions appear early or late in life. The placenta is large, heavy and firm. It shows SGT &amp; many microorganisms.</p>
<p>Early Manifestations: develop during the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text {st }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> two years of life.</p>
<ul>
<li>Skin rash: painless rash formed of macules, papules and pustules all over the body. Micro: the usual syphilitic reaction.</li>
<li>Condyloma lata: bulky skin papules at areas of moist skin as axilla and under the breast. Micro: the usual SGT with hyperplastic covering epithelium.</li>
<li>Scaly desquamation of palms and soles, leucoderma and alopecia.</li>
<li>Mucous patches: lesions similar to skin rash on mucous membranes of mouth, pharynx, vagina &amp; anus. They may ulcerate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> snail track.</li>
<li>Rhagades: radiating scars at angles of mouth &amp; anus.</li>
<li>Saddle nose: caused by gumma of the nasal septum.</li>
<li>Syphilitic osteomyelitis: involving epiphyseal lines <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> retardation of growth.</li>
<li>Syphilitic inflammation of internal organs as liver <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> cirrhosis and lung <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> pneumonia.</li>
</ul>
<p>Late Manifestations: develop within 2-30 years after birth.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Gumma of bones [gummatous osteitis): skull, nose saddle nose and hard palate (perforate palate).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diffuse syphilitic periostitis: Produces a square shaped skull &amp; saber tibia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Effusions in big joints.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hutchinson teeth: the permanent central incisors are small, peg-shaped, widely separated and notched.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iritis, keratitis, retinitis results in blindness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>8</mn><mtext>th&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">8^{\text {th }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> cranial nerve affection causes deafness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>C.N.S. affection results in general paralysis of insane.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-rhinoscleroma">3) RHINOSCLEROMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-rhinoscleroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Granulomatous inflammation of the nose (other sites: laryngeal scleroma, pharyngeal scleroma) caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis bacteria which is endemic in Egypt &amp; which multiplies in the macrophages producing a foamy appearance (Mickulicz cells).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology-plate-7">Morphology: plate (7)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-plate-7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gross: Rhinoscleroma usually affects the nasal cavity by forming a bulky grey, firm mass. Lesions associated with Rhinoscleroma may also affect the larynx; nasopharynx; oral cavity; paranasal sinuses; or soft tissues of the lips, nose, trachea, and bronchi..</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">Microscopic<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Microscopically, the most conspicuous feature is the presence of histiocytic granulomas, with fibrosis and an abundant infiltrate of lymphocytes and plasma cells.</li>
<li>The mucosal surfaces display variable changes, ranging from squamous metaplasia to extreme pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia.</li>
<li>Large vacuolated, "foamy" histiocytes, known as Mikulicz cells (arrow) are characteristic of rhinoscleroma and are most numerous in the nodular stage as well as Russel bodies (arrow head) which are plasma cells distended with glassy pink flyaline appearing material( immunoglobulins).</li>
<li>Klebsiella organisms are seen within cells and in extracellular locations.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-04dffbac.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>A
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-91586369.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg"></p>
<p>Plate (7)</p>
<p>B</p>
