<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-leprosy">4)LEPROSY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-leprosy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: Infective granuloma caused by Mycobacterium leprae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="etiology-pathogenesis">Etiology &amp; pathogenesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Organism: Mycobacterium leprae
Acid-alcohol fast bacillus
Source: prolonged close contact 5-10 yrs
Site: skin and nerves</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manifestations-according-to-type">Manifestations according to type<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations-according-to-type" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">1) Tuberculoid (mild) &lt;br&gt; Macula-anaesthetic leprosy &lt;br&gt; Good immunity</th><th style="text-align: center;">2) Lepromatous (severe) &lt;br&gt; Nodular leprosy-leonine facies &lt;br&gt; Low immunity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Gross &lt;br&gt; Macules (flat hypopigmented patches) &lt;br&gt; + nerve Inflammation (thickening)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Nodules or erythematous macules &lt;br&gt; + nerve Inflammation (Thick, cord-like)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Microscopic &lt;br&gt; Granuloma (leproma) + few organisms</td><td style="text-align: center;">Granuloma + many organisms</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Lymphocytes + plasma cells + foamy macrophages (clear cells or foam cells) called lepra cells</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">CP: &lt;br&gt; loss of sensation &amp; sweating &lt;br&gt; Trophic changes (ulcers) &lt;br&gt; Deformities and loss of parts of limbs &lt;br&gt; (due to loss of sensation &amp; low blood supply)</td><td style="text-align: center;">leonine facial disfigurement &lt;br&gt; Severe trophic changes &lt;br&gt; Deformities and loss of parts limbs &lt;br&gt; Loss of sensation</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Macule: nat area of discoloration of skin
Papule: slightly raised area
Nodule: raised mass
Polyp (wide CT core) I papilloma (thin CT core): finger like ro"ection from surface</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-actinomycosis">5) ACTINOMYCOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-actinomycosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: infective granuloma caused by Actinomyces israeli. It is an anaerobic gram +ve bacteria. The organism is commensal in the mouth, carious teeth and intestine. Infection can be endogenous especially when the body immunity is lowered.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gross: multiple intercommunicating abscesses opening to the surface by multiple sinuses discharging pus and yellow bacterial colonies [known as sulphur granules].</p>
<p>Microscopic: each abscess is formed of three zones: [Fig. 6]</p>
<ol>
<li>Central zone of pus containing rounded or oval bacterial colonies formed of thinfilaments surrounded by club-like swellings.</li>
<li>Mid zone of inflammatory cells including polymorphs, pus cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages and giant cells.</li>
<li>Outer zone of fibrosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-20ec29af.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-actinomycosis-are">Types of Actinomycosis are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-actinomycosis-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Cervicofacial Actinomycosis [60%]:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Affects the region of angle of mandible and adjacent parts of neck and face.</li>
<li>Micro-organism enter through buccal mucosa after minor trauma.</li>
<li>Gross and micro: describe.</li>
<li>Blood spread may occur. No lymphatic spread because of the large size of the filaments.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Intestinal Actinomycosis [20%].</li>
<li>Pulmonary Actinomycosis [15%].</li>
<li>Skin Actinomycosis [5%].</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="summaryof-bacterial-infections">SUMMARYOF BACTERIAL INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summaryof-bacterial-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>ACUTE inflammation
a. Suppurative
b. Non- suppurative</p>
<p>CHRONIC inflammation
a. Non -specific
b. Specific (granuloma)
c. Infl. + Immune reaction
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-b348f4aa.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></p>
<p>Any infectious disease whether acute or chronic should be described in the following manner:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="etiology-pathogenesis">Etiology &amp; pathogenesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#etiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Organism &amp; its description</li>
<li>Route of infection</li>
<li>Site of lesions</li>
<li>Mechanism of lesion production</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Basic reactions.</td><td style="text-align: left;">ALL</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Bacterial infections.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Toxemia-bacteremia-septicimia-pyemia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">T8</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Leprosy</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Syphilis.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Actinomycosis.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Rhinoscleroma.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viral-diseases">VIRAL DISEASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viral-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Viruses are the smallest known infective agents. All viruses depend on host cell metabolism for their replication, they are obligate intracellular parasites. Viruses vary greatly in size from 20-300 nm. Viruses are either spherical or cylindrical in shape. A single virus particle, called virion is made up of a core consisting of a single molecule of nucleic acid either DNA or RNA and a surrounding protein shell called a capsid. Diseases caused by viruses are either:</p>
<ol>
<li>Acute illness: e.g. common cold and influenza.</li>
<li>Lifelong latency and long-term reactivation: e.g. herpes viruses.</li>
<li>Chronic disease: e.g. HBV, HCV and HIV.</li>
<li>Neoplasia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-infection">Mode of Infection:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Inhalation: e.g. Influenza and measles.</li>
<li>Ingestion: e.g. poliomyelitis and viral hepatitis.</li>
<li>Inoculation: e.g. trachoma.</li>
<li>Bite of a vector: e.g . yellow fever.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disease-spectrum-and-pathological-changes-associated-with-viral-infections">Disease spectrum and pathological changes associated with viral infections:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disease-spectrum-and-pathological-changes-associated-with-viral-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several possible consequences to a cell that is infected by a virus, and ultimately this may determine the pathology of a disease caused by the virus.</p>
<ol>
<li>host Lytic infections result in the destruction of the.</li>
<li>Abortive infection: in which the virus couldn't complete its replication, due to lack of essential factors needed for replication or due to action of host immune mechanisms.</li>
<li>Persistent infections: Symptoms and signs remain over relatively long periods of time due to slow viral release.</li>
<li>Latent infections: there is a delay between the infection by the virus and the appearance of symptoms. Fever blisters (cold sores) caused by herpes simplex type 1 result from a latent infection; they appear sporadically as the virus emerges from latency, usually triggered by some sort of stress in the host.</li>
<li>Transformation: Some viruses have the potential to change a cell from a normal cell into a tumor cell. These viruses are referred to as oncogenic viruses.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-changes">Pathological Changes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Cellular changes: include:
a) Cellular proliferation as in warts.
b) Cellular degeneration and necrosis as in poliomyelitis and viral hepatitis.</li>
</ol>
<p>c) Appearance of inclusion bodies as in rabies and smallpox.
2) Inflammatory cellular exudate: Mainly perivascular and consists lymphocytes and macrophages.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acquired-immuno-deficiency-syndrome-aids">Acquired Immuno-Deficiency Syndrome: AIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-immuno-deficiency-syndrome-aids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The causative organism is the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) which is a retrovirus (RNA virus containing the enzyme reverse transcriptase), 2 types are known: HIV-1 &amp; HIV-2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transmission-of-the-virus-occurs-through">Transmission of the virus occurs through<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transmission-of-the-virus-occurs-through" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Sexual contact.</li>
<li>Parentral inoculation</li>
<li>From infected mothers to their newborns.</li>
</ol>
<p>The persons at high risk for developing AIDS are Promiscuous homosexuals, intravenous drug abusers, hemophiliacs, blood recipients and sexual partners or children of any individual with the disease. Only small numbers of cases have been free from all risk factors._N.B. The virus may produce asymptomatic infection for many years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">Mechanism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lymphopenia: mainly due to selective loss of CD4 + helper T-cell together with impairment in the function of the surviving helperT cells. The total leucocytic count is low (less than 2000) and the CD4 + T cell count is below 200. The CD4/CD8 ratio is inverted, normally it is 2 while in AIDS it is 0.5 .</li>
<li>Decreased and altered T cell functions: increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections and malignant neoplasms.</li>
<li>Decreased delayed tyge hapersensitivity, decreased proliferative response to antigens, decreased specIfic c OtOXIClty &amp; ecreased production of IL-2 &amp;IL-8.</li>
<li>Polyclonal B cell activation: hypergammaglobulinemia and inability to mount de novo antibody response to new antigens.</li>
<li>Altered Monocyte/Macrophage functions: decreased chemotaxis and phagocytosis.</li>
</ol>
<p>The phases of HIV infection and their corresponding clinical features</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Early acute (Unitial) phase (group I) Self limiting acute illness (acute infection) consisting of non specific symptoms such as: sore throat, muscle pain, fever and skin rash. There is high level of virus replication with antiviral response.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Middle ( Latent ichronic phase (group II) .There is low level of HIV replication which may last for several years. Patients may be asymptomatic (group II) or develop persistent generalized lymphadenopathy. Most if not all patients with HIV infection will progress to AIDS after a chronic phase lasting from 7 to 10 years.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Final crisis (opportunistic infection &amp; tumours) phase (group III): There is breakdown of host defense with recrudescence of viral replication, this phase comprises.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-opportunistic-infections-such-as">A. opportunistic infections such as<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-opportunistic-infections-such-as" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Protozoal and Helminthic infections: toxoplasmosis, - strongyloidosis, pneumocystosis.</li>
<li>Fungal infections: candidiasis, histoplasmosis and cryptococcosis.</li>
<li>Bacterial infections: tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteriosis, salmonella and shigella infections.</li>
<li>Viral infections: cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus and Varicella - Zoster virus.
B. Malignant neoplasms, such as non Hodgkin's lymphoma, Burkitt's lymphoma and Kaposi's sarcoma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epstein-barr-virus">Epstein-Barr virus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epstein-barr-virus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Epstein- Barr Virus (EBV) is a herpes virus and is the causative agent of Burkitt's lymphoma in Africa, nasopharyngeal cancer in the orient and infectious mononucleosis.</p>
<p>Mode of transmission: The virus is spread by close contact (kissing). The virus can also be spread by blood transfusion.</p>
<p>Pathogenesis: EBV only infects a small number of cell types that express the receptor for complement C3d component (CR2 or CD21). These are certain epithelial cells (oro &amp; naso-pharynx) and B lymphocytes. This explains the cellular tropism of the virus. The virus is replicated in pharyngeal epithelial cells, shed into the saliva and is taken up by B lymphocytes. As a result of EBV infection, these lymphocytes become stimulated to divide and are protected from undergoing apoptosis (cell death). They become transformed cells and they begin to appear in high levels in the bloodstream.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-caused-by-ebv">Diseases caused by EBV:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-caused-by-ebv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Infectious mononucleosis: This disease is characterized by non specific symptoms and signs, including malaise, generalized lymphadenopathy, tonsillitis, enlarged spleen and liver, and fever. The disease usually runs a benign course.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Burkitt's lymphoma: A type of malignant tumor of B lymphocytes, affecting jaw and face of young children. Tumor cells show evidence of EBV DNA.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nasopharyngeal cancer: The disease is a malignant tumor of the epithelium of the upper respiratory tract and the tumor cells contain EBV DNA.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The association between EBV and a number of other tumors has only come to light in more recent years, indicating that the oncogenic effects of the viruses may be evident when infecting other cell types. The best known of these examples is Hodgkin's disease, which another type of malignant lymphoma.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="human-papilloma-virus">Human Papilloma virus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#human-papilloma-virus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: Human papilloma virusHPV) is a family of over 100 viruses including those which cause) warts and are transmitted by contact. Some types of HPV are associated with tumors of the genital .tract including cancer of the cervix</p>
<p>Types of HPVs: The strains of HPV may be divided into two major groups</p>
<ol>
<li>Low-risk groups: these are the strains which produce raised warts, namely HPV<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6 \&amp;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">6&amp;</span></span></span></span></span> HPV-11.</li>
<li>
<ol start="2">
<li>High-risk groups are more likely to lead to the development of cancer. These high-risk types cause growths that are usually flat and nearly invisible. Examples include HPV-16 8. HPV-18</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-caused-by-hpv">Diseases caused by HPV:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-caused-by-hpv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Common warts: The majority of HPVs produce warts on the hands, fingers, and even the face. Most of these viruses are thus innocuous, causing nothing more than cosmetic concerns.</li>
<li>Genital warts (Condylomata acuminatum), sexually transmitted, and most commonly caused by two HPV strains, HPV-6 and HPV-11.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytomegalic-inclusion-disease-cid">Cytomegalic Inclusion Disease (CID)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytomegalic-inclusion-disease-cid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The modes of transmission of the cytomegalovirus include
A. Intra-uterine transplacental transmission. from newly infected or asymptomatic mother to her fetus leading to</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abortion, stillbirth or premature baby.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Severe multisystem disease in the form of anemia, purpura, thrombocytopenia jaundice, hepato-splenomegaly, pneumonia, hepatitis, encephalitis and mental retardation. Most of these patients die.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mild multisystem disease in the form of pneumonitis, hepatitis and encephalitis. Most of these patients recover but many may develop mental retardation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Asymptomatic infection, but few patients may develop hearing defects or mental retardation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-acquired-transmission">B. Acquired transmission<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-acquired-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Respiratory droplet transmission .</li>
<li>Blood transfusions and organ transplantions.</li>
<li>Venereal transmission .</li>
<li>Transmission through mother's milk to her baby.</li>
</ul>
<p>The clinical picture ranged from an asymptomatic illness to serious multisystem affection in immunosuppressed persons. The manifestations include pneumonitis, hepatitis, enterocolitis, and retinochoroiditis. eNS involvement in adults is rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Viral infections</td><td style="text-align: left;">Acquired Immuno-Deficiency Syndrome: AIDS &lt;br&gt; HPV &lt;br&gt; EBV &lt;br&gt; Cytomegalovirus</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathology-of-fungal-infection">PATHOLOGY OF FUNGAL INFECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-of-fungal-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fungi are microscopic plant single-celled or multicellular organism. They are not always pathogenic. Many fungi are saprophytes (living on dead organic matter). Fungi can be true pathogens that cause infections in healthy persons or they can be opportunistic pathogens that cause infections in immunocompromised persons. Others are used for the development of antibiotics, antitoxins, and other drugs used to control various human diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-caused-by-fungi">Diseases Caused by Fungi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-caused-by-fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fungal infections or mycoses can be classified depending on the degree of tissue involvement and mode of entry into the host. These are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Superficial &amp; cutaneous: localized to the skin, hair, nails&amp; mucosa. Examples include oral candidiasis (thrush), vaginal candidiasis, athlete's foot (tinea pedis), and diaper fungal infections of babies.</li>
<li>Subcutaneous infection: Are rare conditions, in which Infection may arise following the wounding of the skin and the introduction of soil saprophytes. The infection is chronic, localized, confined to the dermis, subcutaneous tissue or adjacent structures, leading to ulcerative lesion. Madura foot is an example of this type of affection.</li>
<li>Systemic Mycoses: These are invasive infections of the internal organs. They are uncommon in normally healthy persons. They may be caused by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Primary pathogenic fungi: These are fungal infections of the body caused by fungal pathogens which can overcome the physiological and cellular defenses of the normal human host by changing their morphological form. The primary site of infection is usually pulmonary. Infection by Histoplasma capsulatum (histoplasmosis) is an example of this type of affection.</li>
<li>Opportunistic fungi that are of marginal pathogenicity (non pathogenic or of low virulence) but can infect the immunocompromised host causing potentially fatal infections. Examples include systemic Candidiasis. In this condition candida albicans - which is part of the normal human flora - can proliferate and disseminate throughout the body of severely immunocompromized host.</li>
</ul>
<p>Pathogenesis of fungal infections: Fungi produce their pathological effects through the following mechanisms.
A. Surface factors that help in adherence to host tissue.
B. Enzymes which facilitate tissue invasion</p>
<p>Immunological response against fungi: immunological reaction against pathogenic fungi may be mediated By:</p>
<ol>
<li>Cell mediated immunity.</li>
<li>Humoral immunity against cell membrane antigens.</li>
</ol>
<p>Spectrum of inflammatory responses: Tissue reaction to pathogenic fungi may be extremely variable, depending on the type of invading fungus and the host immune response. we can find any of the following inflammatory responses.</p>
<ol>
<li>Acute and chronic suppurative inflammation.</li>
<li>Chronic inflammation with mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate.</li>
<li>Granulomatous inflammation.</li>
<li>Necrotizing inflammation.</li>
</ol>
<p>Any form of tissue reaction certainly may be associated with necrosis and scarring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="candida-albicans">Candida albicans<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#candida-albicans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Candida albicans (also called Monilia is the (most common fungal pathogens of mankind. These are normal inhabitants of oral cavity, GI tract, &amp; vagina. Fungi are yeast-like cell with pseudohyphae &amp; hyphae.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-99f259ae.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></p>
<p>Disease spectrum of Candida albicans: Depending on the immunological status of the host, Candida can cause superficial &amp; cutaneous affection in healthy individuals, and can cause systemic opportunistic affection in immunocompromised patients. The infection is endogenous as the organism is a commensal.</p>
<ol>
<li>Superficial &amp; cutaneous candidiasis: may occur in healthy individuals. The normal flora starts to invade mucosal surfaces and skin. Predisposing factors include pregnancy, with oral contaceptives, diabetes, and prolonged antibiotic intake.</li>
</ol>
<p>Sites: Oral candidiasis (thrush), vulvovaginal candidiasis, skin &amp; nail bed (paronychia) and esophagus &amp; intestine.</p>
<p>Gross: Mucosal surfaces showed superficial white friable patches composed of organisms and inflammatory debris. When detached, it leaves red inflamed surface and in severe cases there is surface ulceration.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-61e511cf.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig 7 Oral candidiasis</p>
<p>Microscopic: Ranges from acute diffuse neutrophilic infiltration with microabscesses within the epithelium, to chronic granulomatous inflammation. Fungal bodies, hyphae and spores may be detected by PAS stain.
2. Systemic Candidiasis: is a form of opportunistic infection, occurs in immunocompromised patients.</p>
<p>Sites: Urinary tract (kidney &amp; urinary bladder), GIT (oesophagus &amp; stomach), Heart, Lung, CNS</p>
<p>Gross: Wide spread necrotizing lesion within the affected organ.
Microscopic: Multiple microabscesses, in which the fungal colonies occupy the center of the lesion. They are surrounded by necrosis and neutrophilic infiltrate. Fungal bodies, hyphae and spores may be detected by PAS stain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mycetoma-madura-foot-nocardiasis">Mycetoma (Madura Foot/Nocardiasis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mycetoma-madura-foot-nocardiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: Madura foot or mycetoma (named because of the tumour-like mass it forms) is a chronic granulomatous infection involving the subcutaneous tissue and bone of feet and characterized by the formation of localized lesions with multiple draining sinuses. The exudates contains granules that may be yellow, white, red, brown, or black, depending upon the causative agent.</p>
<p>Aetiology: Mycetoma can be divided into two major categories according to the causative organism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causative-agent">Causative agent:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causative-agent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Eumycetoma: which is caused by true fungi, in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases, which represent a form of subcutaneous fungal infection.</li>
<li>Actinomycetoma: which is caused by filamentous bacteria, and represent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases.</li>
</ol>
<p>Both forms have similar gross and microscopic appearance.
Mode of infection: Organisms are normally present in environment (soil &amp; dust). Infection occurs in bare-footed persons after minor penetrating skin injury inoculating soil organisms, occurring preferentially in rural areas, usually among agricultural workers who work barefoot. The disease is endemic in the tropics and subtropics.</p>
<p>Risk factors: Mycetoma typically presents in agricultural workers (hands, shoulders and back - from carrying contaminated vegetation and other burdens), or in individuals who walk barefoot in dry, dusty conditions. Minor trauma allows pathogens from the soil to enter the skin.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c67298e2.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg"></p>
<p>Gross: Both forms of mycetoma present as a progressive, cutaneous and subcutaneous swelling. Multiple nodules develop which may suppurate and drain through multiple sinus tracts that usually discharge serosanguinous fluid and, at times, grossly visible granules of various colours depending on the agent involved.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-b1cfe78f.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<p>Microscopically: the dermis and subcutaneous tissue contain localized abscesses, each of which contains one or more granules in its centre. Eosinophilic, club like material may border the granules. Between abscesses, there is extensive formation of septic granulation tissue and scarring. Infection often involve contiguous bone, resulting in destructive osteomyelitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Fungal</td><td style="text-align: left;">Madura foot</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Candida</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Rest category C</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parasitic-infestations">PARASITIC INFESTATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parasitic-infestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parasitic-infestations">PARASITIC INFESTATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parasitic-infestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Bilharziasis or schistosomiasis</li>
<li>Hydatid disease</li>
<li>Amoebiasis (see special colon)</li>
<li>Malaria</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schistosomiasis-bilharziasis">SCHISTOSOMIASIS (Bilharziasis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schistosomiasis-bilharziasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DEFINITION: Parasitic allergic granulomatous disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni or hematobium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aetiology-pathogenesis">AETIOLOGY &amp; PATHOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Schistosoma mansoni affects GIT. Schistosoma hematobium affects urogenital tract.
Pathogenesis: The bilharzial lesions are allergic ( type I -type IV hypersensitivity) to antigens produced by cercaria, adult worms and ova.</p>
<ol>
<li>Cercaria: Skin penetration by cercaria in swimming water resulting in allergic dermatitis or bathers itch (acute allergic inflammation) itchy macules or papules rich in eosinophils, some PNLs, macrophages &amp; dilated congested blood vessels</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-adult-worms">2. Adult worms:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-adult-worms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Living: Adult worm lives in veins of GIT (S.mansoni) or urogenital system (S.haematobium)
B. Dead: Severe allergic inflammation to its antigens causes tissue necrosis and dense inflammation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-ova">3. Ova:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-ova" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Trapped eggs mature normally, secreting antigens that elicit a vigorous immune response.</li>
<li>The egg induced granuloma formation is a delayed Type Hypersensitivity reaction, and, although eventually resulting in severe pathology classically associated with schistosomiasis, appears to be a necessary protective host response against hepatotoxic components of Soluble Egg Antigen.</li>
<li>The granuloma that forms around the egg consists mainly of a number of different type of immune cells, including both T and B cells, macrophages, giant cells, epitheloid cells, mast cells, plasma cells, fibroblasts and eosinophils, with subsequent fibrosis and ova calcification.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-65bb1d92.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<p>Severe acute allergic inflammation in BV wall(thrombophlebitis) Necrosis + A.lnfl. rich in eosinophils</p>
<p>Mechanical irritation in submucosa (highly vascular)</p>
<p>Some trapped in submucosa
Forming granuloma</p>
<p>Released in lumen come out in urine or stools</p>
<p>Some carried by blood to liver or lungs (emboli) forming granulomas + REG hyperplasia
reticuloendothelial system hyperplasia
(lymphadenopathy
&amp;
splenomegaly)</p>
<p>Ova &amp; worms produce mechanical irritation at site resulting in bilharzial granulomas &amp; release antigens which stimulate the immune system types 1,11,111 &amp; IV hypersensitivity reactions with an associated enlargement of LN &amp; spleen which are organs of the reticuloendothelial syster (RES)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Granuloma</p>
<p>Early granulomas are cellular (many cells + GT &amp; Bilharzial granulation tissue
Later <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>
Very late <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>
fibrocellular(cells + FT)
fibrotic or healed (FT or scar tissue)</p>
<p>B. Generalized lymphadenopathy &amp; splenomegaly: antigenic stimulation of REG in LN &amp; spleen result in their proliferation (hyperplasia) with increase in the size of these organs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="granuloma-basic-reaction-br-plate-6">Granuloma basic reaction (BR): (plate 6)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#granuloma-basic-reaction-br-plate-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Central zone contains ovum (oval structures) with a refractile shell. Ova may contain a living miracidium which is pink &amp; nucleated or a dead miracidium which is pink but with no nuclei. Dead ova in long standing infestations become dystrophicaly calcified &amp; appear blue (H&amp;E stain).</li>
<li>Ova are surrounded by many eosinophils, macrophages, lymphocytes, plasma cells, PNLs &amp; giant cells (this is a mixture of 4 different hypersensitivity reactions).
C. EPITHELIAL or mucosal changes (basic reaction)
N.B.: ova are deposited in the most vascular parts as submucosa, but may also be deposited elsewhere.</li>
</ol>
<p>GROSS
MICROSCOPIC</p>
<ol>
<li>Epithelial changes</li>
</ol>
<p>Thinning (transparent
Thick mucosa
Cysts
Mass (complication)
Atrophic epithelium
Hyperplasia of cells or Metaplasia
Cystitis cystica /glandularis (US)
Neoplasia (carcinoma US)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-sandy-patches">2. Sandy patches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-sandy-patches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Yellowish granular area calcified ova+dense FT seen causing mucosal roughening through atrophic mucosa
Occurs due to a massive oviposition at the same time.The ova die become calcified &amp;surrounded by FT and covered by a thin transparent mucosa.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-polyp">3. Polyp<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-polyp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Surface protrusion of mucosa + submucosa with Silh. granulation tissue</p>
<p>Cellular + fibrocellular + fibrotic granulomas in mucosa &amp; polyp core. Ova are both fresh &amp; calcified in same lesion
Occurs due to a repeated oviposition of small numbers of ova at the same site over a long period of time. This produces a slow rise of mucosa until a fingerlike projection or polyp is formed.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">GROSS</th><th style="text-align: left;">MICROSCOPIC</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">4. Fibrotic lesions &lt;br&gt; White firm + shrinkage</td><td style="text-align: left;">Fibroblasts + collagen fibers &lt;br&gt; Few trapped dead ova (mostly &lt;br&gt; Calcified)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">5. Bilh. Ulcers &lt;br&gt; Superficial (shallow) &lt;br&gt; Saucer shaped small &lt;br&gt; deep ulcers rare</td><td style="text-align: left;">Simple ulcer edges &amp; floor contain Bil.GT</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="caused-by">Caused by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#caused-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>falling of a polyp</li>
<li>of ova penetrating mucosa</li>
<li>mucosal ischemia due to pressure atrophy of sandy patches fissure (tear in UB mucosa) which occurs as a result of over distention of bladder with urine, in the presence of 2 fixed fibrotic areas along which a tear of mucosa occurs.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-picture">CLINICAL PICTURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-46495308.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-bladder-ub-schistosomiasis-bilharzial-cystitis">URINARY BLADDER (UB) SCHISTOSOMIASIS (BILHARZIAL CYSTITIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-bladder-ub-schistosomiasis-bilharzial-cystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>SITE: submucosa of trigone, posterior &amp; lateral walls</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-cd008b3c.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bilharzial granuloma
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c2b0881c.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<p>Large intestine with submucosal ova
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-cb47adba.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg"></p>
<p>Large intestine polyps
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a7080917.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sandy patch in urinary bladder
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-3075909c.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg"></p>
<p>Urinary bladder. Brunns nest arrow head &amp; early cystitis cystic arrow
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a0fdbd2f.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c7cc93da.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg"></p>
<p>Liver fibrosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="morphology">MORPHOLOGY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urothelial-epithelial-lesions-plate-6">Urothelial epithelial lesions:(plate 6)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urothelial-epithelial-lesions-plate-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Transitional cell hyperplasia: this will cause thickening of mucosa. With more proliferation of the cells, the epithelium will send downgrowths in the form of downward projections. When these separate from the surface, they produce transitional cell islands called Brunn's nests. Central degeneration with loss of cells will result in transitionally lined cysts called cystitis cystica.</li>
<li>Transitional cell atrophy: reduction of cell layers to 1-2 layers due to ischemia from the pressure of ova on BVs &amp; the endarteritis obliterans associated with the inflammatory reaction.</li>
<li>Squamous metaplasia: chronic irritation by the ova will produce change in type of cover from a weaker transitional to a stronger squamous type of epithelium. With more irritation, this layer may start to produce surface keratin like skin &amp; is termed leukoplakia (grossly appears as a white patch).</li>
<li>Glandular metaplasia in Brunn's nests: whereby the transitional lining changes to mucous secreting intestinal type cells, it is called cystitis glandularis.
N.B.: cystitis glandularis &amp; leukoplakia are considered precancerous i.e. they may lead to UB carcinoma.</li>
<li>Sandy patches see above</li>
<li>Polyps see above</li>
<li>Ulcers see above</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">COMPLICATIONS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Terminal hematuria: Hemorrhage into lumen at end of micturition due to squeezing out of ova during bladder contraction.
2- Ulcers get 2ry infected by pyogenic organisms <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Fistulae (vesico-rectal or vesicovaginal) &amp; ascending infection to kidney ending in renal failure
3- Malignant transformation (squamous cell carcinoma/transitional cell carcinoma/adenocarcinoma) see tumors</p>
<p>4- Fibrosis: Contracted UB which has a small capacity
Bladder neck obstruction resulting in obstructive uropathy (see special)
Urinary tract obstruction causes pressure on both kidneys and eventually chronic renal failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="urogenital-bilharziasis">UROGENITAL BILHARZIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urogenital-bilharziasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Ureters: Lesions occur in submucosa of lower third &amp; are similar to those of UB Complications:-Fibrosis of a hollow organ leads to obstruction (see repair)
A) Stenosis causing hydroureter &amp; hydronephrosis but if 2ry infection occurs, this condition changes fo pyoureter &amp; pyonephrosis
B) Obstructive uropathy results in back pressure on kidney &amp; chronic renal failure</p>
<p>Seminal vesicles-prostate-epidydimis- rarely testis: granulomatous inflammation
Vulva - vagina- endocervix- urethra: fibrosis of these narrow structures results in stenosis &amp; obstructive complications &amp; infertility</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bilharziasis-of-large-intestine-plate-6">BILHARZIASIS OF LARGE INTESTINE (plate 6)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bilharziasis-of-large-intestine-plate-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sites: lesions occur in submucosa &amp; lamina propria of rectosigmoid
Lesions: similar to US but polyps are more common than sandy patches &amp; ulcers. There is no predisposition to cancer. Finally, a feature of colonic bilharziasis in cases of whole wall fibrosis is that ova are deposited outside the colonic wall in the form of a tumor-like mass of bilharzial GT attached to the outer aspect of colon (Bilharzioma). In such cases, there will be no ova in stools since ova have no way of reaching the lumen (closed intestinal bilharziasis)</p>
<p>Complications: same as US
1- Hemorrhage: fresh blood in stools since lesions are rectosigmoidal and lower down the tract.</p>
<p>2-2ry infection of ulcers resulting in dysentery (diarrhea, blood, mucus &amp; tenesmus)</p>
<p>3- Fibrosis causing stenosis &amp; intestinal obstruction is rare since colon is wide &amp; lesions generally superficial. Nevertheless, submucosal fibrosis may result in Silharzioma</p>
<p>4- Spread to liver &amp; lungs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bilharziasis-of-liver">BILHARZIASIS OF LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bilharziasis-of-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>MORPHOLOGY
GROSS
Early: Increase in liver size (Hepatomegaly) due to REC hyperplasia ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Kupffer cells) Late: shrinkage of liver due to fibrosis</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Surface irregular due to FT retraction or shrinkage</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Size: small shrunken</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cut section: liver parenchyma appears normal, but portal tracts are widened, due to fibrosis and appear as white thickbanas (pipe stem fibrosis). The smaller portal tracts when affected only appear as fine white lines.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consistency: firm (FT)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Liver cells &amp; lobules are not affected; only the sinusoids show increased number of Kupffer cells containing hematin pigment.</li>
<li>Portal tracts:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Widened by fibrosis</li>
<li>Ova + bilharzial granulomas (cellular-fibrocellular-fibrotic)</li>
<li>Dead worms producing an allergic thrombophlebitis may be present</li>
<li>Angiomatoid formation: They are dilated congested anastomotic collateral channels opening between branches of hepatic artery and portal vein (PV) to by pass the fibrotic obstruction of portal tracts</li>
</ul>
<p>COMPLICATIONS of schistosomalliver fibrosis</p>
<ol>
<li>Portal hypertension:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a9c16dd1.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Ascitis</li>
<li>Congestive splenomegaly</li>
<li>Porto-systemic anastomosis open producing dilated tortuous BVs: e.g. esophageal varices-piles- caput medusa (periumblical dilated tortuous veins)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Portal vein thrombosis resulting from slowing of the portal blood flow</li>
<li>Ammonia encephalopathy</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bilharzial-or-egyptian-or-congestive-splenomegaly-morphology">BILHARZIAL OR EGYPTIAN OR CONGESTIVE SPLENOMEGALY MORPHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bilharzial-or-egyptian-or-congestive-splenomegaly-morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>GROSS
Early: mild enlargement due to antigenic stimulation of REC (littoral cells &amp; white pulp cells) hyperplasia
Late: marked enlargement due to congestion from portal hypertension (high portal venous pressure) congestion of red pulp</p>
<ul>
<li>Size: large</li>
<li>Surface: shows perisplenitis as ruptured vessels lead to subcapsular hemorrhage causing irritation &amp; perisplenitis (serofibrinous inflammation)</li>
<li>Cut section:</li>
</ul>
<p>Dark reddish brown (congestion of red pulp sinusoids)
Dark grayish brown nodules called fibrosiderotic nodules may be seen due to hemorrhages in red pulp. RECS engulf RBC and carry hemosiderin pigment. Many die releasing the hemosiderin, this excites a fibrotic reaction around it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic">MICROSCOPIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Early: white pulp increased in size &amp; littoral cells containing bilharzial pigment hematin are increased in the sinusoids of red pulp</p>
<p>Late: congestive spleen:</p>
<ul>
<li>White pulp is atrophic due to pressure atrophy by the congested red pulp.</li>
<li>Red pulp sinusoids dilated &amp; full of RBCs. Sinusoids contain many littoral cells filled with hemosiderin.</li>
<li>Scattered foci of fibrous tissue containing free hemosiderin (fibrosiderotic nodules)(+ve Prussian blue reaction).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-bilharziasis">PULMONARY BILHARZIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-bilharziasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ova <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> endarteritis obliterans <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> necrotizing arteriolitis which heals by FT</li>
</ul>
<p>Bilharzioma</p>
<ul>
<li>Dead worms <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟶</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟶</span></span></span></span></span> verminous pneumonia</li>
</ul>
<p>May reach lungs through:
1- Opening of porto-systemic anastomosis and passage of mansoni ova from GIT
2- Vesical plexus ,internal iliac veins &amp; inferior vena cava to lungs in hematobium infestation
3- Diffuse fibrosis of lung granulomas may result in interstitial fibrosis of lung</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malaria">Malaria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malaria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Malaria is an infectious disease caused by the parasite called Plasmodia. There are four identified species of this parasite causing human malaria, namely, Plasmodium vivax, P. falciparum, P. ovale and P. malariae. It is transmitted by the female anopheles mosquito.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathology-of-malaria">Pathology of Malaria:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-of-malaria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Anaemia: Red blood cells are the principal sites of infection in malaria. All the clinical manifestations are primarily due to the involvement of red blood cells. Anemia is caused mainly by repeated hemolysis of infected red cells. The bone marrow shows marked normoblastic hyperplasia</li>
<li>Spleen: Spleen plays an important role in the immune response against malarial infection. Splenic enlargement is one of the early and constant signs of malarial infection. Spleen may become palpable as early as the first paroxysm. The early enlargement of the spleen is due to congestion and oedema of the pulp. Later it is due to lymphoid and reticulo-endothelial hyperplasia with an increased hemolytic and phagocytic function of the organ. Frequent relapses and reinfections lead to pulp sclerosis and dilated sinuses. Rapid and considerable enlargement of spleen may sometimes result in splenic rupture, which is a serious complication of malaria</li>
<li>Liver: Enlargement of the liver also occurs early in malaria. The liver is enlarged after the first paroxysms, it is usually firm and may be tender. It is oedematous, coloured brown, grey or even black as a result of deposition of malaria pigment. In patients with repeated attacks of malaria, liver also enlarges significantly along with a large and hard spleen. However, there is no functional abnormality of the liver in these patients.</li>
<li>kidneys: In falciparum malaria an acute and transient self-limiting glomerulonephritis is common, whereas in P.malariae a chronic glomerulonephritis presents as nephrotic syndrome.</li>
<li>Nervous system gets involved predominantly in P. falciparum malaria and only very rarely in the other forms. Increased cytoadherence and rosetting of red cells, occlusion of the microcirculation by the red cell rosettes and their thrombosis all result in cerebral anoxia, development of malaria granulomas and punctate haemorrhages leading to malarial encephalitis and meningoencephalitis.</li>
</ol>
