<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="summaryof-bilharziasis">SUMMARYOF BILHARZIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summaryof-bilharziasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-reaction">Basic reaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>MICROSCOPIC: granuloma: ovum + many eosinophils + lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages, few giant cells &amp; PNLs</p>
<p>GROSS:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">1. Hollow structures</th><th style="text-align: center;">Urinary bladder</th><th style="text-align: center;">Large Intestine</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">A- Epithelial changes</td><td style="text-align: center;">Atrophy &lt;br&gt; Ulcer &lt;br&gt; Hyperplasia &lt;br&gt; - Von Brunn's nests &lt;br&gt; - Cystitis cystica</td><td style="text-align: center;">Atrophy &lt;br&gt; Ulcer &lt;br&gt; Hyperplasia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Metaplasia &lt;br&gt; - Squamous metaplasia &lt;br&gt; - Leukoplakia &lt;br&gt; Cystitis glandularis &lt;br&gt; Neoplasia (carcinoma)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Metaplasia &lt;br&gt; Sq. metaplasia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">B- Polyps &lt;br&gt; C- Sandy patches &lt;br&gt; D- Fibrosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Less common &lt;br&gt; Common &lt;br&gt; Diffuse</td><td style="text-align: center;">Common &lt;br&gt; Less common &lt;br&gt; Bilharzioma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2. Solid organs</td><td style="text-align: center;">Liver &lt;br&gt; Granulomas &lt;br&gt; Fibrosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lung &lt;br&gt; Granulomas &lt;br&gt; Fibrosis &lt;br&gt; Thrombophlebitis &lt;br&gt; Eosinophilic abscess</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="3">
<li>Surface: skin allergic dermatitis at site of skin penetration by cercaria</li>
<li>Reticuloendothelial system: lymph nodes &amp; spleen</li>
<li>Hyperplasia of REC--+enlargement</li>
<li>Pigment in REC</li>
<li>Chronic venous congestion spleen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hydatid-disease-echinococcosis">Hydatid disease (echinococcosis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydatid-disease-echinococcosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infectious-agent">Infectious agent<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infectious-agent" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The causative agent is Echinococcus granulosus (dog tapeworm).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-oftransmission">Mode oftransmission:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-oftransmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Human infection occurs by hand-to-mouth transfer of tapeworm eggs from dog faeces. The larvae penetrate the intestinal mucosa, enter the portal system and are carried to various organs where they produce cysts in which infectious protoscoleces develop called hydatid cysts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Symptoms depend on the location of the cyst within the body The most common site for the cysts is the liver. Less commonly brain, lungs and kidneys are affected.</p>
<p>The wall of the cyst is formed of the following layers:</p>
<ol>
<li>Ectocyst: fibrous advential layer due to host response</li>
<li>Middle layer: laminated membrane of proteinaceous material</li>
<li>Endocyst: inner germinal layer from which the scolices may be detached</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Pressure atrophy on the surrounding structures.</li>
<li>Leakage: Allergic reaction.</li>
<li>Rupture: Sudden rupture of the brood capsules and liberation of the daughter cysts and formation of secondary cysts. Rupture may also cause fatal anaphylaxis.</li>
<li>Secondary infection and abscess formation.</li>
<li>Cysts in the body may remain viable or die and calcify. They may be detected on routine X-rays.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam
Category B 15% of exam
Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Parasitic</td><td style="text-align: left;">Bilharziasis &lt;br&gt; Hydatid &lt;br&gt; Rest category c</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulatory-disturbances">CIRCULATORY DISTURBANCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulatory-disturbances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-hyperemia-congestion">1- HYPEREMIA&amp; CONGESTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-hyperemia-congestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>They are two reasons for increased blood volume in a particular part of the body.</p>
<p>Hyperemia is increased blood flow to an organ, resulting in increased blood content. It is due to active vasodilatation of its arterioles and capillaries.</p>
<p>Examples are blushing, and rubor of acute inflammation.
Congestion is decreased blood flow from an organ, resulting in increased blood content. It is due to obstruction to the venous outflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-congestion">Types of Congestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-congestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c4d4c00c.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg"></p>
<p>1- Local:
a. Acute local venous congestion:</p>
<p>Aetiology: Sudden occlusion of a vein by thrombus, ligature, strangulation ecl.. Effects: Sudden congestion associated with edema and hemorrhage</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-chronic-local-venous-congestion">b. Chronic local venous congestion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-chronic-local-venous-congestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Aetiology: Gradual incomplete occlusion of a vein by</p>
<ul>
<li>Pregnancy ( compress iliac veins) Leading to congested leg veins.</li>
<li>Cirrhosis or portal fibrosis ( compress portal vein radicals),) leading to mesentric and splenic veins congestion causing ascitis, splenomegaly and esophageal varices).</li>
<li>Mitral stenosis ( blood stasis in left atrium) leading to pulmonary venous congestion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Effects: Gradual congestion associated with edema, hemorrhage, opening of the collaterals and formation of varicosities (dilatation, elongation, thickening and tortousity of the chronically congested veins) and may be thrombosis due to stasis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-generalized">2- Generalized:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-generalized" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Acute general venous congestion:</p>
<p>Aetiology: Acute heart failure.
Effects: Sudden generalized congestion of organs associated with generalized edema.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-chronic-general-venous-congestion">b. Chronic general venous congestion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-chronic-general-venous-congestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: Gradual congestion of the systemic veins and their tributaries with or without congestion of pulmonary veins.
Aetiology: 1-Left sided failure 2- Rt sided failure. 3- Congenital heart disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">EXAMPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lung congestion: It occures in mitral stenosis or left sided hairt failure</li>
</ul>
<p>Gross: Early the lungs are dark red, moist and heavy, later they appear brown and indurated.</p>
<p>Microscopic: (Fig. 11) The alveolar walls showed congested capillaries, edema and hemorrhage. Intraalveolar heart failure cells ( macrophages engulfing hemosiderin) which may migrate to the draining lymph nodes. Later the libarated hemosiderine surrounded by fibrosis (brown induration).</p>
<p>CP: Dyspnea, hemoptysis and pulmonary hypertension ending in right ventricular failure. The right ventricular failure results in chronic generalized venous congestion.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-da9579ee.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg">
(Fig. 11) Lung congestion</p>
<ul>
<li>Liver congestion (Nutmeg liver): It occures in chronic generalized venous congestion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Gross: (Fig. 12) Early the liver is enlarged and heavy, cut section showed dark red spots of congested centrilobular areas against a yellow background of fatty change (nut meg apearance). Later, the liver become shrunken with irregular surface due to fibrosis around central areas.</p>
<p>Microscopic: Congestion of the central veins and central parts of the sinusoids. These associated with pressure atrophy of the centilobular hepatocytes and steatosis of the periphrall hepatocytes. Later, fibrosis around the central areas occur.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-9df19cb4.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg">
(Fig. 12) Nut meg liver: left (gross) and right (microscopic)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spleen-congestion">- Spleen congestion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spleen-congestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gross: Enlarged heavy spleen with dark congested cut section.
Microscopic: Congested sinusoids and atrophic follicles. Later hemosiderin leak associated with fibrosis leading to fibrosiderotic nodules.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-edema">2- EDEMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Pathological accumulation of excess fluids [transudate or exudate) in the interstitial tissue spaces and serous sacs.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Exudate</th><th style="text-align: left;">Transudate</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">High protein content&gt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \mathrm{gm} \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9444em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span>.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low protein content &lt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \mathrm{gm} \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9444em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span>.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">High specific gravity&gt; 1015.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low specific gravity &lt; 1015.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">High fibrinogen content [clots].</td><td style="text-align: left;">No fibrinogen [does not clot].</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Rich in inflammatory cells.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low cellularity.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Result when vessels leak protein (which</td><td style="text-align: left;">They result when hydrostatic pressure</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">carries water) which may be due either to</td><td style="text-align: left;">pusing salt and water out of normal</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">inflammation or to mild vascular injury.</td><td style="text-align: left;">vessels.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-edema">Causes of edema:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure: may be localized due to vein obstruction or generalized in congestive heart failure.</p>
<p>2- Sodium and water retention: due to excess aldosterone (tumor, liver failure, other), kidney failure, glomerulonephritis urinary obstruction.
3- Decreased osmotic pressure: When the total plasma proteins drops below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.5 \mathrm{gm} \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9444em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> or when the albumin drops below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5 \mathrm{gm} \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9444em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> lead to excess fluid accumulation in the tissue spaces and serous sacs causing generalized edema.
4- Increased capillary permeability: due to toxins, chemicals as histamine and serotonin in acute inflammation.
5- Lymphatic obstruction: causes local edema.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="classification-of-edema">Classification of edema:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Generalized edema is usually due to heart failure, cirrhosis of the liver, nephrotic syndrome, nutritional, malabsorption / protein losing enteropathies The worst generalized edema is seen in hypoproteinemia from many causes. Bad generalized edema called anasarca.
2- Localized: caused by obstruction of veins or lymphatics and inflammation.
Examples of edema due to venous obstruction:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> Pulmonary veins in left-sided heart failure
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> Leg veins due to thrombosis or Pregnancy ("pressure of the uterus", estrogen)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> Portal vein: in Cirrhosis and certain other liver diseases
Examples of edema due to lymphatic obstruction:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> When lymphedema involves the extremities, it can be producing elephantiasis caused by filarial worms.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> Obstruction of the pulmonary lymphatics by cancer is a common mechanism of death in cancer patients. Obstruction of lymphatics in the breast by a cancer produces "orangepeel skin", an ominous sign.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span> After surgery and after irradiation Chylous effusions result from leaking lymphatics, usually from trauma or cancer involving the thoracic duct.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-thrombosis">3- THROMBOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: The formation of a solid compact mass inside the cardiovascular system during life from the circulating blood constituents. It mainly consists of platelets and clotted blood( fibrin entangling blood cells).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="three-conditions-predispose-to-thrombus-formation">Three conditions predispose to thrombus formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#three-conditions-predispose-to-thrombus-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) injured endothelium.
(2) alterations in normal blood flow
(3) hypercoagulable blood. These are Virchow's triad.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-thrombosis">Causes of thrombosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1-Injured endothelium: as in myocardial infarcts, myocarditis sites ,cardiac jet lesions (abnormal flow), inflamed or prosthetic cardiac valves, ruptured atherosclerotic plaques, vasculitis syndromes and radiation injury.</p>
<p>2- Altered blood flow ("turbulence and stasis"): Blood physics keeps the formed elements, including the platelets, away from the endothelial surface. When the flow is turbulent, the platelets meet the endothelium. Activated coagulation factors, which are ordinarily cleared by the onward flow of blood,probably accumulate in pockets of turbulence, while sufficiently anti-clotting proteins probably cannot reach these pockets. Finally, turbulence itself might physically damage endothelium. As in myocardial infarcts, fibrillating cardiac atria, in dilated cardiac chambers (valve or muscle disease) and aneurysms.</p>
<p>3- Hypercoagulable blood: Congenital factor deficiencies, increase in number of platelates [after operations], fibrinogen [during pregnancy], RBCs [polycythaemia], WBCs [leukaemia] &amp; decrease plasma volume [dehydration].</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-thrombosis">Mechanism of thrombosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endothelial-injury-leading-to">Endothelial injury leading to<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endothelial-injury-leading-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Exposure of subendothelial collagen which is highly thrombogenic and release of endothelial thrombotic and antithrombotic factors.</li>
<li>Adhesion of the platelets to the exposed collagen which is mediated by factor VIII. This factor is produced by the endothelial cells. The initial thrombus is formed of platelets only. They adhere to exposed collagen at site of endothelial injury. The platelets release ADP which promotes further aggregation of more platelets. This thrombus is pale, fragile and can be washed out.</li>
<li>The platelets derived thromboxane A2 causes platelet contraction and platelet factor 3 is involved in formation of thrombin from prothrombin.</li>
<li>Thrombin leads to transformation of fibrinogen into fibrin. These fibrin threads which deposit on the platelet thrombus and encourage further deposit in of platelets. Platelets depoist in layers at right angles to the blood stream. Between this layers blood stasis allows deposition of fibrin threads entangling red and white cells. The thrombus is now formed of all blood elements [mixed thrombus] &amp; shows homo-genous pink lines [aggregated platelets] known as lines of Zahn.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology-of-the-thrombus">Morphology of the thrombus:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-of-the-thrombus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Thrombi generally have formed in irregular, swirling layers with more or fewer red cells and/or platelets Includecf. (When flow is laminar, fewer red cells are</p>
<p>incorporated; when flow is turbulent more red cells are incorporated.) These are the lines of Zahn. The thrombi tend to be rather hard and friable.</p>
<p>Rule: When thrombi form in fast-moving blood (heart, arteries), fibrin and platelets will predominate (pale thrombus). When thrombi form in slow-moving blood (veins, sites of turbulence and stasis), they will contain areas which are rich in red blood cells (red thrombus).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="special-thrombi">Special thrombi:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-thrombi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mural thrombi form on the walls of the cardiac chambers and aorta. As a rule, they do not occlude the lumen.</p>
<p>Arterial thrombi usually occur over ruptured atherosclerotic plaques, less often at sites of other vascular disease or old surgery. Except in the aorta, arterial thrombi generally occlude the artery, adhering tightly to the wall, and seldom embolize. Thrombi that form in the aorta, however, are notorious for embolizing.</p>
<p>Vegetations are thrombi which occur on cardiac valves. They may be loaded with bacteria ("bacterial endocarditis"), or sterile (the thrombi of acute rheumatic fever).</p>
<p>Venous thrombi almost always occlude the vein &amp; easily embolize. Thrombosis in veins more common because veins are thin-walled, superficial [easily injured) and blood flow is slow. They are of 2 types:</p>
<ol>
<li>Thrombophlebitis: thrombosis initiated by inflammation. It may be septic [in veins draining areas of acute suppuration) or aseptic [in veins exposed to trauma or radiation).</li>
<li>Phlebothrombosis: thrombosis initiated by factors other than inflammation. It occurs in veins of feet and calf in cardiac patients due to stasis and compression of veins against matress; or in femoral and pelvic veins after labour or operations due to increase in number of platelets, stasis and mild inflammation.</li>
</ol>
<p>Venous thrombi are likely to be symptomatic. Deep leg vein thrombi are usually asymptomatic, but often cause pain and edema. Even thrombosis of superficial (varicose) veins can be painful.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-and-fate-of-thrombi-fig-13">Effects and Fate of thrombi: (Fig. 13)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-and-fate-of-thrombi-fig-13" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Fragmentation: Thrombi may fragment or break free, producing thromboemboli. It produce septic emboli and pyaemia if the thrombus is infected.</p>
<p>2- Occlusion of an artery will result in ischemia and of a vein will lead to congestion and edema.</p>
<p>3- Organization :Since thrombi are composed of fibrin, they are simultaneously attacked by plasmin (to break them up) and invaded by fibroblasts and</p>
<p>angioblasts i.e granulation tissue which coverts into scar (organization). Mural thrombi generally take a long time to organize, incorporate into the lumen and they even calcify.</p>
<p>4- Organization and canalization: As the thrombus turns, over a few weeks, into vascular granulation tissue, it recanalizes. Ultimately, an occluded vessel which once had a single large lumen ends up with many tiny lumens.</p>
<p>5- Propagation: when a thrombus occludes a vein completely, the proximal column of blood clots till the next tributary. Opposite the tributary another thrombus is formed [the blood is moving) and when it occludes the lumen completely it results in the formation of another clot proximal to it. The process may be repeated several times [resulting in alternating thrombi and clots) and may even reach the heart [fatal].</p>
<p>6- Lnfection: very large thrombi become infected with bacteria, producing an intractable infection which .ultimately turns the thrombus into pus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-716f389e.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg">
(Fig. 13) Effects and Fate of thrombi</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-embolism">4- EMBOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: embolus is an insoluble mass circulating in the blood stream. Embolism is the process of impaction of embolus in a narrow vessel.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-emboli">Types of emboli:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-emboli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Most emboli are dislodged or fragmented thrombi (thromboemboli).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tumor emboli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasitic emboli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air emboli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fat emboli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Amniotic fluid emboli.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Sites of embolism: systemic arteries, pulmonary arteries and portal vein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="course-of-emboli-of-thrombotic-origin">Course of emboli of thrombotic origin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#course-of-emboli-of-thrombotic-origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Emboli from systemic vein or right side of heart impact in lungs.</li>
<li>Emboli form aorta or left side of heart impact in any organ [cerebral, renal, splenic].</li>
<li>Emboli form portal vein impact in liver.</li>
<li>Emboli form systemic vein may by-pass the lungs through septal defect in the heart &amp; impact in any organ. This is called paradoxical embolism.</li>
</ul>
<p>Effect of thromboembolism: Depends on size of the embolus, Nature (septic or aseptic) and state of collateral circulation.</p>
<p>A- Aseptic embolus: Produces transient ischemia if the collateral circulation is good and infarction when poor.
B- Septic embolus: Produce pyaemic abscess at the site of its impaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-embolism">PULMONARY EMBOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source: The large majority of pulmonary emboli come from the deep leg veins and may be from thrombi in iliac and pelvic veins or right side of the heart..</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Big embolus: occluding the pulmonary trunk or one of its main branches <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> release of excessive amounts of serotonin from the platelets <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> bilateral pulmonary artery vasoconstriction <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> sudden death due to acute right sided heart failure. No infarction [no time].</li>
<li>Medium-sized embolus in healthy lung <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> no effect because the lung has double blood supply [bronchial and pulmonary).</li>
<li>Medium-sized embolus In systemic hypotension, when the bronchial arteries are poorly perfused <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> haemorrhagic lung infarct.</li>
<li>Patients may have several episodes of embolization, leading to permanent high pulmonary vascular resistance.</li>
<li>Small-sized embolus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> no effect.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="systemic-embolization">Systemic embolization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systemic-embolization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is an embolization down a systemic artery. Most come from the heart (75%) e.g mural thrombi from myocardial infarcts and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> are others, e.g aortic aneurysms, and ulcerated atherosclerotic plaques</p>
<p>Rule: In contrast to pulmonary emboli, systemic emboli almost always produce infarcts. No artery is immune, though the majority probably go to the lower extremities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amniotic-fluid-embolism-amniotic-fluid-infusion-fig-14">AMNIOTIC FLUID EMBOLISM ("Amniotic Fluid Infusion") [Fig. 14]<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amniotic-fluid-embolism-amniotic-fluid-infusion-fig-14" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This very lethal event occurs in 1 out of 50,000 deliveries.</li>
<li>Amniotic fluid, which is full of baby's debris, enters the maternal circulation.</li>
<li>Respiratory difficulty and shock are followed by DIC (Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy).</li>
<li>The mechanism may be: the amniotic fluid vasoactive substances cause pulmonary vasoconstriction or its thrombogenic factors causing intravasular coagulation.</li>
<li>The pathologist finds squamous cells and other debris in the pulmonary vasculature.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-62998503.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg">
(Fig. 14) Amniotic fluid pulmonary embolism</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="air-embolism">Air Embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#air-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Injury to large neck veins
2- Ruptured chest veins due to chest trauma
3- Decompression sickness ("caisson disease") : Results when a pressurized underwater worker or scuba diver surfaces too fast, or when a high-flying plane's cabin depressurizes. The dissolved gases in the tissue escapes into the circulation as bubbles. The acute form causes agonizing pain and brain damage because nitrogen is very soluble in myelin. The chronic form ("caisson disease") causes ischemic necrosis of parts of the skeleton and the mechanism is poorly understood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Wherever the gas lodges, it interferes with blood flow. Large amounts of gas in the heart render pumping ineffective.</p>
<p>2- The few bubbles introduced into the blood during intravenous therapy seem to be harmless. It takes maybe 100 mL of gas to harm a grown-up.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-ischemia">5- ISCHEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-ischemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: decrease of arterial blood supply to organ or tissue due to occlusion of its artery.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types">Types:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Acute Ischemia sudden complete arterial occlusion:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Thrombus or embolus.
2- Strangulation of vessels as occlusion of intestinal vessels in strangulated hernia, intussusception and volvulus.
3- Twisting of pedicle of movable organ, e.g. ovarian cyst.
4- Surgical ligature of artery.
5- Severe arterial spasm as in ergot poisoning.
6- Extensive venous obstruction as in case of mesentric venous thrombosis ( marked venous engorgment, this impedes the arterial blood flow leading to ischemia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sudden occlusion of arteries with poor collaterals [end arteries] <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> infarction or gangrene.</li>
<li>Sudden occlusion of arteries with good collaterals <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> no effect.</li>
<li>Gradual <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> Chronic Ischaemia:</li>
</ul>
<p>B. Chronic ischemia (gradual incomplete arterial occlusion):</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Atherosclerosis.</li>
<li>Arteritis as in marked endartitis oblitrans as in syphilis.</li>
<li>Artery compression as by tumour.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects">Effects:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>With poor collaterals <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> ischaemic atrophy and fibrous replacement as in myocardial fibrosis due to coronray atherosclerosis.</li>
<li>With good collaterals <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> no effect.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-infarction">6- INFARCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: An infarct is a localized area of necrosis due to sudden ischemia produced by occlusion of either arterial supply or venous drainage. 99% results from arterial occlusion caused mainly by thrombosis or embolism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Arterial infarcts, the most common situation, usually result from:</p>
<ul>
<li>thromboemboli or in-situ thrombus formation.</li>
<li>The next most common cause is spasm (Prinzmetal's angina).</li>
<li>Much less common are extrinsic compression from adhesions or tumors.</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Venous infarcts result when veins are compressed and deoxygenated blood cannot leave the organ.</p>
<ul>
<li>The classic examples involve the bowel (strangulated hernias, torsion of the testis, fibrous adhesions), and even tumors or</li>
<li>extrinsic pressure can impinge on outflow.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-infarcts">Types of infarcts:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-infarcts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Pale infarcts are usual when arteries are occluded in solid organs. Bleeding is minimal, cloudy swelling of cells pushes blood back out, and the red cells lyse and disperse their hemoglobin.</li>
<li>Red infarcts ("hemorrhagic infarcts", ) result when veins are occluded, or when arteries are occluded in loose tissues (bowel) or with a dual blood supply, or when the organ was already very congested. Infarcts of the lung and small bowel from any cause tend to be hemorrhagic, and many brain infarcts (especially the embolic ones, where collateral circulation is good) are hemorrhagic from reperfusion.</li>
</ol>
<p>KEY: If the artery (rather than the vein) is occluded, and there is no reperfusion from removal of the occlusion, and the organ possesses only a single blood supply, then the infarct will be white. Otherwise it will be red.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="morphology-of-infarcts">Morphology of infarcts:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-of-infarcts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gross: All infarcts tend to be wedge-shaped" ( pyramidal), with the apex pointed at the focus of arterial occlusion in lung, spleen, and kidney infarcts. The infarction is surrounded by a zone of hyperemia, its base is raised when recent (edema), covered by fibrinous exudate and depressed when old (fibrosed). Venous infarcts, watershed infarcts, cerebral infarcts, or myocardial infarcts are not wedge shaped.</p>
<p>Microscopic picture is coagulatire necrosis or liquefactive necrosis if there is bacterial infection, or the infarct has caused necrosis of all the cells in a portion of the brain. Inflammatory cells enter the infarct by the first day, and become plentiful over the next several days. (see BR for necrosis).</p>
<p>Fate of infarcts: Healing by fibrosis may followed by dystrophic calcification.
Remark: General reaction: fever, leucocytosis, increased sedimentation rate and elevation of certain serum enzymes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-gangrene">7- GANGRENE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: massive tissue necrosis followed by putrefaction.</p>
<ul>
<li>Necrosis is caused by: sudden ischaemia or bacterial toxins.</li>
<li>Putrefaction is caused by: saprophytic bacteria which breaks down proteins and produces hydrogen sulphide [bad odour]. The latter reacts with iron of haemoglobin forming iron sulphide [black In colour].</li>
</ul>
<p>Types are: classified according to amount of blood and tissue fluids in the affected part at the time of its death .</p>
<ol>
<li>Dry gangrene. (fig. 15)</li>
<li>Moist gangrene.</li>
<li>Infective gangrene.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 15 Dry gangrene
4. Gas gangrene.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-7e1fc873.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-dry-gangrene">1- Dry Gangrene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-dry-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It occurs due to cut of arterial blood supply alone while the venous drainage and surface evaporation are normal.</li>
<li>Caused by thrombosis, embolism, surgical ligature, arterial spasm etc.... But the commonest example is senile gangrene.</li>
</ul>
<p>Senile gangrene: usually affects old males.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="predisposing-factors">Predisposing factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#predisposing-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis which affects the main artery as well as the collaterals.</li>
<li>Weak cardiac action helps vascular stasis leading to thrombus formation either spontaneously or after minor injury by e.g. wearing tight shoes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is important to mention the fact that healthy tissues respond to irritation by inflammation, while ischaemic tissues respond to irritation by necrosis.</li>
<li>The condition usually begins in the tip of big toe.</li>
<li>Cut of blood supply will result in a small area of necrosis, which is rapidly invaded by saprophytic bacteria resulting in gangrene.</li>
<li>The necrotic part appears pale and cold at first, but as gangrene develops it becomes black, shrunken and mummified and has a bad odour.</li>
<li>Putrefaction of the gangrenous part produces small amounts of toxins that irritate the adjacent ischaemic tissues which respond to irritation by necrosis. The necrotic tissues then undergo putrefaction and become gangrenous.</li>
<li>The gangrenous process spreads proximally until it reaches an area of good blood supply, where the tissues respond to irritation by inflammation.</li>
<li>Now the gangrenous process stops and a red line of acute inflammation, known as line of demarcation, appears separating the healthy skin above from the gangrenous skin below.</li>
<li>A groove, known as line of separation, formed by granulation tissue separates the healthy tissues above from the gangrenous tissues below.</li>
<li>This groove may gradually deepens until it separates the gangrenous part [natural amputation], leaving a conical stump. The conical shape of the stump is due to variation of blood supply.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-moist-gangrene-fig-16">2- Moist Gangrene (Fig. 16)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-moist-gangrene-fig-16" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Moist gangrene caused by occlusion of both arterial and venous blood supply and usually affects internal organs. Putrefaction is rapid and toxaemia is severe [fatal]. The line of demarcation is poorly developed and spontaneous separation doesn't occur. Examples: Diabetic gangrene and intestinal gangrene.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-52f4573d.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16 Moist gangrene</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dry-gangrene">Dry GANGRENE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dry-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by occlusion of arterial blood supply alone.</li>
<li>Usually affects exposed limbs.</li>
<li>Putrefaction is slow.</li>
<li>Spread is slow.</li>
<li>Toxins are minimal in amount.</li>
<li>Toxaemia is mild [not fatal].</li>
<li>Line of demarcation is well developed</li>
<li>Line of separation is well developed.</li>
<li>Natural amputation can occur.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Affected part is shrunken &amp; black.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="moist-gangrene">Moist Gangrene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moist-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by occlusion of both arterial and venous blood supply.</li>
<li>Usually affects internal organs.</li>
<li>Putrefaction is rapid.</li>
<li>Spread is rapid.</li>
<li>Toxins are maximal in amount.</li>
<li>Toxaemia is severe [fatal].</li>
<li>Line of demarcation is poorly developed</li>
<li>Line of separation is absent.</li>
<li>Natural amputation cannot occur. Affected part is swollen and brown.</li>
</ul>
<p>Diabetic gangrene: more common in diabetic females after the age of 45 years. Uncontrolled diabetes results in hyperlipaemia which leads to atherosclerosis at an earlier age. It begins in the tip of the big toe or in the sole of the foot. The gangrene starts dry but rapidly becomes moist because low body resistance and excess sugars in the tissues help putrefaction and lead to rapid occlusion of the venous drainage. It is characterized by rapid putrefaction, rapid spread, excess toxins, severe toxaemia, poorly developed line of demarcation, no line of separation and no natural amputation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-infective-gangrene">3- Infective gangrene<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-infective-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a subtype of moist gangrene in which bacteria cause both tissue necrosis and putrefaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lung gangrene: putrefaction of lung abscess.</li>
<li>Cancrum oris: oral gangrene caused by treponema vincenti &amp; Bacillus fusiform in debilitated children.</li>
<li>Bed sores: Skin ulcer over bony prominence due to prolonged recumbence. They are due to blood stagnation &amp; thrombosis of the vessels followed by bacterial infections.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-gas-gangrene">4- Gas gangrene:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-gas-gangrene" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a subtype of infective gangrene characterized by elaboration of several gases which is very serious and commonly fatal due to toxemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-and-pathogenesis">Causes and pathogenesis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-and-pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It occurs in deep ischemic wounds contaminated by soil containing anaerobic spores (contaminated by animal fecal material) as in agricultural accidents.</li>
<li>Tissue destruction including vascular damage causes local ischemia and germination of spores.</li>
<li>The organisms are of 2 types of clostridia.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Saccharolytic group (CI. welchii) produces;
a) Powerful exotoxin causing muscle necrosis.
b) Hyaluronidase causing rapid spread of infection resulting in progressive muscle necrosis.
c) Fermentation of muscle carbohydrates resulting in production of carbon dioxide and hydrogen gases.</li>
<li>Proteolytic group (CI. Histolyticum);</li>
</ol>
<p>They cause putrefaction of the necrotic muscle resulting in hydrogen sulfide gas which is responsible for the foul odour of the gangrenous part.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-hemorrhage">8- HEMORRHAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-hemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Escape of blood outside the cardiovascular system</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-hemorrhage">Causes of hemorrhage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-hemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Trauma.
2- Diseases of blood vessels themselves (from the petechiae of scurvy to the rupture of a syphilitic aortic aneurysm into the throat).</p>
<p>3- Diseases around blood vessels (infections, cancers)
4- Lack of clotting factors (congenital, acquired, DIC), lack of platelets,.
5- High blood pressure.</p>
