<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-hemorrhage">Types of hemorrhage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-hemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-internal">1- Internal:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-internal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hemopericardium: in the pericardial cavity.</li>
<li>Hemoperitoneum: Blood in the peritoneal cavity.</li>
<li>Hemarthrosis: Bleeding into a joint.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-external">2- External:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-external" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hemoptysis: Bleeding from the trachea. Coughing of blood.</li>
<li>Hematemesis: Vomiting blood.</li>
<li>Hematochezia: Bright red blood out the rectum. Bleeding per rectum From lower GI bleeding.</li>
<li>Melena: Black, tarry, partially-digested blood out the rectum. From upper GI bleeding</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-interstitial">3- Interstitial:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-interstitial" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hematomas: Enough blood in the tissues to create a palpable mass,</li>
<li>Petechiae: Little hemorrhages in the tissues, generally defined to be under 3 mm across.</li>
<li>Purpura: Hemorrhages in the tissues defined to range from 3-10 mm.</li>
<li>Ecchymoses: A bigger part of hemorrhage in the tissues defined to be above 10 mm .</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-effects-of-hemorrhage-depends-on-where-and-how-much">The Effects of hemorrhage depends on "where" and "how much".<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-effects-of-hemorrhage-depends-on-where-and-how-much" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="where">Where:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#where" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bleeding into the brain are devastating.</li>
<li>A few cc of blood forced into the pericardial sac under left-heart pressures causes instant death by occluding the return of blood to the right side of the heart.</li>
<li>Bleeds into the vitreous lead to blindness.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-much">How much:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-much" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Loss of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of blood volume: No effect.</li>
<li>Loss of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> : can be compensated by release of catecholamines, renin and antidiuretic hormones which cause restoration of blood pressure.</li>
<li>Loss of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> : Leads to hypovolemic shock.</li>
<li>Chronic blood loss: as in case of bilharziasis leading to iron deficiency anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-shock">9- SHOCK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: Widespread hypoperfusion of the tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-picture-cp">Clinical picture (CP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-picture-cp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Skin pallor and sensation of cold that indicate under perfusion of the skin as blood is shunted to the vital organs.</li>
<li>Weak rapid pulse and shallow respiration</li>
<li>Oliguria or anuria</li>
<li>Hypotension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-and-causes-of-shock">Types and Causes of shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-and-causes-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) Cardiogenic (pump failure):Causes :</p>
<p>1- Massive myocardial infarct.
2- Rupture (ventricle, or valve).
3- Massive pulmonary embolism.
4- Severe arrhythmias.
5- Cardiac tamponade.
II) Hypovolemic shock:</p>
<p>1- Heavy bleeding: Externally or Internally ( Trauma, surgery and blood diseases).
2- Other fluid loss e.g Vomiting, Burns and Diarrhea.
III) Peripheral pooling of blood:</p>
<p>Peripheral pooling of blood in capillary bed due to periphral vasodilation resulting in reduction of blood volume and cardiac output as:</p>
<p>1- Septic shock as in septicemia (from bacterial breakdown products and especially cytokine production by way of nitric oxides.</p>
<p>2- Anaphylactic shock (generalized mast-cell degranulation, type I hypersensitivity): leading to loss of vascular tone.</p>
<p>3- Neurogenic: Certain poisons (notably war gases), Profound anaesthesia, Spinal cord injury and Vasovagal (i.e., extreme pain, emotion) leading to neurogenic vasodilatation and hyotension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenesis">Pathogenesis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>With widespread anaerobiosis, lactic acidosis is likely to develop, and pH goes way down resulting in arteiolar vasodilataion and periphral pooling of blood in the microcirculation.</li>
<li>A variety of other secondary mediators of shock are produced by hypoperfused tissues. Histamine, serotonin, leukotrienes, cachectin, interleukin 1, C3a, C5a, and</li>
</ol>
<p>many other substances dilate vessels, inviting blood to pool in venules (congestion), and/or make small vessels permeable, causing blood to leak out.
3. When endothelial cells are damaged or thromboplastin enters the circulation, DIC may result.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stages-of-shock">Stages of shock:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stages-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Compensated shock, periphral vasoconstriction by released catecholamines and activation of renninangiotensin system). The blood is shunted away from the kidneys, salivary glands, gut, skin, and muscles in order to perfuse the brain and heart. Blood pressure is maintained. Patients may be oliguric from reduced blood flow to the kidneys and have dry mouth and skin from reduced blood flow to these organs.</li>
<li>Progressive shock ("decompensated shocl('), blood pressure and cardiac output decline and he vital organs experience severe hypoxia. All these patients have the lactic acidosis.</li>
<li>Irreversible phase: Multi organ failure ( renal, cardiac, cerebral, respiratory).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-changes">Pathological changes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Survivors typically have reversible necrosis of the renal tubules, which don't grow back for a few weeks. Until this time, patients are oliguric, and accumulate toxic products that are ordinarily excreted in the urine. This is not a lethal problem with today's fluid management. Tough cases can be dialyzed.</p>
<p>2- In worse cases, the lungs are damaged, and after a few weeks, patients die of pulmonary exudates, fibrin deposition "hyaline membranes" and fibrosis "adult respiratory distress syndrome, (ARDS)".</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="postmortem-picture-of-shock">Postmortem picture of shock:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#postmortem-picture-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Brain: Diffuse hypoxic injury ("respirator brain") and may be infarcts.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heart: Subendocardial necrosis (the subendocardium is the least-well oxygenated part of the heart) and widespread contraction band necrosis in the heart.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lung: diffuse arteriolar damage ( ARDS).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Kidney: Acute tubular necrosis of the kidneys (shock kidneys are heavy, since lack of tubular integrity promotes backleak of glomerular filtrate into the interstitium)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenals: stressed adrenals, i.e., cortical hyperplasia, lipid depletion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>GIT: bleeding points ("stress ulcers") in the stomach and duodenum. Necrosis of, and bleeding into, portions of the small intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Liver: fatty change of the liver and centrilobular necrosis.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam
Category B 15% of exam
Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Circulatory disturbances</td><td style="text-align: left;">Hyperemia &lt;br&gt; Venous congestion &lt;br&gt; Edema &lt;br&gt; Thrombosis &lt;br&gt; Embolism &lt;br&gt; ischemia &amp; infarction &lt;br&gt; Gangrene &lt;br&gt; Types of hemorrhage &lt;br&gt; Shock</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disturbances-of-growth">DISTURBANCES OF GROWTH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disturbances-of-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="any-growth-entails">Any growth entails:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#any-growth-entails" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cell proliferation or division with an Increase in number of cells
Cell maturation and differentiation is the change in appearance and function
Any growth may be:
Normal or physiologic (controlled)
Abnormal or Pathologic (controlled or uncontrolled)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-d6b8d6ab.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="decreased-growth">Decreased growth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#decreased-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A) Developmental or congenital
B) Non Developmental - atrophy</p>
<p>Increased growth
A) Non Neoplastic: atrophy-hypertrophy-hyperplasia-metaplasia- dysplasia (adaptations &amp; controlled growths )
B) Neoplastic (uncontrolled growths or tumours)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="decreased-growth">Decreased growth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#decreased-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-developmental-or-congenital">A- Developmental or congenital<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-developmental-or-congenital" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Agnesia: Means complete absence of an organ e.g. absence of a whole kidney.
Aplasia: Means complete failure of cell growth of an organ( severe from of hypoplasia) e.g. a kidney.
Hypoplasia: Means failure to reach full-sized development e.g. infantile uterus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-non-developmental">B- Non Developmental<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-non-developmental" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Atrophy (see before)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-growth">Increased growth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-growth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A-Non Neoplastic (adaptations &amp; controlled growths - see before)</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertrophy</li>
<li>Hyperplasia</li>
<li>Metaplasia</li>
<li>Dysplasia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dysplasia-fig-17">DYSPLASIA (Fig 17)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dysplasia-fig-17" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: A non neoplastic disordered cellular proliferation, maturation and differentiation of cells usually in association with chronic irritation &amp; chronic inflammation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Mucous membranes of the cervix uteri, bronchi, oral cavity, urinary bladder, colon and gall bladder.
(2) Skin epidermis.
(3) Liver.</p>
<p>Gross: Nonspecific gross appearance</p>
<p>Microscopic Picture: is characterized by
(1) Loss of cell pattern i.e. normal orderly arrangement (polarity) with increase in layers of immature cells
(2) The dysplastic cells show mild atypia (cellular abnormalities in appearance) as pleomorphism (different shapes &amp; sizes) and hyperchromasia (increased nuclear colour)
(3) Increased mitosis
(4) Dysplasia may be low grade or high grade depending on the degree of cellular atypia.</p>
<p>Low grade dysplasia affects the basal third of the epithelium.
High grade dysplasia affects the lower two-thirds up to the whole thickness.
Prognosis &amp; clinical significance: low grade dysplasia is commonly reversible when the irritating cause is removed. High grade dysplasia and carcinoma in situ (intra epithelial malignancy not invading the basement membrane) are difficult to differentiate from one another microscopically, hence are grouped together and considered as a pre-invasive phase of malignancy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Dysplasia literally means any abnormal growth. Therefore the term is sometimes used to describe certain congenital defects, such as fibrous dysplasia of bone and renal dysplasia. These types of dysplasia are not related to the conventional epithelial dysplasia described above.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carcinoma-in-situ">CARCINOMA IN SITU<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carcinoma-in-situ" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(Intraepithelial Neoplasia, Intraepithelial Carcinoma, Pre-invasive Carcinoma)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carcinoma in situ (CIS) represents a pre-invasive stage of cancer &amp; is characterized by severe epithelial atypia (severe dysplasia) without invasion of the basement membrane. CIS is essentially a microscopic change. Once the basement membrane is invaded the CIS phase ends and actual malignant tumor starts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features">Pathological Features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-features">Gross features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>CIS may be difficult to detect grossly.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>However some cases may cause a thick indurated patch (as CIS of cervix or bladder).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rarely CIS may cause a mass as in cases of CIS of mammary ducts.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Microscopic features: CIS is essentially a microscopic change characterized by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Diffuse cellular atypia involving the whole thickness of the affected epithelium. The cells are pleomorphic with dark nuclei and numerous mitoses i.e. cytologically malignant. Their architectural orientation (polarity) is disturbed.</li>
<li>No invasion of basement membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fate: Progression into invasive carcinoma occurs after a variable time (usually years).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-common-sites-of-cis">Examples of common sites of CIS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-common-sites-of-cis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Bladder</li>
<li>Cervix &amp; endometrium</li>
<li>GIT</li>
<li>Mammary gland</li>
<li>Skin</li>
</ol>
<p>B- Neoplastic (uncontrolled growths or tumours)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a8394693.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17 High grade dysplasia/CIS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="neoplasia">NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">DEFINITION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A neoplasm (tumor) is a new growth forming an abnormal mass, caused by autonomous self controlling proliferation of cells. It is characterized by being a pathologic proliferation of any cell type which is Irreversible, uncontrolled, unlimited, progressive &amp; purposeless.</p>
<p>The study of tumors is referred to as oncology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aeiiological-aspects-of-neoplasia">AEIIOLOGICAL ASPECTS OF NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aeiiological-aspects-of-neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A)PREDISPOSING FACTORS,: Co-carcinogens &amp; Precancerous factors: These are nonspecific promoting or helping factors which may transform the latent tumour cells to frank malignant cells.</p>
<ol>
<li>Aging increases the risk of some types of cancer (prolonged exposure to carcinogens), e.g prostatic cancer is almost present in every male above the age of 100 years..</li>
<li>Sex: Males are generally more susceptible to cancer, however some carcinomas predominate in females as breast carcinoma (very rare in males) &amp; thyroid carcinoma.</li>
<li>Diet: Diet rich in fat is related to colorectal cancer, while smoked fish is related to gastric cancer.</li>
<li>Environmental Factors: e.g air pollution (lung cancer), farmers (skin cancer due to prolonged exposure to sun).</li>
<li>Trauma: It may be related to some types of cancer as osteosarcoma.</li>
<li>Histocomaptibility type &amp; blood group: e.g gastric carcinoma is more common in blood group A persons.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-hormonal-sex-factors">7. Hormonal/sex factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-hormonal-sex-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> oestrogen is responsible for breast cancer or uterine cancer
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> testosterone is responsible for prostate cancer
8. Chronic irritation at sites where cells are known to divide rapidly(labile) &amp; Chronic diseases (PRECANCEROUS FACTORS) Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chronic Inflammatory Diseases as: a-Bilharziasis of the urinary bladder. b-Ulcerative colitis. c -Atrophic gastritis d-Radiodermatitis e-Peptic ulcer of the stomach. f-Tertiary syphilis of tongue -Lupus vulgaris (cutaneous T.B)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gall stones and urinary stones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyperplastic and metaplastic lesions as leukoplakia, endometrial hyperplasia, mammary hyperplasia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Some Benign Tumors e.g villous bladder papilloma, adenomatous polyps, some nevi. .. etc</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Others as liver cirrhosis, varicose ulcers, Paget's disease of bone, undescended testis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="9">
<li>Trauma Unknown effect but is suspected to play a role.
B) AGENTS CAUSING CANCER: Carcinogens &amp; Oncogenes</li>
</ol>
<p>The process of neoplasia begins with cell transformation (DNA damage &amp; genetic mutation). A variety of a) chemical carcinogens as benzene, cigarette smoke &amp; nitrites can initiate &amp; or promote this process b) Radiation, either as low level, long-term environmental gamma rays or as higher, therapeutic irradiation, can also produce genetic mutations. c) Infections particularly viral e.g. human papilloma virus (HPV) are also important agents ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{a} \&amp; \mathrm{~b} \&amp; \mathrm{c}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="mord">&amp;</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">b</span></span><span class="mord">&amp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">c</span></span></span></span></span> are called carcinogens. They are external agents that can cause DNA damage <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn mathvariant="bold">1</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\mathbf{1}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathbf mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> )</p>
<p>Genetic damage with DNA alterations leads to a) point mutations, b) translocation of genetic material from one chromosome to another, c) gene reduplication with amplification. These alterations transform proto-oncogenes (genes which are responsible for promotion &amp; regulation of growth in embryogenesis or normal growth but are suppressed or "turned off' in adult life) into oncogenes (are "turned on" or activated proto-oncogenes).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-definitions">Important definitions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-definitions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a- Carcinogen: external agents, which can cause DNA damage &amp; point mutations. Carcinogens are also called teratogens if they produce neoplasia during pregnancy.
b-Proto-oncogenes: Are normal genes that promote &amp; regulate growth i.e. expressing growth factors e.g. EGF -PDGF .... etc ... and may become mutated or activated into an oncogene. These protooncogenes are inhibited or regulated during normal growth by anti - oncogenes
c- Anti-oncogenes which are like proto-oncogenes but express growth inhibitory effects e.g. TGF B &amp; P53, &amp; are also called tumor suppressor factors.
d- Oncogene: is a suppressed anti-oncogene or an activated proto-oncogene (activated by change in gene structure or in gene expression i.e. functions) They are no longer sensitive to growth regulatory stimuli e.g. c- oncogene or cellular oncogene &amp; v-oncogene or viral oncogene. An oncogene can be considered as a cancer inducing gene.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>1</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Examples: c-erb-B2 in breast carcinoma, ras found in many carcinomas &amp; leukemias, BRCA-1 in breast &amp; ovarian carcinomas, Rb in retinoblastoma &amp; mutations in p53 gene in many carcinomas</p>
<p>The Transformation Of Proto-Oncogenes Into Oncogenes occurs by one of three mechanisms:</p>
<p>1- Point mutations, possibly due to exposure to cancer-causing chemicals.
2- Chromosomal translocations, where during cell divisions, a part of a certain chromosome (with its genes) is relocated into another chromosome leading to gene fusion or change in the sequence of genes, finally resulting in activation and transformation of proto-oncogenes.</p>
<p>3- Gene amplification: this is reduplication of proto-oncogenes.</p>
<p>Oncogenes encode synthesis of proteins called oncoproteins. These oncoproteins differ from the normal products of proto-oncogenes in that they are devoid of important regulatory elements and that their production in the transformed (neoplastic) cells is not dependent on growth factors or other external signals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-carcinogens">TYPES OF CARCINOGENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-carcinogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>CHEMICAL CARCINOGENS e.g. Aromatic hydrocarbons as 3,4 benzpyrene (exist in cigarette smoke) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> cancer lung and bacterial metabolites (as nitrosamines) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> cause cancer stomach.</li>
<li>PHYSICAL CARCINOGENS: e.g polonged exposure to ultraviolet rays (sun ) can cause skin malignancy (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma &amp; melanoma).</li>
<li>VIRUSES: Some viruses are oncogenic, e.g.</li>
</ol>
<p>Hepatitis C or B virus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> liver cancer
Ebstein Barr virus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> nasopharyngeal carcinoma and Burkitt's lymphoma
Human papilloma virus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> carcinoma of oral mucosa and cervix
4. HORMONES: They cannot cause tumor initiation but may act as promotors. Examples include</p>
<p>Oestrogen : High levels of oestrogen can promote endometrial carcinoma &amp; mammary carcinoma.
Androgens: Androgen in high levels can promote prostatic carcinoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-theories-of-origin">C) THEORIES OF ORIGIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-theories-of-origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most tumors arise from a single clone of cells (monoclonal), in response to an unknown or less commonly known stimulus.
Several theories have been put forward:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="multistep-theory">- Multistep theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multistep-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Stage of initiation---Exposure to carcinogen is followed by a latent stage where the affected cell remains dormant until it is acted upon by a carcinogen or non carcinogen(cocarcinogen).</p>
<p>2- Stage of promotion-carcinogen/non carcinogen (co-carcinogen) affect latent cell which proliferates by REVERSIBLE (hyperplasia-metaplasia -dysplasia) then IRREVERSIBLE (neoplasia) growths</p>
<p>3- Stage of neoplastic transformation/progression: Purposeless- uncontrolledprogressive cell proliferation IRREVERSIBLE</p>
<ul>
<li>Genetic mutation theory successive DNA mutations in a single cell cause cancer (somatic mutation theory)</li>
<li>Failure of immune surveillance: Failure of immune surveillance prevents removal of the new abnormal tumour cells which form during life. These cells if left in the body proliferate resulting in a neoplasm Failure of immune surveillance mechanisms: Neoplastic cells produce new or new oncoproteins or antigens (tumor associated antigens-TAA, which are considered foreign by the immune system. The immune system reacts by a cytotoxic immune response. If the immune system is defective or fails to recognize the new antigens as foreign, the cell escapes immune system &amp; a tumor is formed e.g. AIDS failure of immune system to recognize these new foreign antigens &amp; kill the cells carrying them results in tumor formation</li>
<li>Inhibition of apoptosis: it is now clear that some oncogenic mutations disrupt apoptosis, leading to tumor initiation, progression or metastasis</li>
<li>Virogene-oncogene theory Viruses may lead to development of cancer by:
integrating viral oncogenes into host DNA
producing proteins that inactivate products made by tumour suppressor genes
Some viruses that have been implicated in causing neoplasms:</li>
<li>Epstein-Barr virus e.g.
a. Burkitt's lymphoma
b. form of lymphoma derived from B cells)
c. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
d. other B cell lymphomas and some cases of Hodgkin's disease</li>
<li>Hepatitis B causes hepato cellular carcinoma</li>
<li>Human papillomavirus causes cervical carcinoma and some forms of carcinoma of skin cancers</li>
<li>HTLV-1 causes T ceilleukaemia/lymphoma</li>
</ul>
<p>Viruses not only affect growth regulatory genes (proto-oncogenes) but also may cause loss of tumor suppressor gene function (anti-oncogenes) and cause limitation of apoptosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-characteristics-of-tumors">GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS OF TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-characteristics-of-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A) Structural
B) B) Behavioral including complications &amp; spread as well as causes of death</p>
<p>All tumours share certain structural &amp; behavioral features, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Tumor proliferation is due to genetic abnormalities (inherited or acquired).</li>
<li>Tumor proliferation does not respect the rules that control normal cell growth, e.g.:</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Tumors can be derived from any cells, even from permanent cells that do not normally divide (nerve cells and striated muscle cells).</p>
<p>2- Cell proliferation is irreversible and unlimited. Thus cell proliferation progresses even after Any tumor consists of proliferating cells and fibrovascular stroma.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">HYPERPLASIA</th><th style="text-align: left;">NEOPLASIA</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Excited by a stimulus</td><td style="text-align: left;">- A stimulus is not always detected.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Reversible, i.e. pathological</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Irreversible, i.e. cell proliferation is</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">hyperplasia stops and disappears if the</td><td style="text-align: left;">unlimited and progresses independent</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">stimulus abates.</td><td style="text-align: left;">of any stimuli.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- Proliferated cells are normal-shaped</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Proliferated cells in case of malignant</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- May be useful (e.g. compensatory</td><td style="text-align: left;">neoplasia are abnormal-shaped.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">hyperplasia)</td><td style="text-align: left;">- Harmful</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>According to their behavior, tumors are classified into:
A. According to type of growth (Benign or malignant) Plate 9</li>
<li>Malignant tumours are further subdivided into: Insitu Intraepithelial and Invasive - There are 2 main types of invasive tumours:</li>
</ul>
<p>Locally malignant No metastasis and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⟷</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\longleftrightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.522em; vertical-align: -0.011em;"></span><span class="mrel">⟷</span></span></span></span></span> frank Invasive with metastasis
N.B.: Invasive tumours are called:
a) Primary: original single tumour mass
b) Occult: Hidden primary
c) Secondaries (metastasis): spread, many masses.</p>
<p>B) According to histological origin of tumour (epithelial, mesenchymal or other)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plate-9-benign-malignant-tumours">PLATE 9 Benign &amp; Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plate-9-benign-malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-72c6c0a0.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>

<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-a225b23d.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg"></p>
