<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Tissue of Origin</th><th style="text-align: center;">Benign</th><th style="text-align: center;">Malignant</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">A) EPITHELIUM:</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1. SURFACE EPITHELIUM.</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">a) Stratiffed squamous</td><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell papilloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell carcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">b) Transilional</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transilional cell papilloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transilional cell carcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">c) Ducts of glands</td><td style="text-align: center;">Duct papilloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Duct carcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">d) Mucosa of GIT</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenomalous polyp</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenocarcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2. GLANDULAR EPITHELIUM</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Endocrine &amp; Exocrine glands</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenocarcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">B) MESENCHYME</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1- CONNECTIVE TISSUE</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">a) Fibrous</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibroma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibrosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">b) Adipose</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lipoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Liposarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">c) Primitive mesenchyme</td><td style="text-align: center;">Myxoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">?Myxosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">d) Bone</td><td style="text-align: center;">Osleoma &amp; osleoblasloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Osteosarcoma.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">e) Cartilage</td><td style="text-align: center;">Chondroma, osteochondroma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Chondrosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2- SMOOTH MUSCLE</td><td style="text-align: center;">Leiomyoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Leiomyosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">3- STRIATED MUSCLE</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rhabdomyoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rhabdomyosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">4- ENDOTHELIUM</td><td style="text-align: center;">Angioma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Angiosarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">5- MESOTHELIUM</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rare</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mesothelioma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">6- Synovium</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Synovial sarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">C) OTHERS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1- Pigmenled cells</td><td style="text-align: center;">Nevus (benign melanoma)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Malignant melanoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2- Totipotent cells</td><td style="text-align: center;">Teratoma ,malure (benign)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Terafoma,immalure (malign)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">3- Embryonic cells</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Embryonic rumors</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">4- Lymphoid &amp; hemopoeitic</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Lymphoma &amp; leukemia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">5- Schwann cells</td><td style="text-align: center;">Schwannoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Malignant schwannoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">6- Trophoblast</td><td style="text-align: center;">Vesicular mole</td><td style="text-align: center;">Choriocarcinoma</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-benign-and-malignant-neoplasms-br">CHARACTERISTICS OF BENIGN AND MALIGNANT NEOPLASMS (BR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-benign-and-malignant-neoplasms-br" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">BENIGN NEOPLASMS</th><th style="text-align: center;">MALIGNANT NEOPLASMS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">A. TUMOR STRUCTURE &lt;br&gt; 1-GROSS FEATURES: &lt;br&gt; Regular defined tumor &lt;br&gt; - In solid organs the tumor appears lobular and commonly capsulated &lt;br&gt; - Tumors arising from a surface (skin, &amp; mucous membranes) appear as a defined noncapsulated projection called papilloma</td><td style="text-align: center;">A. TUMOR STRUCTURE &lt;br&gt; 1-GROSS FEATURES: &lt;br&gt; Irregular ill-defined noncapsulated tumor with the cut section of the tumor often showing areas of Hge &amp; necrosis. &lt;br&gt; - A tumor inside a solid organ appears as an irregular mass. &lt;br&gt; - Tumors arising from surface epithelia appear are either: &lt;br&gt; 1- Polypoid fungating cauliflower mass &lt;br&gt; 2- Ulcerative pattern: with raised everted edges, rough necrotic floor &lt;br&gt; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\&amp;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">&amp;</span></span></span></span></span> &lt;br&gt; indurated base, &lt;br&gt; 3- Irregular infiltrative growth below the surface.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">2-MICROSCOPIC FEATURES: &lt;br&gt; a)Cell Differentiation: Excellent The cells are perfectly differentiated i.e. closely mimic the corresponding normal cells. Rare mitoses.</td><td style="text-align: center;">2-MICROSCOPIC FEATURES: &lt;br&gt; a)Cellular Anaplasia (bad differentiation): &lt;br&gt; 1) Cellular pleomorphism. &lt;br&gt; 2) Nuclear pleomorphism: &lt;br&gt; 3)High N/C ratio and hyperchromatism &lt;br&gt; 4) Nucleoli may be prominent. &lt;br&gt; 5) Abundant mitoses &lt;br&gt; 6)Tumor giant cells containing a</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">b)Structural (histological) Differentiation: &lt;br&gt; This is the degree of resemblance of the structural pattern of the tumor to that of the normal tissue In benign tumors the tumor cells exhibit structural patterns similar to the normal tissue (perfectly differentiated</td><td style="text-align: center;">singleLarge &lt;br&gt; polypoid nucleus or multiple nuclei &lt;br&gt; b)Histological Differentiation: . &lt;br&gt; May be graded as well differentiated (grade I), moderately differentiated (grade II), poorly differentiated (grade III) &amp; undifferentiated (grade IV), according to the degree of differentiation</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">BENIGN NEOPLASMS</th><th style="text-align: center;">MALIGNANT NEOPLASMS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">B. TUMOR BEHAVIOR &lt;br&gt; 1-Rate of Growth: Often slow. &lt;br&gt; 2-Mode of Growth: Expansile, compressing without invasion &lt;br&gt; 3- Prognosis: &lt;br&gt; a. Benign tumors do not spread &lt;br&gt; b. Benign tumors do not recur if well excised. &lt;br&gt; c. Benign tumors are not dangerous unless: &lt;br&gt; - They arise in vital organs as brain. &lt;br&gt; - They cause obstruction. &lt;br&gt; - They produce hormones &lt;br&gt; - They may change malignant</td><td style="text-align: center;">B. TUMOR BEHAVIOR &lt;br&gt; 1- Rate of Growth: Often rapid. &lt;br&gt; 2- Mode of growth: Invasive &lt;br&gt; 3- Prognosis: &lt;br&gt; a. Malignant tumors spread (local &amp; distant). &lt;br&gt; b. Recurrence is very common &lt;br&gt; c. Malignant tumors are serious &amp; cause death due to spread, cachexia, infections &amp; organ destruction &amp; failure (e.g. liver failure, respiratory failure, renal failure ... ) &lt;br&gt; d. Some malignant tumours may act as functioning tumours e.g. &lt;br&gt; - Endocrinal tumour may over secrete FUNCTIONING tumour. &lt;br&gt; - Non endocrinal ECTOPIC hormone or polypeptide production (e.g. Lung cancer may produce ACTH &amp; Cushing syndrome. Such non endocrinal tumours which produce signs and symptoms of a known endocrinal disorder are termed paraneoplastic syndromes. &lt;br&gt; e. Complications of any malignancy &lt;br&gt; - General complications: &lt;br&gt; 1. Cachexia 2. Anemia 3. Hemorrhages &lt;br&gt; 4- Severe infection &lt;br&gt; - Local complications of any malignancy: Organ failure due to destruction- Obstruction - Pressure &lt;br&gt; - Complications due to spread of tumour: &lt;br&gt; 1- Lymphatic spread &lt;br&gt; 2- Blood stream spread &lt;br&gt; 3- Transceolomic:Krukenberg T ovary &lt;br&gt; 4- Implantation &lt;br&gt; a) Transcanalicular &lt;br&gt; b) Direct implantation or inoculation</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spread-of-malignant-tumors">SPREAD OF MALIGNANT TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread-of-malignant-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>MECHANISM OF SPREAD</p>
<p>Malignant tumors spread locally to surrounding tissues and distantly to remote sites (metastases).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">Mechanism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Gene mutation: results in new tumour associated (TAA) antigens on surface of cell. This changes the surface molecule receptors with loosening of Intercellular junctions &amp; loss of contact inhibition: E Cadherin loss results in proliferation and invasion</p>
<ol>
<li>Invasion of Extracellular Matrix (ECM): The following steps are included:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Loss of cellular cohesion: Normal cells are glued together by molecules called cadherins. Tumor cells lose the normal cadherin expression, allowing them to detach (loosening up).</li>
<li>Attachment of tumor cells (through receptors) to matrix components; mainly to laminin of basement membrane and fibronectin of the interstitial tissue . Attachment to ECM promotes the next steps.</li>
<li>Degradation of the ECM by proteolytic enzymes secreted by the tumor cells or by stimulated host cells (fibroblasts &amp; macrophages). Several enzymes are released as type IV collagenase (causing lysis of basement membranes of epithelia and of vessels) and cathepsin D (causing degradation of interstitium). Degradation of ECM is very important for the tumor cells to create passage ways for their migration.</li>
<li>Migration (mobility) of tumor cells (by pseudopodia). This is mediated by tumor-derived cytokines (mobility factors) such as "autocrine mobility factor". The process may be helped by acquiring negative charges on surface of tumor cells causing their repulsion and loss of contact inhibition.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-vascular-dissemination-and-homing-of-tumor-cells">2) Vascular Dissemination and Homing of Tumor Cells:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-vascular-dissemination-and-homing-of-tumor-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tumor mobility allows cells to come in contact with lymphatics, capillaries, venules or arterioles.</li>
<li>Tumor cell can penetrate lymphatics, capillaries &amp; venules, but rarely the thickwalled arterioles.</li>
<li>Once the tumor cells cross the vascular basement membranes, they reach circulation as tumor emboli, where most of them get destroyed by immune mechanisms. The surviving tumor cells adhere to platelets &amp; get impacted in small vessels, where they adhere to the endothelium, cross the basement membrane (by mechanisms similar to those described above) &amp; settle in the</li>
</ul>
<p>new site (homing). In their new sites, tumor cells proliferate forming metastatic deposits (metastasis, secondary tumors).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="routes-of-spread">ROUTES OF SPREAD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#routes-of-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>LOCAL (DIRECT) SPREAD Tumor cells invade adjacent structures in direct continuity e.g. cancer: tongue can directly spread to the floor of mouth</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distant-spread-metastasis">DISTANT SPREAD (METASTASIS):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distant-spread-metastasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A) LYMPHATIC SPREAD: Occurs more commonly with carcinomas than sarcomas
i) Lymphatic embolism:</p>
<p>Malignant cells invade the wall of lymphatic vessels <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> tumor emboli <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> lymph node.</p>
<ul>
<li>Spread from one node to another may occur by efferent lymphatics.</li>
</ul>
<p>Grossly: The affected nodes are enlarged &amp; firm. They may become fused &amp; fixed.
Microscopically the metastatic deposit resembles the primary tumor from which it is derived.</p>
<ul>
<li>Progressive spread by the lymphatic route may ultimately lead to tumor emboli within the main lymphatic ducts (thoracic duct), from which tumor emboli reach the venous circulation causing hematogenous spread
ii) Lymphatic permeation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> lymphatic obstruction <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> lymphatic oedema.</li>
</ul>
<p>Example: Breast carcinoma <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> permeation of axillary lymphatics <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> oedema of the whole arm</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-hematogenous-blood-spread-course">B) HEMATOGENOUS (BLOOD) SPREAD: COURSE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-hematogenous-blood-spread-course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Emboli derived from primary tumors of organs drained by systemic veins (vena cava) e.g. breast, and kidney <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> pulmonary arteries <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> lung metastases.</li>
<li>Emboli derived from tumors of lungs (whether primary or metastatic) are carried through pulmonary veins to left side of heart and systemic arterial and systemic arterial circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> metastases in different organs as liver, bones, brain ... etc.</li>
<li>Emboli derived from tumors of organs drained by the portal vein (tumors of gastrointestinal tract) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> liver metastases. Further spread from liver gives rise to emboli that reach the hepatic veins <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> inferior vena cava to lungs ... etc.</li>
<li>Emboli reaching the vertebral system of veins from tumours of pelvic, abdominal or thoracic organs lead to metastasis in brain, spinal cord &amp;</li>
</ul>
<p>vertebrae without causing lung metastasis since vertebral veins have wide anastmotic channels connecting them with lumbosacral, abdominal &amp; thoracic veins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathology-of-organ-metastases">PATHOLOGY OF ORGAN METASTASES:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-of-organ-metastases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The most common sites of metastases include the liver, lungs, bones &amp; brain.
Metastases are rare in muscles ,spleen, pancreas &amp; intestine.
Gross picture Metastases appear as scattered round nodules of variable sizes:
Microscopic picture: Metastases resemble the primary tumor from which they are derived.</p>
<p>Bone metastases: May be osteolytic but in case of cancer prostate it may be osteosclerotic (new bone formation is stimulated around the metastatic deposit, since malignant cells of prostatic origin secrete phosphatase).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-spread-through-body-cavities-transcoelomic-spread">C) SPREAD THROUGH BODY CAVITIES (TRANSCOELOMIC SPREAD):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-spread-through-body-cavities-transcoelomic-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the serosal covering of an organ is infiltrated by malignant cells of a tumor within this organ, some of these cells may detach and become implanted in other sites. This may be associated with hemorrhagic effusion. Transcoelomic spread includes:</p>
<p>1- Transperitoneal spread from carcinoma of stomach, colon, pancreas...etc cause metastatic peritoneal/ omental nodules accompanied by hemorrhagic ascites. In females, carcinoma of stomach (or colon) may be associated with bilateral ovarian metastases, termed "Krukenberg tumors" which were considered to represent transcoelomic spread. They are now believed to be due to retrograde lymphatic or blood spread, since Krukenberg tumors can also occur in case of cancers of breast, urinary bladder &amp; biliary tract.
2- Transpleural and transpericardial spread from lung or breast cancer resulting in metastases on the diaphragm accompanied by hemorrhagic pleural or pericardial effusion.</p>
<p>3- Malignant tumors of brain may give rise to tumor cells within the CSF leading to metastases within the lining of the ventricles, base of skull and spinal cord.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-other-methods-of-spread">D) OTHER METHODS OF SPREAD:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-other-methods-of-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Transluminal spread: malignant cells detached from transitional carcinoma of the renal pelvis may become implanted in the mucosa of urinary bladder forming secondary deposits.</li>
<li>Surgical implantation/ Innocculation:</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Instruments contaminated with malignant cells during surgical management of a tumor may transfer tumor cells into the surgical wound causing secondary tumor deposits.
b) Implantation from carcinoma of lower lip may lead to a secondary tumor in the upper lip</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-death-in-malignant-tumours">Causes of death In Malignant tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-death-in-malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Malnutrition: obstruction-anorexia-Ioss of absorption- Macrophage TNF alpha &amp; toxic tumour metabolites(toxemia).Tumour interferes with food intake absorption &amp; digestion</li>
<li>Anemia due to:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Hemorrhages: invasion of blood vessels
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Bone Marrow metastasis: causes destruction of marrow
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Hemolysis: is an immune reaction
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Folic acid def: due to malnutrition</li>
<li>Cachexia: severe form of protein calorie malnutrition causing wasting of body (loss of wt-anemiaweakness): Malnutrition-TNF alpha&amp; toxic metabolites-anorexia &amp; decrease Fat metabolism- low resistance to infection (malnutrition &amp; low immunity)</li>
</ul>
<p>CP: Wasting - Pallor- malaise &amp; fever +/- 2ry infections</p>
<ul>
<li>Local complications due to organ destruction or affection
A) Renal failure: obstruction &amp; local tissue destruction if metastatic &amp; bilateral
B) Hepatic failure &amp; obstructive jaundice
C) Increase intracranial tension &amp; pressure on vital centers</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-epithelial-tumours">1- Epithelial tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-epithelial-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-benign-tumours-of-epithelial-origin">A) BENIGN TUMOURS OF EPITHELIAL ORIGIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-benign-tumours-of-epithelial-origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-papilloma-a-benign-exophytic-tumor-of-surface-epithelium">(1)Papilloma: A benign exophytic tumor of surface epithelium.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-papilloma-a-benign-exophytic-tumor-of-surface-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A benign noncapsulated tumor of surface epithelium. Papillomas are classically exophtic (projecting) papillary tumors, composed of proliferated epithelial cells resting on intact basement membranes, supported from below by connective tissue core; containing blood vessels. Papillomas are rarely inverted endophytic lesions (that push the basement membrane and grow inwards, pushing the subepithelial tissues; of course without invasion) e.g. inverted papillomas of urinary bladder and nose. Classical papilloma may be sessile or pedunculated, single or multiple, they are classifies (according to type of epithelium) into:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-squamous-cell-papilloma">A) SQUAMOUS CELL PAPILLOMA:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-squamous-cell-papilloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition &amp; origin: A benign tumor of stratified squamous epithelium
Sites: Skin, lip, tongue, oral mucosa, pharynx, larynx, oesophagus, cervix, vagina and anal canal.</p>
<p>Gross Picture: Small sessile or pedunculated projection.
Microscopic Picture: Connective tissue cores covered by thick proliferated stratified squamous epithelium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-other-types-of-paplloma">B) OTHER TYPES OF PAPLLOMA:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-other-types-of-paplloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transitional-cell-papilloma-villous-papilloma">Transitional cell papilloma (villous papilloma):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transitional-cell-papilloma-villous-papilloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; origin: A benign tumor arising from urothelium (transitional mucosa of urinary tract). It is strongly pre-malignant.</p>
<p>Sites: urinary bladder, ureter or renal pelvis.
Gross Picture: The tumor appears as a noncapsulated velvety friable mass of delicate papillary processes.</p>
<p>Microscopic Picture: Delicate vascularized connective tissue cores covered by usually not more than six layers of regular transitional cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Bleeding (hematuria).</li>
<li>Malignant change into transitional cell carcinoma</li>
<li>Urethral or ureteric obstruction</li>
</ol>
<p>Columnar cell papilloma: A benign tumor arising from columnar cells e.g. duct papilloma of the breast &amp; mucous cell papilloma (Adenomatous Polyp): of gastrointestinal mucosa.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-duct-papilloma">1- DUCT PAPILLOMA:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-duct-papilloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; origin: A benign tumor arising from the epithelium of major ducts; Sites: Major ducts, as those of breast (most common) or pancreas.</p>
<p>Gross Picture: It usually appears as a small complex papillary projection inside the duct lumen.</p>
<p>Microscopic Picture: Delicate vascular cores covered by regular ductal epithelial cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Bleeding per nipple 2) Malignant transformation into duct carcinoma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>MUCOUS CELL PAPILLOMA (Adenomatous Polyp, adenopapilloma, mucosal adenoma):</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Definition, origin and Sites: A benign tumor of mucosa. Sites: Gastrointestinal tract is the commonest site.</p>
<p>Gross Picture: It appears as a sessile, pedunculated or complex papillary projection. Microscopic Picture: Proliferated mucosal glands lined by columnar epithelium, supported by fibrovascular stroma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Gastrointestinal bleeding is common.</li>
<li>Malignant transformation into adenocarcinoma.</li>
<li>Obstruction (e.g. pyloric obstruction)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-adenoma">2- ADENOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-adenoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition, origin: A benign tumor arising from glandular epithelium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Exocrine or endocrine glands (breast, ovary, salivary glands ,pancreas ,thyroid, etc)
2- Mucosal glands of GIT, endometrium ... etc (adenomatous polyp... see above)</p>
<p>Gross Picture: A capsulated globular or ovoid mass.
Microscopic Picture: Several Patterns:
1- Simple adenoma (tubular adenoma): proliferated glands separated by delicate fibrovascular stroma.</p>
<p>Remark: Mucous cell papilloma, is grossly a papilloma (arising from surface epithelium), but microscopically is an adenoma (composed of proliferated mucosal glands), Therefore it is called adenopapilloma or adenomatous polyp</p>
<p>2- Fibroadenoma : glandular as well as stromal proliferations. Breast is the main site.</p>
<p>3- Cystadenoma: Adenoma with retained secretions <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> cystic dilatation. Example: ovarian cystadenoma.</p>
<p>4- Papillary Cystadenoma: A cystadenoma with profound intracystic epithelial proliferation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> papillae. Example: papillary cystadenoma of the ovary.</p>
<p>5- Special types of adenomas arising in salivary glands (salivary gland adenomas) e.g.
a. Pleomorphic adenoma: It is an adenoma with stroma rich In mucin and pseudocartilage foci
b. Warthin's tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum): It is a special type of papillary cystadenoma in which the epithelial cells appear oncocytic (large eosinophilic cells) and the stroma is rich in Iymhocytes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I) Adenoma of endocrine glands may be hormone secreting e.g. thyroid adenoma
II) May change to malignant</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-epithelial-tumors-carcinoma-plate-10">MALIGNANT EPITHELIAL TUMORS (CARCINOMA) (plate 10)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-epithelial-tumors-carcinoma-plate-10" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) Carcinomas of Surface Epithelium:
(1)Squamous cell carcinoma.
(2) Basal cell carcinoma.
(3) Transitional cell carcinoma.
II) Glandular Carcinoma:
(1)Adenocarcinoma.
(2) Mucoid carcinoma.
(3) Carcinoma simplex</p>
<ol>
<li>TRANSITIONAL CELL CARCINOMA (TCC)</li>
</ol>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of transitional epithelium. It arises de novo or on top of villous papilloma.</p>
<p>Sites: Urinary bladder, ureter and renal pelvis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture">Gross Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Papillary Type:_A villous papilliferous growth with broad infiltrating base.
2- Non-papillary Types:
a) Fungating polypoid mass.
b) Malignant ulcer.
c) Infiltrative pattern.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Papillary TCC:Jhe malignant transitional cells overlie vascular connective tissue cores, usually more than 6 cell layers. Papillary TCC tends io invade less deeply than non-papillary TCC and hence has a better prognosis.
2- Nonpapiliarv TCC:Jhe malignant transitional cells form solid groups.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spread">Spread:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Local</li>
<li>Distant : mainly by lymphatics &amp; late by blood.</li>
<li>Transluminal implantation may occur</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-squamous-cell-carcinoma-epidermoid-carcinoma">2) SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA (Epidermoid Carcinoma)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-squamous-cell-carcinoma-epidermoid-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of stratified squamous epithelium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Skin
b. Squamous mucous membranes as lip, tongue, mouth, pharynx, larynx, oesophagus, cervix, vagina &amp; anal canal
c. Other mucous membranes on top of squamous metaplasia e.g. squamous cell carcinoma of urinary bladder on top of squamous metaplasia due to bilharziasis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="predisposing-factors">Predisposing factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#predisposing-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) prolonged exposure to sun. b) squamous metaplasia &amp; leukoplakia.</p>
<p>Gross Picture: Several patterns:
a) Fungating polypoid pattern.
b) Ulcerative pattern:</p>
<p>Irregular -Raised everted edges. - Rough necrotic floor.- Indurated base.-infiltrative pattern.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The dermis or submucosa is infiltrated by malignant epithelial cells which in well differentiated neoplasms form "cell nests". These cell nests consist of malignant cells that replicate the organization of the normal epidermis i.e. the periphery of these nests shows basal cell differentiation, followed by prickle cells then granular cells with the center of the nests showing keratin. In less differentiated neoplasms fewer cell nests are formed &amp; in anaplastic carcinoma, no cell nests may be detected .
Broder's grading of squamous cell carcinoma:
Grade I: 75-100% of the tumor consists of cell nests.
Grade II: 50-75% cell nests.
Grade III: 25-50% cell nests.
Grade IV: 0-25% cell nests.</p>
<p>Spread: Local, lymphatic and by blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-basal-cell-carcinoma-rodent-ulcer">3) BASAL CELL CARCINOMA (Rodent Ulcer)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-basal-cell-carcinoma-rodent-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A locally malignant tumor arising from basal layer of skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Skin exposed to sun, commonly that of face, particularly above an imaginary line drawn from the angle of the mouth to the lobule of ear, particularly at the inner and outer angles of eyes, side of nose and angie of mouth.
b. Skin of extensor surface of arms and legs is less commonly affected</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="predisposing-factors">Predisposing factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#predisposing-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prolonged exposure to sun.</p>
<p>Gross Picture Starts as a red papule: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> ulcer which has the following features:
Irregular-Raised, rolled in, beaded edges. Rough floor. - Firm base.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The dermis is infiltrated by masses of malignant epithelial cells, the peripheral cells are columnar basal cells with palisade (parallel) arrangement, while the central cells are polyhedral. There are several variants of basal cell carcinoma e.g. the pigmented, type, where tumor masses contain excessive melanin pigment.</p>
<p>Spread: only local. However basal cell carcinoma may change malignant (basosquamous or squamous cell carcinoma) leading to distant spread.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-carcinomas-of-glandular-origin">2) CARCINOMAS OF GLANDULAR ORIGIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-carcinomas-of-glandular-origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition-origin-sites">DEFINITION &amp; ORIGIN &amp; SITES:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition-origin-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are malignant tumors arising from glandular epithelium:</p>
<ol>
<li>Of the mucosal surfaces (as gastrointestinal mucosa, endometrium or endocervix)</li>
<li>Glandular organs (endocrine or exocrine glands as prostate, ovary, mammary gland, salivary glands... etc)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture">GROSS PICTURE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>In mucous surfaces the tumor pattern may be:
a) Fungating polypoid pattern.
b) Malignant ulcer type.
c) Infiltrative pattern (annular and diffuse subtypes).</li>
<li>In endocrine and exocrine glands, the tumor forms an irregular infiltrative growth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spread">SPREAD:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Local</li>
<li>Distant spread by :
a) Lymphatics
b) blood (late)
c) transcoelomic</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-types">MICROSCOPIC TYPES:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-adenocarcinoma">1) Adenocarcinoma:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-adenocarcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of glandular epithelium.
Sites:
1- Endocrine and exocrine glands as pancreas, prostate, salivary glands, breast, ovaries.
2- Mucous surfaces as GIT, gall bladder ,endometrium, cervix, bronchi.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture">Gross Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Ln endocrine and exocrine glands, the tumor forms an irregular infiltrative growth.
2- In mucinous surfaces the tumor pattern may be:
a) Fungating polypoid pattern.
b) Malignant ulcer type.
c) Infiltrative pattern (annular and diffuse subtypes).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- In well differentiated adenocarcinoma, the malignant cells show acinar arrangement. These malignant acini differ from the normal acini in several respects:</p>
<ul>
<li>They are irregular with no definite basement membranes.</li>
<li>Their lumens are irregular</li>
<li>The cells show malignant features (describe)</li>
<li>They exist in abnormal sites (as submucosa, musculosa or serosa) due to infiltration.</li>
<li>They may be cystically dilated (cystadenocarcinoma) if the malignant cell secretions are retained. Some malignant cells may show papillary proliferations (papillary adenocarcinoma or papillary cystadenocarcinoma).</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Less differentiated adenocarcinomas show less degrees of acinar differentiation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-mucin-secreting-carcinomas">2) Mucin secreting carcinomas:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-mucin-secreting-carcinomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two types:
a- Mucinous adenocarcinoma (mucoid or colloid Carcinoma): This is an adenocarcinoma with abundant extracellular mucin secretion
b- Signet Ring Cell Carcinoma The malignant cells show intracytoplasmic mucin that pushes the nuclei eccentrically. No acinar differentiation.
3) Carcinoma simplex (undifferentiated carcinoma, spheroidal cell carcinoma:These are malignant tumors of glandular origin, that neither exhibit acinar differentiation nor secrete mucin. Malignant cells form solid groups</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Most common in breast
2- Less common in other glandular sites mainly GIT.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-microscopic-features">Gross &amp; Microscopic Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-microscopic-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Scirrhous Carcinoma: Grossly the tumor is firm, gritty &amp; ill-defined. Microscopically malignant cells are rounded and form small-sized solid groups surrounded by dense stroma.
2- Medullary CarcinomaJencephaloid carcinoma): Grossly the tumor is more expansile and better defined than scirrhous carcinoma and appears relatively soft .Microscopically, malignant cells are rounded and form large-sized solid groups usually with more marked necrosis and little fibrous stroma.
Spread: As adenocarcinoma, describe (1- local spread 2-Distant spread).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-other-types-of-carcinoma">4) OTHER TYPES OF CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-other-types-of-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Urothelial carcinoma (transitional cell carcinoma): A malignant tumor of transitional epithelium occurring in the urinary tract; most commonly the urinary bladder. It is very common in Egypt due to bilharziasis</li>
<li>Hepatocellular carcinoma: A malignant tumor of liver arising from hepatocytes. It is common in Egypt due to chronic hepatitis</li>
<li>Choriocarcinoma: A rare malignant tumor of placenta</li>
<li>Salivary gland carcinomas as adenoid cystic carcinoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma &amp; acinic cell carcinoma</li>
<li>Renal cell carcinoma</li>
<li>Other types</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251212-35cb94f1.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="benign-mesenchymal-tumors">BENIGN MESENCHYMAL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benign-mesenchymal-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-lipoma-plate-9">1) LIPOMA (plate 9)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-lipoma-plate-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition-origin">Definition &amp; origin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition-origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A benign tumor of adipose tissue. It is the most common soft tissue tumor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Anywhere in the body, but most commonly subcutaneous tissue, particularly at the region of shoulders, neck, back and buttocks.
2- Intermuscular septa.
3- Mediastinum, mesentery, omentum, retroperitoneal.
4- Wall of stomach and intestine, and organs as kidney.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture">Gross Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A capsulated globular or ovoid, commonly lobulated yellowish soft greasy mass.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The tumor consists of lobules composed of mature fat cells (adipocytes) which are large vacuolated cells with flattened eccentric nuclei. The lobules are separated by fibrovascular septa.</li>
<li>Rarely lipoma consists of immature or embryonic fat cells which are smaller than mature fat cells showing central nuclei and cytoplasmic vacuoles. This type of lipoma is called hibernoma</li>
</ul>
<p>Secondary changes &amp; malignant transformation: Malignant change into liposarcoma is extremely rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-fibroma">2) FIBROMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-fibroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; origin: An uncommon benign tumor of fibrous tissue
Sites: Dermis - Periosteum of bone - Organs as ovary
Gross Picture: A grayish white firm globular mass.
Microscopic Picture: The tumor consists of variable proportions of fibroblasts, collagen and blood vessels. Fibroblasts may be numerous "cellular fibroma". Fibroblasts appear as spindle shaped cells with elongated nuclei showing tapering ends. Hyaline or myxoid changes may occur.</p>
<p>Secondary changes &amp; malignant transformation: Hyalinosis, myxomatous change &amp; calcification may occur. Malignant change into fibrosarcoma is very rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fibromatosis">FIBROMATOSIS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibromatosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fibromatosis is a tumor-like non neoplastic aggressive proliferation of fibrous tissue extending to neighboring structures as muscle (benign infiltration), resulting in a noncapsulated irregular mass, that commonly recurs after surgical excision. The proliferating fibroblasts show no atypia and there is no distant spread of the lesion.. Aetiology is not clear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="desmoid-tumor-aggressive-fibromatosis">DESMOID TUMOR (AGGRESSIVE FIBROMATOSIS):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#desmoid-tumor-aggressive-fibromatosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Desmoid tumor belongs to a group of lesions called fibromatosis of unclear pathogenesis Fibromatosis is characterized by non neoplastic aggressive reactive proliferation of fibrous tissue extending to neighboring structures (benign infiltration) resulting in a noncapsulated irregular tumor- like mass, that commonly recurs after surgical excision.</p>
<p>The proliferating fibroblasts show no features of malignancy &amp; the lesion does not metastasize.</p>
<p>The most common form of fibromatosis is abdominal desmoid which arises from the musculo-aponeurotic structures of the anterior abdominal wall in woman during or after pregnancy. There are many other types of fibromatosis as extra-abdominal desmoid, penile fibromatosis, palmar and plantar fibromatosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-chondroma-plate-9">3) CHONDROMA (plate 9)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-chondroma-plate-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A benign tumor of cartilage</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Within the interior of bone (enchondroma); most commonly short bones of hands &amp; feet test, less commonly at ends of long bones or in flat bones as pelvis; ribs, sternum &amp; scapula Enchondroma is usually solitary, but rarely multiple (enchondromatosis, Oilier's disease</p>
<p>2- 0 n the surface of bone (subperiosteal or juxtacortical chondroma).
3- Extraskeletal soft tissue chondroma and bronchial chondroma are rare.
Gross Picture: A globular well demarcated mass, commonly nodular or lobulated. A thin outer capsule may be seen. The tumor is bluish gray and translucent.</p>
<p>Microscopic Picture: Nodules of cartilage composed of hyaline matrix and cartilage cells residing inside their lacunae. Cartilage cells (chondrocytes) are rounded with vacuolated cytoplasm.</p>
<p>Secondary changes &amp; malignant transformation: Myxoid change, calcification &amp; ossification are common .Malignant change into chondrosarcoma is rare in solitary</p>
<p>chondroma &amp; more common in case of enchondromatosis.residing inside their lacunae. Cartilage cells (chondrocytes) are rounded with vacuolated cytoplasm.
4) OSTEOCHONDROMA (Exostosis, cancellous osteoma orechondroma)</p>
