<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="definition-origin-and-sites">Definition, Origin and Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition-origin-and-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Osteochondroma is a developmental tumor-like abnormality (hamartoma) rather than a true neoplasm. It arises from aberrant lateral growth of the epiphyseal cartilage. They occur in long bones &amp; stop growing after puberty.</p>
<p>Gross Picture: The lesion may be single or multiple (multiple exostosis, osteochondromatosis).</p>
<p>The multiple type is a hereditary autosomal dominant disease. The lesion appears as a mushroomshaped lateral projection composed of a bony stalk and head covered by a cartilaginous cap.</p>
<p>Microscopic Picture: Cancelious bone covered by cartilage.
Complications: Malignant change into chondrosarcoma is more common in case of multiple exostosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-osteoma">5) OSTEOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-osteoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteoid-osteoma">OSTEOID OSTEOMA:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteoid-osteoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: Benign bone tumor composed of osteoid tissue
Sites: Any bone, the commonest are femur and tibia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-picture">Gross Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The tumor is solitary, less than 2 cm in diameter (commonly less than 1 cm ). Its substance appears pink, gritty and friable. Osteoid osteomas arising below the periosteum are famous of exciting a tremendous amount of reactive bone that encircles the tumor so that in X ray films the tumor appears as a radiolucent small lesion (nidus), with dense sclerotic margins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Trabeculae of poorly mineralized osteoid bone rimmed by proliferating osteoblasts. The intervening stroma is loose and richly vascularized.</p>
<p>Complications: Osteoid osteoma causes a characteristic nocturnal pain which is dramatically improved by aspirin. Pain is caused by excess production of prostaglandin E2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compact-osteoma-ivory-osteoma">COMPACT OSTEOMA: (Ivory Osteoma):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compact-osteoma-ivory-osteoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition, Origin &amp; Sites: Benign tumor arising in membranous bones of the skull.
Gross Picture: A hemispherical, noncapsulated hard ivory-like mass.
Microscopic Picture: concentrically arranged bone lamellae.
Complications: Disfigurement and pressure symptoms e.g. proptosis.
N.B.: OSTEOCHONDROMA is sometimes regarded as a type of osteoma called cancellous osteoma (describe)</p>
<p>Remark: Osteoblastoma is a similar lesion to osteoid osteoma with the following differences</p>
<ul>
<li>Larger</li>
<li>Painless</li>
<li>More common in the spine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-myxoma">6) MYXOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-myxoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A rare benign tumor arising from remnants of primitive mesenchyme.</p>
<p>Sites: I he commonest sites are the heart (particularly atrial) and jaw (in relation to teeth).</p>
<p>Gross Picture: A soft gelatinous mass.
Microscopy: Stellate shaped myxoma cells embedded in mucoid matrix.
Complications &amp; secondary changes: Cardiac myxoma may be serious. It may be pedunculated and blocks the atrlo-ventricular valves. Malignant change may occur.</p>
<p>Secondary hemorrhage and cyst formation may occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-benign-tumors-of-muscles-myomas">7) BENIGN TUMORS OF MUSCLES (MYOMAS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-benign-tumors-of-muscles-myomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-leiomyoma">A) LEIOMYOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-leiomyoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A benign tumor of smooth muscle.
Sites: It is a common tumor. Sites include:
1- Uterus is the most common site. Leiomyoma is the commonest tumor in females. It occurs during the reproductive period of life and is oestrogendependent.
2- Wall of oesophagus, stomach, intestine, urinary bladder and skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gross-picture-of-uterine-leiomyoma">Gross Picture (of uterine leiomyoma):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-picture-of-uterine-leiomyoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Single or multiple.</li>
<li>Occurs within the myometrium (intramural, interstitial), but may also occur beneath the serosa (subserous) or immediately beneath the endometrium (submucous).</li>
<li>Sharply circumscribed, round and firm.</li>
<li>Uncapsulated but may acquire false capsule of compressed surrounding muscles.</li>
<li>The cut section is grayish or grayish brown and usually shows a whorly appearance.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-picture">Microscopic Picture:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells, which are spindle shaped cells that differ from fibroblasts in having more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and rod-shaped nuclei having blunt (non-tapering) ends.
2- Fibrous stroma containing blood vessels. This fibrous stroma may be abundant (particularly after the menopause) and the tumor may then be called fibromyoma or fibroid.
3- Secondary changes as hyaline, myxoid and cystic changes, ischemic necrosis and calcification are common.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Malignant change into leiomyosarcoma is extremely rare. 2-Uterine myoma may lead to uterine bleeding and infertility</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-rhabdomyoma">B) RHABDOMYOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-rhabdomyoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: An extremely rare benign tumor of striated muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-benign-tumors-of-vessels-angioma">8) BENIGN TUMORS OF VESSELS (ANGIOMA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-benign-tumors-of-vessels-angioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Benign lesions ( hamartomas) composed of vascular spaces filled with Blood (hemangioma) or Lymph (lymphangioma).</li>
<li>They are usually detected in early life (congenital tumor-like malformations (hamartomas) rather than true neoplasms.</li>
<li>They do not change malignant.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-hemangioma-figs-18-19">A) HEMANGIOMA (Figs. 18 &amp; 19)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-hemangioma-figs-18-19" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition: These are benign noncapsulated lesions composed of vascular spaces filled with either blood (hemangioma) or lymph (lymphangioma). They are usually detected in early life and represent congenital tumor-like malformations (hamartomas) rather than true neoplasms. They do not change malignant.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">CAPILLARY HEMANGIOMA</th><th style="text-align: left;">CAVERNOUS HEMANGIOMA</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Sites:</td><td style="text-align: left;">Sites:</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">1- Skin, often since birth (birth mark).</td><td style="text-align: left;">1- Skin, particularly of the face.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">2- Mucus membranes of lip and tongue.</td><td style="text-align: left;">2- Mucus membranes of lip &amp; tongue.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">3- Organs as brain &amp; kidney</td><td style="text-align: left;">Macrochelia &amp; macroglossia may</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">occur.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">3- Organs as liver, spleen &amp; muscles</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Gross: A deep red well defined patch.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Gross: A purple well defined soft swelling.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Microscopy:</td><td style="text-align: left;">Microscopy:</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Small vascular spaces lined by</td><td style="text-align: left;">Wide vascular spaces lined by</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">endothelium &amp; contain blood.</td><td style="text-align: left;">endothelium &amp; filled with blood.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-lymphangioma">B) LYMPHANGIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-lymphangioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: A benign hamartomatous (tumor-like) lesion of lymphatic vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Skin particularly of head, neck and axilla.
2- Mucous membranes e.g. lip and tongue
3- Viscera as spleen, liver &amp; kidney</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-gross-microscopic-features">Types, Gross &amp; Microscopic Features:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-gross-microscopic-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cavernous lymphangioma: This is the most common type:
Grossly: A grayish pink swelling that may cause enlargement macrochelia (lip enlargement) or macroglossia (tongue enlargement).
Microscopically: wide vascular channels, filled with pale eosinophilic lymph &amp;
Cystic lymphangioma (cystic hygroma):
Grossly: a huge congenital cystic swelling, composed of widely cystic lymphatic channels. It occurs at the side of the neck and may cause troubles delivery of the baby.</p>
<p>Microscopically: like cavernous lymphangioma, but wider vascular lymphatic channels.</p>
<p>Capillary lymphangioma: A small lesion composed of capillary spaces lined by endothelium &amp;filled with lymph
C) HEMANGIOENDOTHELIOMA: A rarer tumor composed of capillary spaces associated with prominent proliferation of endothelial cells. Some of these tumors are benign and others are of low grade malignancy
D) OTHER BENIGN VASCULAR TUMORS: Glomangioma &amp; sclerosing hemangioma: See systemic pathology.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-7ca7f332.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 18 Capillary hemangioma
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-3e29c68a.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19 Cavernous hemangioma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="9-benign-tumours-of-nerve-sheath-see-special">9) BENIGN TUMOURS OF NERVE SHEATH (see special)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-benign-tumours-of-nerve-sheath-see-special" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-mesenchymal-tumors-sarcomas">MALIGNANT MESENCHYMAL TUMORS (SARCOMAS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-mesenchymal-tumors-sarcomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>GENERAL CHARACTERS: See table page</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">CLASSIFICATION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A) Differentiated Sarcomas:</p>
<p>1- Liposarcoma
2- Fibrosarcoma
3- Rhabdomyosarcoma
4- Leiomyosarcoma
5- Angiosarcoma &amp; other malignant vascular tumors.
6- 0steosarcoma 7Chondrosarcoma
B) Undifferentiated Sarcomas: These are sarcomas derived from different cell types (fibroblasts, osteoblasts, lipoblasts... etc.) but without differentiation that points to their cell of origin. These sarcomas are sometimes designated according to the predominant cell pattern e.g.
a. Round cell sarcoma,
b. Spindle cell sarcoma,
c. Giant cell sarcoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-liposarcoma">1) LIPOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-liposarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Origin: A malignant tumor of adipose tissue.
Sites: Retroperitoneal, mesenteric, mediastinal, intermuscular, subcutaneous.
Gross Picture: Large soft mass with foci of necrosis and hemorrhage.
Microscopic Picture: In well differentiated liposarcoma, the malignant cells contain abundant intracytoplasmic fat. In undifferentiated (pleomorphic) liposarcoma, the malignant cells are extremely pleomorphic with very poor lipoblastic differentiation. Sometimes liposarcoma shows myxoid foci (myxoliposarcoma).</p>
<p>Spread: Direct and blood spread. The well differentiated types have a much better prognosis than the other types.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-fibrosarcoma">2) FIBROSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-fibrosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of fibrous tissue. Sites: Subcutaneous, periosteal, intermuscular...</p>
<p>Gross: A large grayish mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.
Microscopy: In well differentiated fibrosarcoma the malignant spindle cells are separated by abundant collagenous stroma. In less differentiated forms there is little collagen and more marked cellular anaplasia.</p>
<p>Spread: Direct &amp; blood spread. Well differentiated fibrosarcoma has a better prognosis due to slow spread.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-rhabdomyosarcoma">3) RHABDOMYOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-rhabdomyosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A malignant tumor of striated muscle. Three main types:
1- Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides): occurs in children; mainly in urinary bladder, vagina and cervix. It consists of small spindle cells with dark nuclei in a myxoid matrix.</p>
<p>2- Pleomorphic Rhabdomyosarcoma: occurs in adults in intermuscular septa and soft tissue. It consists of extremely pleomorphic cells, some of which may show cytoplasmic cross striations (strap cells).</p>
<p>3- Alveolar Rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of malignant cells exhibiting alveolar arrangement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-leiomyosarcoma">4) LEIOMYOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-leiomyosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of smooth muscle.
Sites: Most commonly uterus and GIT
Gross: Large fleshy mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis.
Microscopy: Malignant spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and large dark nuclei. Cytoplasmic actin can be detected by immunohistochemistry.</p>
<p>Spread: Direct and blood spread (faster in less differentiated tumors)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-othersarcomas">5) OTHERSARCOMAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-othersarcomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Malignant vascular tumors, osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma... etc: See systemic pathology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-lymphoma-leukemia">6) LYMPHOMA &amp; LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-lymphoma-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymphomas are a group of primary malignant neoplasms of lymphoid tissue arising from B or T lymphocytes or rarely histiocytes.</p>
<p>Leukemia is a malignant proliferation of one of the leukocyte forming tissue</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="miscellaneous-benign-malignant-tumors">MISCELLANEOUS BENIGN &amp; MALIGNANT TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#miscellaneous-benign-malignant-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>PIGMENTED (MELANOCYTIC) TUMORS</li>
</ol>
<p>Definition: These are benign &amp; malignant tumors arising from melanocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Skin</li>
<li>Mucous membranes &amp; mucocutaneous junctions (as conjunctiva, rectum, mouth &amp; vagina)</li>
<li>Eye as choriod and iris.</li>
<li>Leptomeninges.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Pigmented nevus or mole: It may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>Congenital nevus:</li>
<li>Acquired nevus including junctional, intradermal &amp; combined types.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-malignant-melanoma">2- Malignant Melanoma.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-malignant-melanoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It may grow vertically (nodular melanoma) .This type is more serious &amp; spreads rapidly</li>
<li>It may grow radially. This type is less dangerous than nodular melanoma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-benign-lesion-nevus-or-mole">A) BENIGN Lesion: (NEVUS or MOLE):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-benign-lesion-nevus-or-mole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition: Benign tumour of the melanocytes. It is present in nearly every individual and usually dates since birth, so it is considered as a hamartomatous malformation.</p>
<p>Sites: Skin is the most common site.
Gross Picture: Small brown to black macules. Old nevi become depigmented
Microscopic Picture: Acquired nevi develop along three phases:
a) Junctional Nevus: Nests of nevus cells are seen, at the dermo-epidermal junction. These nevus cells are rounded melanocytes with ovoid nuclei and cytoplasmic melanin granules.
b) Compound Nevus: This phase is characterized by appearance of intradermal groups of nevus cells along with the intraepidermal (junctional) nests.
c) Intradermal Nevus: Over time, the intraepidermal nests disappear. Simultaneously, the dermal nevus cells become spindled and lose their melanin-7 depigmantation of old nevi.
d) Other Types of nevi include</p>
<p>Blue Nevus which is a congenital skin nevus appears blue in color. Microscopically it consists of deep intradermal pigmented elongated melanocytes. Malignant transformation is very rare.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malignant-transformation-of-nevi">Malignant Transformation of Nevi:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malignant-transformation-of-nevi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is relatively more common in patients with large number of acquired nevi. Malignancy is suspected when the size of nevus enlarges with ulceration, color changes &amp; regional lymph node enlargement</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-malignant-melanoma">B) MALIGNANT MELANOMA:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-malignant-melanoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Definition &amp; Origin: A malignant tumor of melanocytes. It commonly arises de novo, but nodular melanoma may arise on top of pre-existing acquired or congenital nevi. Malignant transformation of a pre-existing nevus is suspected when the size enlarges with ulceration, color changes and regional lymph node enlargement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Skin is the most common site (any skin including head neck, scrotum, palms of hands, soles of feet etc).</p>
<p>2- Rare sites include:
a) mucous membranes &amp; mucocutaneous junctions as
b) conjunctiva, rectum, mouth &amp; vagina)
c) eye as choroid and iris.
d) leptomeninges.</p>
<p>Age: Most common between 40-60years, but younger and older ages may be affected.
Types: Clark classified malignant melanoma into:Two main patterns of growth: Radial and vertical.</p>
<p>A- Melanomas with Radial Pattern of Growth: Tumor grows laterally within the epidermis (in situ).</p>
<p>Minimal dermal infiltration occurs later. Subtypes include:
(1)Lentigo maligna: Arises from the sun-exposed skin of the elderly. The tumour appears as a slowly growing flat lesion of varying shades of brown colour. Microscopically the tumour is composed of dysplastic pleomorphic melanocytes spreading along the basal layer of epidermis and skin appendages. The prognosis is good but invasion and metastasis can occur, often after 10 years.
(2)Superficial spreading melanoma: Occurs on any area of the skin but is most common on the back of men and lower legs in women. The tumour appears as a flat or slightly raised brown to black lesion with irregular border. Microscopically there is proliferation of atypical melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction together with invasion of the epidermis by malignant cells arranged singly or in small groups. Sooner or later there is vertical growth phase, the dermis is invaded and a nodule develops.
(3)Acrallentiginous melanoma: Affects the palms and soles. The lesion appears as a pigmented macule. Histologically it resembles lentigo maligna. Soon, however an invasive often spindlecelled tumour arises and the prognosis is poor.</p>
<p>B- Melanoma with Vertical Pattern of Growth (Nodular Melanoma) A malignant tumor of melanocytes. It commonly arises de novo, but may arise on top of pre-existing acquired or congenital nevi. Most common above age of 40 y . The tumour forms a rapidly growing dark brown nodular ulcerating mass. Microscopically the malignant cells invade the epidermis and dermis (vertical growth). The depth of invasion in the dermis and subcutaneous fat is an important prognostic factor. The tumour cells show one of two patterns:
a) Masses of round or polyhydral epithelioid-like cells separated by fine vascular stroma.
b) Spindle shaped malignant cells scattered or in bundles.</p>
<p>Melanin pigment is found both intracellular and extracellular. Few tumours are nonpigmented and are known as amelanotic melanomas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sites">Sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Skin is the most common site (including head neck, scrotum, palms of hands, soles of feet ... etc).
2- Rare sites include
a) mucous membranes &amp; mucocutaneous junctions
b) eye as choriod and iris.
c) leptomeninges..</p>
<p>Grossly: 1-3 cm firm dark brown ulcerating nodule
Microscopy Anaplastic pigmented melanocytes infiltrate the epidermis&amp; dermis.. Rarely the cells do not produce melanin (amelanotic melanoma).Such tumors may be difficult to diagnose except by immunohistochemistry(searching for melanoma antigensHMB-45, S100 &amp; Melan a) .</p>
<p>Prognosis: It depends on the depth of invasion by measuring the vertical extent of tumor below the stratum granulosum (Clark's level). However prognosis is generally poor due to rapid spread of tumor by all routes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spread">Spread:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Local spread
b) lymphatic spread to regional lymph nodes
c) Blood spread.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-teratoma">2) TERATOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-teratoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition-origin-sites">Definition, origin &amp; sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition-origin-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Teratoma is a composite tumor containing structures derived from ectoderm, mesoderm &amp; endoderm. It arises from primitive germ cells or totipotent cells that may exist in post-natal life in some places as ovary, testis, sacrococygeal region &amp; mediastinum. The structure of teratoma is foreign to the site from which it arises</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="origin">Origin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#origin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>During early fetal development the primitive structural cells are called totipotent cells which can give rise to all three embryonic cell types (ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm). Through action of placental chemical organizers - organs are formed from these primitive cells &amp; the later progressively disappear.</li>
<li>Sometimes some primitive totipotent cells that are directed towards the gonads (totipotent germ cells) persist in the goads or arrest along the line of their</li>
</ul>
<p>migration (midline: base of skull, mediastinum, sacrococygeal ... etc) and remain in their primitive state without prenatal maturation</p>
<ul>
<li>The born fetus is usually structurally normal .However if the totipotent cells proliferate in post natal life, they give rise to a tumor composed of a mixture of ectodermal, endodermal and mesodermal structures, but these structures will not form mature organs (due to lack of placental chemical organizers).
N.B.: Tumors that arise from the totipotent cells are called teratomas (composed of a mixture of ectodermal, endodermal and mesodermal structures) and may be benign or malignant. However tumors that do not arise from totipotent cells, but from one of the embryonic cells (ectoderm, mesoderm or endoderm) are called embryonic tumors which are almost always malignant.</li>
</ul>
<p>Age: Any age; children, young adults or elderly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types">Types:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A- MATURE TERATOMA (Benign Teratoma):
These tumors consist of a haphazard mixture of mature ectodermal structures such as skin, neuroglial cells &amp; teeth, mature endodermal structures such as thyroid tissue &amp; other types of glandular epithelium &amp; mature mesodermal structures such as cartilage, bone, adipose tissue, fibrous tissue, muscle ... etc. It maybe cystic &amp; consist predominantly of skin &amp; hairs (dermoid cyst)
Malignant transformation occurs in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of mature teratomas (any type of malignancy, but squamous cell carcinoma is the most common).</p>
<p>Microscopically: These mixed mature structures can be easily recognized
Grossly, mature teratomas are of two types:
a) Cystic Teratoma (DERMOID CYST) (Fig 20): Commonest in ovary. Usually large.</p>
<p>It consists of: - A dermoid ridge which IS a solid part covered by skin.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> The rest of the tumor is cystic and contains sebaceous material, tufts of hair, teeth and other structures.
b) Solid Teratoma: Less common</p>
<p>B- IMMATURE TERATOMA (Malignant Teratoma):</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It consists of a varied amount of immature tissues (immature cartilage, neuroepithelium, glands... etc).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The degree of malignancy and spread is proportionate to the degree of immaturity.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>According to the proportion of immature to mature structures,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This group is subtyped as grade I, grade II &amp; grade III</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="c-monodermal-teratomas-specialized-teratomas">C- MONODERMAL TERATOMAS (Specialized Teratomas):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-monodermal-teratomas-specialized-teratomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are teratomas that differentiate along the line of a single abnormal tissue.
Examples:
a) Struma ovarii: A benign ovarian teratoma composed of thyroid tissue.
b) Ovarian or testicular choriocarcinoma: A malignant placental epithelial tumor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-embryonic-tumors-fig-21">3) EMBRYONIC TUMORS (Fig.21)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-embryonic-tumors-fig-21" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition-origin-and-age">Definition, origin and age:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition-origin-and-age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Malignant tumors derived from embryonic cell remnants ( multipotential cells)
(Ectoderm, endoderm or mesoderm) in infants and young children
Structure: They consist of primitive embryonic (undifferentiated) malignant small round cells. However some of these cells may partially differentiate into mature tissues of the same class from which these embryonic cells are derived (e.g. mesodermal tissues as smooth muscle &amp; cartilage in embryonic tumors derived from mesodermal cells)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples">Examples:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Neuroblastoma of adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic ganglia.
2- Retinoblastoma of eye.
3- Nephroblastoma of kidney.
4- Hepatoblastoma of liver.
5- Medulloblastoma of brain.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-861c0c38.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 20 Dermoid cyst
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-ed2bbdd0.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 21 Embryoma kidney</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-carcinoma-and-sarcoma">CHARACTERISTICS OF CARCINOMA AND SARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-carcinoma-and-sarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">CARCINOMA</th><th style="text-align: center;">SARCOMA</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Definition: Malignant tumor of epithelium Most common form of malignancy.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Definition: Malignant tumor of mesenchyme. Much less common than carcinoma.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Age: Usually (but not always) above age of 40 years.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Age: Usually (but not always below age of 20 years.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Growth rate: Rapid</td><td style="text-align: center;">Growth rate: Faster than carcinoma.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Mode of growth: Infiltrative &amp; expansile</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mode of growth: as carcinoma, but its rapid rate of growth gives it a more expansile appearance</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Gross Features: 1-Size is usually less bulky than sarcoma. 2-Consistency: Usually hard.3Colour is usually Grayish. 4-Carcinoma may arise inside a solid organ (as endocrine gland, liver or kidney) &amp; forms an irregular growth. 5-Carcinoma can also arise from surface epithelium (as skin or mucous membranes) forming a fungating cauliftower mass or an ulcerative growth .It can also invade under the surface (as if inside a solid organ)a infiltrative pattern</td><td style="text-align: center;">Gross Features: 1-Most sarcomas form bulky masses. 2-Consistency: Usually soft and fleshy. 3-Colour is tinged pink due to richer vascularity. 4-Sarcomas arising in a solid organ forms a bulky growth, more regular (expansile). than carcinoma. 5-Sarcomas do not arise from surface epithelium therefore do not classically appear as ulcerating or cauliflower masses, but they can arise from subepithelial mesenchyme (as if in a solid organ) , and appear as bulky expansile growth.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Remark: Carcinoma is derived from the Greek "carcinos" meaning a crab to describe their infiltrative mode.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Remark: Sarcoma is derived from the Greek "sarc" which means ftesh to describe their fleshy consistency.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Microscopic Features: 1-Cellular anaplasia: Usually less marked than sarcoma. 2Histological differentiation: depends on arrangement of the tumor cells. When the tumor is anaplastic, it may be confused with undifferentiated sarcoma. It is worth nothing that, both in cases of carcinoma and sarcoma, poor grades of histological differentiation are associated with high grades of celluar anaplasia. 3-Cell cohesion: Neoplastic cells exhibit variable grades of cohesion. This is however poor in anaplastic carcinomas. 4Blood vessels are less and better formed than in sarcoma. 5- Hemorrhage, necrosis and secondary changes are usually less profound than in sarcoma.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Microscopic Features: 1-Cellular anaplasia is generally greater than carcinoma. &lt;br&gt; 2-Histological differentiation depends in most cases on cell products which may be intracellular (as fat in case of liposarcoma) or extracellular (matrix) as collagen in case of fibrosarcoma and osteoid in osteosarcoma. Thus if a sarcoma arising for example from osteoblasts, shows no osteoid, it is considered undifferentiated. 3-Cell cohesion is often absent and the tumor cells occur singly. 4-Blood vessels are more numerous and thin- walled.5-Hemorrhage, necrosis and secondary changes as hyaline and myxomatous changes are common.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Distant spread-usually slower than sarcomaoccurs early by lymphatics then later by blood, but some carcinomas spread relatively early by blood (carcinoma of thyroid, breast, lung, kidney, prostate &amp; placenta)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Distant spread-usually faster than carcinoma -occurs early by blood &amp; rarely (10%) by lymphatics.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">TNM Staging of carcinoma:</th><th style="text-align: left;">TNM Staging of sarcoma:</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">T: represents tumor state &amp; size, graded &lt;br&gt; as Tis (tumor in situ), T1, T2 T3 &amp; T4.</td><td style="text-align: left;">TNM system (modified)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">N: represents the degree of spread to &lt;br&gt; lymph nodes and is graded as NO,N1,N2 &amp; &lt;br&gt; N3 (NO means absent)</td><td style="text-align: left;">T: usually graded as T1 or T2 according to &lt;br&gt; size</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">M: represents metastases due to blood &lt;br&gt; spread and is graded as MO (absent) or &lt;br&gt; M1 (present).</td><td style="text-align: left;">N: usually graded as NO &amp; N1 &lt;br&gt; M: graded as MO &amp; M1</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Examples T1 NOMO is early cancer stage &lt;br&gt; (better prognosis), while T4 N3 M1 is an &lt;br&gt; advanced stage (worst prognosis).</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-locally-malignant-tumors">CHARACTERISTICS OF LOCALLY MALIGNANT TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-locally-malignant-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a group of intermediate malignant tumors characterized by</li>
</ul>
<p>1- A slower rate of growth than frank malignant tumors
2- Local invasion without distant spread
3- Microscopic features of malignancy.</p>
<ul>
<li>They may changes into frank malignant tumors.</li>
<li>Examples of locally malignant tumors:</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Basal cell carcinoma.
2- Giant cell tumour of bone (Osteoclastoma) (grade II).
3- Adamantinoma.
4- Craniopharyngioma.
5- Bronchial adenoma.
6- Carcinoid tumour.
7- Astrocytoma (grade II).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remarks">REMARKS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remarks" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carcinomas arise from epithelium, while sarcomas arise from mesenchyme. The normal epithelium is characterized by cohesive (adherent) cells resting on basement membranes. The type (differentiation) of normal epithelial tissue is determined by cell type &amp; cell arrangement (e.g. glandular or stratified). The normal mesenchyme mostly consists of noncohesive spindle cells The type (differentiation) of mesenchyme is largely determined by cell products which may be extracellular as collagen (fibroblasts) &amp; osteoid (osteoblasts) or intracellular as actin &amp; myosin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumour-like-lesions">TUMOUR-LIKE lesions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumour-like-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Hamartomas: Hemangioma - lymphangioma &amp; Pigmented nevi-Osteochondroma/ osteochondromatosis.</li>
<li>Granuloma</li>
<li>Choristoma: microscopically normal tissue in abnormal sites</li>
<li>Fibromatosis &amp; desmoid</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hamartoma">HAMARTOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hamartoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a tumor-like developmental malformation formed of noncapsulated mature tissues of the affected organ, arranged haphazardly. It usually stops growing after puberty. Some hamartomas are precancerous.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-hamartomas">Examples of hamartomas:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-hamartomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Lung hamartoma (a mixture of cartilage, smooth muscle and bronchial mucosal tissue).
2- 2-Kidney hamartoma
3- Angiomas,
4- Pigmented nevi.
5- Exostosis &amp; neurofibromatosis are regarded as hamartomatous malformations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-influencing-the-prognosis-of-malignant-tumors">FACTORS INFLUENCING THE PROGNOSIS OF MALIGNANT TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-influencing-the-prognosis-of-malignant-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Tumor Type: e.g. malignant melanoma &amp; most sarcomas have poorer prognosis than carcinomas.
2- Tumor Site: e.g. superficial tumors as those arising from skin are diagnosed earlier and treated easier than deeply seated tumors and brain tumors.
3- Differentiation: Well differentiated tumors grow slower than less differentiated ones.
4- Tumor Stage: There are different methods for tumor staging, one of the popular methods is the TNM system:
5- Immune Host Responses:</p>
<ul>
<li>The tumor cells have antigens capable of evoking an immune response.</li>
<li>The immune response includes cellular factors as cytotoxic T cells, killer (K) cells, natural killer (NK) cells &amp; activated macrophages. Humoral factors (immunoglobulins &amp; complement) participate by an opsonin effect.</li>
<li>Immunodeficiency states as AIDS and immunosuppressive therapy increase the incidence of development of some tumors in these patients as lymphomas and KaposI sarcoma.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis-prognosis-management-laboratory-diagnosis-of-neoplasia">DIAGNOSIS, PROGNOSIS &amp; MANAGEMENT LABORATORY DIAGNOSIS OF NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis-prognosis-management-laboratory-diagnosis-of-neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Biopsy specimens: Stained paraffin sections or frozen sections can easily prepared and microscopicallyexamined.
2- Fine-needle aspiration Using a needle, aspiration of tumor cells is obtained, stained and examined microscopically
3- Cytological Examination Fluids such as ascites, pleural effusions, CSF and urine may contain related tumors. Using a centrifuge, any floating cells detached malignant cells form a sediment, from which films can be prepared on glass slides, stained andexamined.
4- DNA Flow Cytometry: Measurement of the DNA content of tumor cells by flow cytometry shows abnormal DNA content.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-tumor-markers-fig-22">5- Tumor Markers (Fig. 22):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-tumor-markers-fig-22" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are tumor-derived or associated molecules. They may be secreted in the blood (serum tumor markers) and can be detected within the tumor cells (tissue tumor markers).
a) Serum Tumor markers detected within the blood:</p>
<p>Assessment of the level of these markers helps in diagnosis and follow up of tumor e.g.:</p>
<ul>
<li>Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) in cases of cancer colon, stomach, pancreas and breast.</li>
<li>Alphafetoprotein (AFP) in cases of hepatic cancer and germ cell tumors.</li>
<li>Prostatic specific antigen (PSA) and prostatic acid phosphatase in case of cancer prostate.
b) Tissue Markers localized within tumor cellsThese can be detected by a special technique called</li>
</ul>
<p>IMMUNOHISTOCHEMISTRY. Tissue tumor markers may be detected on the cell membrane, cytoplasm or nuclei. Assessment of tumor markers can be of diagnostic value (particularly in undifferentiated malignant tumors). Some Markers or of prognostic value (as Her 2 which denotes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span> higher tendency for metastases). Few examples of diagnostic tumor markers are given:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cytokeratin and EMA (epithelial membrane antigen) in epithelial tumors Icarcinoma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vimentin in mesenchymal tumors Isarcoma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Common leukocyte antigen for lymphomas.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>S-100 protein in neural tumors, melanoma &amp; cartilaginous tumors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>HMB 45 in melanoma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Desmin in muscle tumors.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>6- Efficiency of treatment: There are three main methods of treatment of malignant tumors (used separately or in various combinations) including surgery, chemotherapy (anti cancer drugs) and irradiation. The efficiency of surgery, the proper choice of chemotherapy and radiotherapy are of great importance. Irradiation is planned according to the degree of response of the tumor to irradiation (radiosensitivity)</p>
<p>7- Age: Tumors of infants and children are generally regarded of poorer prognosis (with exceptions).</p>
<p>8- Tumor Hormone Receptors: The growth of some tumors depends partly on hormone stimulation. The cells of such tumors have hormone receptors. Examples include oestrogen receptor positive breast carcinoma and androgen receptor positive prostatic carcinoma. Depriving these tumors from hormone stimulation helps in controlling their growth. Example anti-oestrogen therapy ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>±</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pm</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">±</span></span></span></span></span> oophorectomy) for breast cancer and antiandrogen therapy ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>±</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pm</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">±</span></span></span></span></span> orchidectomy) for prostatic cancer. Thus, a hormone receptor positive Tumor is better than a hormone receptor negative Tumor.</p>
<p>9- Growth Fraction (GF): This is the proportion of cells within the neoplasm entering the cell cycle (i.e. out of GO phase). The importance of GF is that most antineoplastic drugs act on dividing cells; thus tumors with high GF are the most susceptible to anticancer agents &amp; are also the most rapidly growing if left untreated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management-of-benign-malignant-tumours">MANAGEMENT OF BENIGN &amp; MALIGNANT TUMOURS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-benign-malignant-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>SURGERY: Benign tumours - removal of tumour only (Iumpectomy)</li>
</ul>
<p>Malignant tumours- removal of tumour, the tissues around it sometimes the whore organ and removal of draining lymph nodes (radical surgery)</p>
<ul>
<li>CHEMOTHERAPY: interferes with metabolism of proliferating cells
a) Protein synthesis
b) DNA block</li>
<li>RADIOTHERAPY: causes DNA breaks
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Direct damage of DNA molecule
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Breaks in cell &amp; organelle membranes
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Inhibition of important proteins &amp; enzymes
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Toxic damage by ionization of Intra cellular water</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hormonal-therapy">- HORMONAL THERAPY:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a) Drugs
b) Surgical ablation (removal of ovaries or castration)</p>
<ul>
<li>IMMUNOTHERAPY</li>
<li>Non specific vaccines BeG boosts immunity in general</li>
<li>Interferon &amp; interleukin 2 therapy</li>
<li>GENE THERAPY</li>
<li>VIROTHERAPY ( under trial in animals) NEW
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-b9dbcac6.jpeg" alt="img-90.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 22 CEA positive brown tumour cells</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Dist of growth &amp; neoplasia</td><td style="text-align: left;">ALL</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cytology">CYTOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Is the science of cell structure. Compared to histology, the diagnostic criteria are few and depend solely on nuclear and cytoplasmic features of cells. It is unlike histology, where the cellular features as well as the pattern and the relationship of the cells with their surroundings are all taken into consideration.</p>
<p>Despite these diagnostic limitations, cytology is a rapid - inexpensive - non invasive method of patient evaluation and it is rapidly gaining precedence over many diagnostic techniques because:</p>
<ol>
<li>Easy technique</li>
<li>Rapid: can take many samples in a short time</li>
<li>Inexpensive: requires few personnel and minimal equipment</li>
<li>Repeatable: Non invasive method which offers no inconvenience to the patient</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uses">Uses:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Screening: Early detection of premalignant &amp; early invasive neoplasia</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Cervico-vaginal PAP smears</li>
<li>Breast carcinoma screening programs</li>
<li>Urine screening</li>
<li>Sputum screening for bronchogenic carcinoma</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Initial diagnosis</li>
<li>Follow up and monitoring of treatment</li>
<li>Research and tissue culture material</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytology-samples">CYTOLOGY SAMPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytology-samples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-fluids">1)FLUIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Effusions</p>
<ol>
<li>Pleural</li>
<li>Pericardial</li>
<li>Ascitic fluid</li>
<li>Joint contents</li>
</ol>
<p>Urine
CSF</p>
