<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-smears">2) SMEARS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-smears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cervico-vaginal PAP smears</li>
<li>Testicular aspirate! imprint</li>
<li>Imprint of mass! organ e.g. Lymph nodes</li>
<li>Brush samples: bronchial!gastric</li>
</ul>
<p>3)SPUTUM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-brush-and-lavage">4)BRUSH AND LAVAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-brush-and-lavage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bladder&amp; gastric wash, bronchial brush and lavage and rectal brush ...
5) FNAC/FNAB: fine needle aspiration cytology or biopsy</p>
<p>A 10 ml syringe with a 22-23 gauge needle used to aspirate material from Superficial organs:</p>
<p>Lymph nodes- salivary glands-thyroid-breast-subcutaneous swellings Deep organs (Ultrasound guided): Liver -kidney-pancreas-retroperitoneal-prostate etc</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-discharge">6) DISCHARGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-discharge" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nipple</li>
<li>Conjunctival</li>
<li>Ear</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technical-aspects">TECHNICAL ASPECTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technical-aspects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-processing">A) PROCESSING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-processing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluids are :centrifuged and extra sediment is processed like tissue and made into cell blocks. A special centrifuge called cytospin is used for very clear samples</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-fixatives">B) FIXATIVES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-fixatives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> ethanol is a routine fixative</li>
<li>Cytofix spray</li>
<li>Special fixatives according to sample type</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-stains">C) STAINS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-stains" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="routine">Routine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#routine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PAP All samples since it shows good cytoplasmic detail as well as good nuclear detail Hematoxylin and eosin: FNAC &amp; rest of sediment Giemsa important for fine needle aspirates. It shows good nuclear detail Toluidene blue or Diff Quick: For immediate diagnosis (rush sample)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-stains">Special stains<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-stains" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PAS: for glycogen - mucous - fungus
Silver stains: Fungus - inclusions
Immunohistochemical stains &amp; Tumour markers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examination-of-sample-diagnosis">EXAMINATION OF SAMPLE &amp; DIAGNOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examination-of-sample-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cytologist should preferably take the sample himself or be present with the clinician, to ensure proper fixation and sufficient sampling</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gross-examination">GROSS EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cytologist examines the gross appearance of the sample and describes it: color, volume and whether sample is clear or turbid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-examination">MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Low power is important for:</p>
<ul>
<li>Determination of adequacy (are there enough cells &amp; are the cells representative of the tissue being examined).</li>
<li>Pattern &amp; background</li>
<li>Cell types</li>
</ul>
<p>At this level abnormal cells or groups can be marked for later high power use and an idea about the disease category is formed: Inflammation - degeneration, repair, neoplasia. Inadequate smears can be dismissed</p>
<p>High power + Oil immersion are important for: The determination of the benign or malignant nature of cells examined depending on cytoplasmic features &amp; nuclear details:</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{N} / \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">N</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> ratio</li>
<li>Cell &amp; nuclear shape and size</li>
<li>Cell &amp; nuclear membranes</li>
<li>Others: Inclusion bodies</li>
</ol>
<p>Bacteria/fungi/parasites
Nucleoli-mitotic figures-chromatin pattern
Artifacts</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-features-of-benign-malignant-smears">GENERAL FEATURES OF BENIGN &amp; MALIGNANT SMEARS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-features-of-benign-malignant-smears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>General features of Benign cells (Fig. 23)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-d72bf3c6.jpeg" alt="img-91.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>NUCLEI :Equal size - same shape (round or oval) - normal size</li>
<li>NUCLEAR MEMBRANE: Smooth - regular</li>
<li>CHROMATIN: Fine &amp; uniform diffuse distribution</li>
<li>NO NUCLEOLUS: (few exceptions)</li>
<li>CLEAN BACKGROUND: No tumour diathesis</li>
<li>N/C RATIO: Normal according to the cell type</li>
</ol>
<p>General features of malignant cells (Fig. 24)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-c7f4a791.jpeg" alt="img-92.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>NUCLEI: Enlarged - different sizes (pleomorphic) and hyperchromatic</li>
<li>NUCLEAR MEMBRANE: Irregular with angulations</li>
<li>CHROMATIN: Angulated - Clumped - irregular distribution</li>
<li>PROMINANT NUCLEOLUS: may be angulated</li>
<li>DIRTY BACKGROUND (tumour diathesis): RBCs , necrotic cells and Inflammatory cells. This is a sign of invasion</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N / C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> RATIO: Increased due to nuclear enlargement</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Suptopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cytology</td><td style="text-align: left;">mportance of cytology &lt;br&gt; Cytology samples &lt;br&gt; Bemgn &amp; malignant cell features &lt;br&gt; Rest category B</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="environmental-pathology">ENVIRONMENTAL PATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#environmental-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Environmental pathology includes a group of diseases that result from environmental factors as:
(1) Chemical factors: e.g. heavy metals and industrial organic. compounds.
(2) Physical agents: e.g. extremes of temperature, radiation ... etc.
(3) Nutritional: toxic compounds in food
(4) Occupational: as pneumoconiosis ( dust diseases of the lung)
(5) Cultural agents: e.g. smoking, alcohol ... etc.
(6) Others: e.g. air pollution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-chemical-injury">I) CHEMICAL INJURY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-chemical-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Methyl alcohol: is found in solvents, paint removers and antifreeze. Its metabolites, formic acid and formaldehyde, are toxic to the retina and cortical neurons.
(2) Insecticides: as chlorinated hydrocarbons and phosphates. These are readily absorbed through the skin, respiratory tract and gastrointestinal tract and stored in adipose tissue. cause CNS disturbances, muscle twitches and paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, impotence and infertility.
(3) Carbon monoxide (CO): CO is released by incomplete combustion. It forms stable carboxyhemoglobin incapable of binding to oxygen. It gives the skin a cherry red colour.
(4) Lead: Sources of lead are car exhaust, lead paints, lead water pipes ... etc. Lead causes chronic tubulo-interstitial nephritis, peripheral neuritis, cerebral edema and ginival lead line.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-physical-injury">II) PHYSICAL INJURY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-physical-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Frostbite: Exposure to severe cold causes temporary arteriolar spasm and capillary stasis. This causes ischaemia and gangrene of the fingers, toes, nose and ear.
(2) Heat stroke: Results from exposure to heat. Excessive sweating and generalized vasodilatation occur leading to hypotension, cell hypoxia and hyperkalemia.
(3) Electrical injury: according to the type of current, voltage, path and duration of contact, electric current causes:
(a) Skin burns.
(b) Explosion of solid organs.
(c) Bone fractures.
(d) Rupture of small vessels and focal haemorrhage.</p>
<p>(e) Sudden death due to disruption of neural regulatory impulses causing cardiac or respiratory arrest.
(4) Radiation injury</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiationpathology">RADIATIONPATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiationpathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>RADIATION: Any form of energy carried across space
IRRADIATION: Application of radiant energy to tissues</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sources">SOURCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Natural (background radiation)</li>
</ol>
<p>1- Cosmic rays solar (sun)- galactic (stars): Ultraviolet (UV) rays, infrared rays, &amp; atomic particles
N.B.: Ozone layer prevents harmful doses &amp; substances from reaching us.</p>
<p>2- Radioactive substances in earth crust, these emit radiant energy (radioactive decay) e.g.: uranium 234,235 &amp; 238 (natural isotopes)
2. Artificial</p>
<p>Industrial products -Nuclear explosions (weapons)- Nuclear power plants which may be a source of leakage or accidental release in atmosphere, of damaging radiation resulting in atmospheric pollution <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>1</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-radiation">TYPES OF RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>NON IONIZING: Electromagnetic waves (EMW) of long wave length e.g. Radio waves, infrared waves &amp; ultraviolet waves or rays</li>
<li>IONIZING:
a. Atomic particles or particulate radiation (atomic energy/nuclear energy)
b. Electromagnetic waves (EMW) of short wave length e.g.: X rays &amp; gamma rays
N.B.: UV rays may cause ionization and damage if there is prolonged exposure</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uses-of-radiation">USES of RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uses-of-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>In Industry: sterilization and pasteurization- energy generators (nuclear power plants produce heat and electricity from fission reactions)- microwave ovens and radio and TV.</li>
<li>War: atomic weapons e.g. bombs</li>
<li>Science: geology and archeology (carbon dating)- oceanography</li>
<li>Medicine:</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radiodiagnosis: X-rays- CT scans- MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) for lesions of bone /soft tissue. Use of dyes can show lesions in GIT (barium swallow). Blood vessel abnormalities (angiography) and urinary tract abnormalities (pyelography)</li>
<li>Tissue diagnosis-Electron microscope</li>
<li>Functional diagnosis</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>PET (positron emission tomography): Where a radioactive tracer is injected, and the time taken for it to circulate is a measure of left ventricular contractility.</li>
<li>Radioactive iodine is taken up by suspicious thyroid nodules for diagnosis of cold &amp; hot (active) nodules (a measure of activity of thyroid cells in the nodule)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<ol start="6">
<li>Treatment (Nuclear medicine / radiotherapy) especially cancer (palliative or curative) e.g. Cobalt 60</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Others: e.g. sterilization of sutures, short wave treatment for joint disorders, diathermy (surgical procedure by heat application) and radioisotopes for thyroid disorders.</li>
</ol>
<p>1 atmospheric pollution with radiant energy is called: radioactive fallout (the radiant energy present in the atmosphere after any form of leakage or explosion)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definitions">Definitions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definitions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Radioactivity: SPONTANEOUS change of unstable atomic nuclei ( radioisotope) to another stable state, with the emission of radiant energy
Radioisotope or radionucleide: A radioactive form of an element (i.e. atoms of the same substance containing different number of neutrons) NB to stabilize an atom the number of neutrons must <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> number of protons in nucleus. A radioisotope is therefore an unstable nucleus with increased or decreased number of neutrons</p>
<p>Unstable atom/element/molecule emits ionizing radiation till a stable new atom is formed,
N.B.: Isotope: different forms of the same element e.g.C12, C13, C14</p>
<p>Isotope (stable) since atomic number (number of protons) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=1 / 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/2</span></span></span></span></span> atomic weight (number of protons + neutrons)
radioactive form of isotope ( C14 radioisotope) where number of neutrons is more than protons</p>
<p>Ion: positively or negatively charged atom (an atom which has lost an outer electron has a +ve charge &amp; an atom, which has gained an outer orbit electron, has a -ve charge). These charged atoms react with one another forming
free radicals which are also highly reactive because they carry unpaired electrons in the outer shell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mode-of-action-of-ionizing-radiation">MODE OF ACTION OF IONIZING RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-action-of-ionizing-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-direct-or-target-theory">1. Direct or Target theory:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-direct-or-target-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Direct injury (inactivation/ alteration of):</p>
<ul>
<li>DNA:
a- Damage to mitotic spindle causes suppression in mitotic activity
b- DNA structural abnormalities: Gene damage and chromosomal damage e.g. point mutation translocation- amplification and chromosomal fragmentation (dysjunction with abnormal random fusion) (structure abnormality)
c- DNA functional abnormality: abnormal gene expression (functional abnormality)</li>
<li>Enzyme injury</li>
<li>Cell and nuclear membrane injury</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Indirect or Poison theory: one or more hits affect water molecules in cell or tissue causes ionization of water resulting in free radical <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{H}, \mathrm{OH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> (chemical injury) and formation of hydrogen peroxide (H20 2) chemical injury</li>
</ol>
<p>Effects: These react with DNA, enzymes &amp; cell and nuclear membranes resulting in damage</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-radiation">EFFECTS OF RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>on non living tissue (elements): it produces radioisotope on living tissue: it DEPENDS ON:
(1) Dose: Mild doses produce no visible effects to mild effects. All cells die if doserem <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>800</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000-800</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">800</span></span></span></span></span>
(2) Rate, duration of exposure, distance from source and Penetration power
(3) Type of tissue</p>
<ul>
<li>Radiosensitive: actively mitotic cell e.g. labile cells</li>
<li>Radioresponsive: mitotic only on injury e.g. stable cells</li>
<li>Radioresistant: non mitotic e.g. permanent cells
(4) Oxygen effect. The more vascularized, the more oxygenated and the higher the temperature, the more ionization of water and free radicals &amp; Hproduction is facilitated.
N.B.: The angiogenesis accompanying malignant tumors raises the temperature of the tumor &amp; its oxygen content</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="manifestations-of-radiation-damage">MANIFESTATIONS OF RADIATION DAMAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations-of-radiation-damage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Immediate effects (hours - days)</li>
<li>Early effects (after 1 week)</li>
<li>Late or delayed effects( months to years)
N.B.: permissible dose of radiation for ages 18-25 years is 5 rem / year</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-cells">A. CELLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Atrophy &amp; Vacuolar Degeneration of cells up to necrosis in addition to an acute inflammatory reaction</li>
<li>Later followed by chronic inflammation and healing by fibrosis</li>
<li>Very late, cells mutate</li>
<li>If the mutation is at the level of somatic cells a tumour occurs Carcinogenesis (oncogenesis) but if it occurs at the level of the germ cell the result is genetic abnormalities (teratogenesis) and the mutation is transmitted to offspring</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-tissue">B. TISSUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood vessels dilatation, congestion and tissue shows edema (acute inflammatory: mild early: changes) orsevere early damage to vessel wall (fibrinoid necrosis), resulting in tissue hemorrhage, thrombophlebitis with resultant ischemia of tissue. More ischemia occurs later when endarteritis obliterans occurs with chronicity.</li>
<li>Connective tissue:</li>
</ul>
<p>Early: edema and acute inflammatory cells (PNLs &amp; macrophages).
Later chronic inflammation occurs and healing by fibrosis and scarring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-effects-of-radiation-on-individual-organs">C. EFFECTS OF RADIATION ON INDIVIDUAL ORGANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-effects-of-radiation-on-individual-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="during-treatment">(During treatment)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#during-treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Skin: Early:Acute radiodermatitis: (acute inflammation) erythema, swelling and epidermal desquamation or radiation ulcers due to surface necrosis
Later: Atrophy of skin appendages (alopecia and hypopigmentation)
Very late: Basal cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma</li>
<li>GIT: Early: mucosal inflammation, ulceration &amp; radiation colitis with diarrhea and pain
Late: fibrosis and atrophy leading to malabsorption</li>
<li>Testis and ovary (germ cells) early: destruction -late: fibrosis and sterility</li>
<li>Lungs: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) - late: pulmonary fibrosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-haemopoietic-lymphopoietic">5. Haemopoietic &amp; lymphopoietic:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-haemopoietic-lymphopoietic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>BM depression: anemia, thrombocytopenia &amp; leukopenia (pancytopenia) or total destruction of bone marrow (aplasia)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">L</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{L N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">LN</span></span></span></span></span></span> atrophy or destruction with decrease lymphocytic count in peripheral blood; finally fibrosis Later/delayed: Leukemia-lymphoma
6. Bone: Osteomyelitis- radiation necrosis</p>
<ul>
<li>Bone marrow hypoplasia or aplasia (destruction) with risk of leukemia later</li>
<li>Osteosarcoma</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>Others: radiation nephritis, BV vasculitis and thrombosis (radiation vasculitis)</li>
<li>Long term effects: carcinogenesis or genetic defects (teratogenesis)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-effects-of-total-body-radiation">D. EFFECTS OF TOTAL BODY RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-effects-of-total-body-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1 dose exposure of all body as in radioactive fall out in accidents, wars &amp; background radiation pollution)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="systemic">SYSTEMIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systemic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Early or acute radiation effects due to sudden whole body exposure radiation syndrome</p>
<ul>
<li>Radiation sickness or mild radiation syndrome: (non -lethal) 50-200 rem (0.5-2 Sv)</li>
<li>Fatigue, anorexia and nausea (mild GIT syndrome)</li>
<li>Transient drop in peripheral blood counts(mild )</li>
<li>Haemopoietic syndrome: 200-600rem (2-6Sv) causing: BM depression: pancytopenia (severe)</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal syndrome: 300-1000 rem(3-1 OSv) producing: Severe diarrhea, vomiting (Severe) &amp; GIT hemorrhage</li>
<li>Cerebral syndrome: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>1000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;1000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span></span> rem (1 OSv) ending in convulsions and coma (lethal)
B. Late effects (survivors of accidents with very low dose exposure or slow cummulative whole body exposure in industrial pollution &amp; natural background radiation) Malignancy e.g. leukemia
Genetic disorders ( in offspring)
Infertility &amp; complications of fibrosis at various sites
LOCAL Describe effects on various organs (see above)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-protection">RADIATION PROTECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Shield effect: lead aprons and concrete walls prevent penetration
2- Radiation surveillance and measurement: Dosimeters for personnel and Geiger counters &amp; solid state detectors for checking the presence of radioactivity in environment
3- Bone marrow replacement can be life saving if done early in people who have been exposed to total body radiation (accidents, wars)
4- Chemical protection: cysteine and glutathione</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neoplasm-s-and-radiation">NEOPLASM'S AND RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neoplasm-s-and-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ionizing radiation may playa role in cancer treatment or cancer induction
In Cancer treatment (Radiotherapy): It depends on radiosensitivity of tumor cells.
Radiosensitivity: Is the amount of damage produced in a tumor that is directly proportionate to &amp; correlates with degree of mitotic activity of tissue or tumor. Actively mitotic cells are particularly vulnerable &amp; with damage of mitotic spindle, mitotic activity &amp; cell proliferation is inhibited within the tumor tissue this helps in confining the tumor &amp; preventing its spread. The other mode of action is DNA &amp; chromosomal damage, which is incompatible with life of the tumor cell &amp; the cell dies. Normal tissue survives the radiation dose since its rate of proliferation is lower than tumor.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;">Permanent cells &lt;br&gt; (No mitotic ability)</th><th style="text-align: left;">Stable cells &lt;br&gt; (Low mitotic ability)</th><th style="text-align: left;">Labile cells &lt;br&gt; (High mitotic ability)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Degree of radio- &lt;br&gt; sensitivity</td><td style="text-align: left;">Radioresistant</td><td style="text-align: left;">Radioresponsive</td><td style="text-align: left;">Radiosensitive</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Normal cells</td><td style="text-align: left;">Adult neurons &lt;br&gt; Striated muscle</td><td style="text-align: left;">Muscle (smooth) &lt;br&gt; CT &lt;br&gt; Liver &lt;br&gt; Endocrine organs &lt;br&gt; Glial cells</td><td style="text-align: left;">Bone marrow &lt;br&gt; Intestinal epithelium &lt;br&gt; Hair follicles &lt;br&gt; Gonads &lt;br&gt; Skin</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Tumors</td><td style="text-align: left;">Ganglioneuroma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Sarcomas &lt;br&gt; Gliomas &lt;br&gt; Hepatoma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Leukemia Lymphomas &lt;br&gt; Germinoma &lt;br&gt; gonads) Embryomas</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>1- Curative by killing tumor cells leading to spontaneous cure (Melanoma and Hypernephroma)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-palliative-by">2- Palliative by<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-palliative-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreasing tumor size through killing some cells or inhibiting growth and therefore slowing tumor both primary &amp; secondaries in addition to delaying spread</li>
<li>Relief of pain by decreasing size of tumor and its pressure effects</li>
<li>Control of hemorrhage by thrombosis and endarteritis obliterans
N.B.: Monoclonal antibodies tagged with radioisotope can be used as a form of cancer therapy against cancer cells carrying the target antigens</li>
<li>Cancer induction: The dangers from this source have greatly increased in recent years. The ionizing activity of X-rays &amp; atomic radiation produce many changes in nuclear DNA ranging from single gene mutations to gross chromosomal abnormalities with damage of chromosomes in the form of breaks &amp; random fusion producing mutant tumor cells (carcinogenesis).</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Source of radiation</th><th style="text-align: left;">Possible tumors</th><th style="text-align: left;">Type of radiant energy</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">X-ray workers</td><td style="text-align: left;">Skin cancer-leukemia</td><td style="text-align: left;">Ionizing X-rays</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Mining of radioactive sub- &lt;br&gt; tances</td><td style="text-align: left;">Lung cancer</td><td style="text-align: left;">Atomic energy (particulate &lt;br&gt; &amp; rays)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Atomic explosions</td><td style="text-align: left;">Skin cancer-leukemia-bone &lt;br&gt; cancer</td><td style="text-align: left;">Atomic energy (particulate &lt;br&gt; &amp; rays)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-nutritional-disorders">III)NUTRITIONAL DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-nutritional-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nutrients are chemicals in foods that are used by the body for growth, maintenance, and energy. Nutrients that cannot be synthesized by the body and must be derived from the diet are considered essential. They include vitamins, minerals, some amino acids, and some fatty acids. Nutrients that the body can synthesize from other compounds, although they may also be derived from the diet, are considered nonessential.
N.B.: Macronutrients are required by the body in relatively large amounts; micronutrients are needed in minute amounts.</p>
<p>Lack of nutrients can result in deficiency syndromes (e.g. pellagra) or other disorders (Under nutrition .(Excess intake of macronutrients can lead to obesity and the Metabolic Syndrome. Excess intake of micronutrients can be toxic. Also, the balance of various types of nutrients, such as how much unsaturated versus saturated fat is consumed is important e.g. atherosclerotic plaques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-nutritional-disorders">EXAMPLES OF NUTRITIONAL DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-nutritional-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Protein-calorie disorders:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> In children: marasmus -kwashiorkor (growth &amp; mental retardation)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> in adults: starvation- cachexia- immunodeficiency</li>
<li>Eating disorders: Anorexia nervosa &amp; bulimia nervosa</li>
<li>Nutritional excesses: Obesity</li>
<li>Antioxidants and minerals (trace elements &amp; Fe) :</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Decreased levels of zinc is responsible for delayed wound healing</li>
<li>Decreased levels of iodine is responsible for goiter</li>
<li>Decreased levels of Fe is responsible for anemia</li>
<li>lead or mercury toxicity is responsible for neuropathy</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Vitamin deficiency - Hypervitaminosis ( mostly fat soluble vitamins)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-deficiencies">VITAMIN DEFICIENCIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-deficiencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vitamins are micronutrients (organic chemical compounds) found in a large variety of foods. They are essential for health because they serve as critical catalytic cofactors which speed up reactions without being consumed or prosthetic groups on enzymes involved in vital metabolic reaction. The body usually cannot synthesize them by itself.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E &amp; K. Found mostly in fatty foods (dairy products and meat).These are storable, but do not get absorbed through the gut in biliary insufficiency and other forms of fat malabsorption</p>
<p>Water-soluble vitamins ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">&amp;</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B \&amp; C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mord">&amp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>, and folic acid) are available in most food stuffs as fruits, vegetables &amp; animal products ( only B12 is found exclusively in meat). The body does not store them well.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-responsible-for-hypovitaminosis">Disorders responsible for Hypovitaminosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-responsible-for-hypovitaminosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Iry: Malnutrition, decreased intake
2ry:</p>
<ul>
<li>Malabsorption</li>
<li>Increased metabolism i.e. relative insufficiency e.g. folic acid in pregnancy</li>
<li>Presence of an antagonist e.g. methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist</li>
<li>Debilitating diseases &amp; malignancy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-a">Vitamin A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Vitamin A, is derived from Retinol found in dairy products and meat whilst the previtamin B carotene is found in yellow fruit and leafy vegetables. The body stores it in the liver and shuttles it around on retinol-binding protein</li>
<li>Obvious deficiencies are common in the poor nations. Between 100 and 140 million children are vitamin A deficient.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-vitamin-a">FUNCTIONS OF VITAMIN A:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-vitamin-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vitamin A is involved in gene expression, cell growth and differentiation and its functions include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Maintanance of specialized epithelium especially the mucin secreting types.</li>
<li>Important for vital pigments in the retina.</li>
<li>Increases the immunity.</li>
<li>Antioxidant function.</li>
<li>Anticarcinogenic due to its regulatory effect on cell growth</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-a-deficiency">Vitamin A deficiency:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-a-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- The best known symptoms of deficiency are</p>
<ul>
<li>The first complaint in vitamin A deficiency is diminished vision in the dark</li>
<li>Xerophthalmia or dry eye results from inadequate function of the lacrimal glands which</li>
<li>produce conjunctival dryness</li>
<li>Bitot's spots( keratin plaques) result in opacification of cornea</li>
<li>Keratomalacia: degeneration of cornea with dryness, softening and ulcerations</li>
<li>Blindness is the end result.</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Other problems due to squamous metaplasia include kidney stones, obstruction of the sweat and sebaceous glands leading to acne and lung infections.
3- Immunodeficiency.
4- Increase susceptibility to cancer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-d">Vitamin D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>While some vitamin D is supplied by the diet (yolk of eggs, as well as in various oils particularly fish liver oil and fats), most of it is made in the body, by the action of ultraviolet light on 7dehydrocholesterol in the skin. After 25-hydroxylation in the liver, it is completely activated by 1hydroxylation in the kidney. Its function is to maintain adequate Ca and phosphorus levels for normal mineralization of bone.</li>
<li>Vitamin D deficiency occurs due to lack of dietary sources, lack of exposure to sun, liver and kidney diseases, fat malabsorption or inborn errors of metabolism</li>
</ul>
<p>(vitamin D resistant rickets; type I lacks 1-hydroxylase in the kidney, type II probably lacks vitamin 0 receptors).</p>
<ul>
<li>Vitamin D deficiency blocks mineralization of the osteoid laid down in remodeling of bone leading to osteomalacia in adults and impaired mineralization of the epiphyseal cartilage leading to rickets in children.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rickets">Rickets:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rickets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-sequence-of-events">The sequence of events:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-sequence-of-events" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- The epiphyseal cartilage does not even calcify. Instead, it overgrows.
2- Deposition of osteoid among inadequately mineralized cartilaginous remnants.
3- Enlargement and lateral expansion of osteochondral junction
4- Loss of structural rigidity leading to deformities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features-of-rickets">Pathological features of rickets:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features-of-rickets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I) The bone abnormalities of rickets, include</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-head">1. Head :<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-head" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) delayed closure of fontanelles,
b) craniotabes softening of the skull bones resulting in the bone popping in and out similar to pressing on a Ping-Pong ball.
c) frontal bossing unusually prominent forehead.
d) delayed eruption of temporary teeth</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-chest">2. Chest:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-chest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) rachitic rosary (knobs on the costochondral junctions due to overgrowth of cartilage),
b) pigeon breast (anterior protrusion of the sternum, pulled forward by the respiratory muscles),
c) Harrison's groove: a horizontal line at the lower margin of the thorax where the diaphragm attaches to the ribs. It appears in rickets because the patients lack the mineralized calcium in their bones necessary to harden them; thus the diaphragm, which is always in tension, pulls the softened bone inward
3. Vertebrae: lumbar lordosis (excessive inward curve of the spine)
4. Bow legs and trifoil pelvic deformities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-somatic-lesions">II) Somatic lesions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-somatic-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>lymph node and adenoid enlargement and splenomegaly due to hyperplasia.</li>
<li>Weak tendons and muscles.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-general-lesions">III) General lesions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-general-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Overweight due to limited movements.</li>
<li>Protuberant abdomen due to weak muscles (Potts belly), lordosis.</li>
<li>Lymph node enlargement, splenomegaly</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteomalacia">Osteomalacia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteomalacia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in adults, commonly in females as a result of repeated pregnancies with vitamin D deficiency.</li>
<li>Osteomalacia means "soft bones", the osteoid does not mineralize properly, during bone remodeling and it accumulates. The bone density and cortical thickness are decreased, predisposing to fractures .Bones are soft, easily bent resulting in a trifoil pelvis (this deformity is responsible for obstruction of labour), bowing of legs &amp; lumbar lordosis.</li>
<li>In osteomalacia, the non-calcified bone looks pale on x-ray and has a tendency to break.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-k">Vitamin K<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-k" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the cofactor for the synthesis of gamma-carboxy glutamic acid, which is required for the calcium-binding clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, plus protein C, S, and Z .</li>
<li>Although our intestinal flora makes a little vitamin K for us, it is inadequate and it is usually complemented from the diet. It is present in oils, green leafy vegetables and dairy products</li>
<li>Vitamin K is hard to avoid in the diet, we store several weeks' supply.</li>
<li>Deficiency is seen mostly in newborns and in those with lipid malabsorption or rarely due to wiping out the bacterial flora with antibiotics</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathology-of-vitamin-k-deficiency">Pathology of vitamin K Deficiency:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathology-of-vitamin-k-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Hemorrhagic disease of the newly born</li>
<li>Petechia, ecchymosis and haematomas occur in any tissue following minor trauma.</li>
<li>Persistent bleeding follows wounds and surgical incision.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-c-ascorbic-acid">Vitamin C (ascorbic acid)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-c-ascorbic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Humans, cannot synthesize it and its reserves are limited so the deficiency manifestations appear after 30-40 days. In the diet, it is present in citrus fruits and tomatoes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-c-functions">Vitamin C functions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-c-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>It is involved in developing and maintaining collagen, synthesizing chondroitin sulfate.</li>
<li>Antioxidant as it protects the body against oxidative stress and is a , cofactor in several vital enzymatic reactions and maintains Fe and Cu In vanous oxygenases in a reduced state.</li>
<li>Synthesis of neurotransmitors.</li>
<li>Important in immune functions.</li>
<li>Increases intestinal absorption of iron and folic acid.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-deficiency-syndrome-is-scurvy">The deficiency syndrome is "scurvy:"<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-deficiency-syndrome-is-scurvy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in people who eat very poorly for several weeks. In the poor nations, scurvy occurs in children whose mothers feed them with un-supplemented formula.</li>
<li>Scurvy is a distinctive clinical syndrome related to problems with osteoid synthesis and collagen support of the blood vessels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-features-of-scurvy">Pathological features of scurvy:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-features-of-scurvy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In children, the osteoblasts lay down scanty, poor-quality osteoid. The end result is deformities similar to rickets (enlargement of bony ends rosary bed, sternal depression, bowing of legs and defective teeth formation).</li>
<li>In both children and adults, the capillaries weaken. Patients bruise easily, and bleeding gums, and petechiae around the hair follicles. Eventually, hemorrhages beneath the periosteum develop, making this the most painful of the deficiency diseases.</li>
<li>Wounds heal poorly.</li>
<li>A secondary functional folic acid deficiency develops, because vitamin C is responsible for maintaining folate in its reduced state leading to anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vitamin-b1-thiamine">Vitamin B1 (thiamine)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-b1-thiamine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This vitamin is important in carbohydrate metabolism, synthesis of ATP and it also maintains nerves. Thiamine deficiency was seen classically in people subsisting on polished rice, and today in alcoholics, cancer victims who do not eat, women with extreme vomiting of pregnancy, and in children and adults who have been starved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thiamine-deficiency">Thiamine deficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thiamine-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A cardiomyopathy, with a flabby, failing heart ("wet beriberi"), plus generalized dilatation of arterioles requiring "high output"</li>
<li>A peripheral neuropathy ("dry beriberi"), with numb fingers and toes, weak muscles, and lost reflexes. First the myelin, then the axons and even the motor and sensory neurons go.)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-b3-niacin-nicotinic-acid">Vitamin B3 (niacin, nicotinic acid)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-b3-niacin-nicotinic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Formed from spare tryptophan.</li>
<li>Niacin in maize ("corn") is poorly absorbed, maize is low in tryptophan.</li>
<li>Pellagra ("dry skin") used to be endemic in southern "corn belt" (corn eating societies and In an alcoholics.
Niacin deficiency ("pellagra"): produces the "three D's"</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Dermatitis: Red, thick, scaly, sharply demarcated, irregularly pigmented skin, especially sun-exposed regions; and "beefy red tongue"; Microscopically: acanthosis, confluent parakeratosis, hyperkeratosis and increased pigmentation..</li>
<li>Diarrhea: The mucosa of the colon is hyperemic and covered by pseudomembrane. Microscopically: hyperaemia, areas of necrosis and mononuclear inflammatory cellular infiltration .</li>
<li>Dementia: Mental illness and loss of neurons in frontal lobes; and demylination of the lateral and posterior column (subacute combined degeneration). The fourth "D" is "death".</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b12-cyanocobal-amine-folic-acid">B12 (Cyanocobal-amine) &amp; Folic acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b12-cyanocobal-amine-folic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Coenzyme for nucleic acid &amp; RBC production. Folic acid is also an important for proper nerve function. Present in vegetables &amp;fruit (bananas &amp; lemons). Responsible for megaloblastic anemia in addition to Neurological damage in cases of folic acid deficiency</p>
