<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-cultural-factors">IV) CULTURAL FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-cultural-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Tobacco smoking: Predisposes to:
(a) Coronary atherosclerosis and ischemic heart diseases.
(b) Chronic obstructive lung diseases.
(c) Bronchial carcinoma by its chemical carcinogens.
(d) Fetal hypoxia and premature deaths.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alcohol abuse: Predisposes to:
(a) Fatty change in the liver, alcoholic hepatitis and cirrhosis.
(b) Cardiomyopathy and hypertension.
(c) Acute gastritis, chronic gastritis and pancreatitis.
(d) Testicular atrophy and decreased fertility.
(e) Peripheral neuritis.
(f) Cancer of the oral cavity, pharynx, esophagus, liver and breast.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Street drugs:
(a) Bango: May lead to:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Adverse behavior and psychological reactions.</li>
<li>Deterioration of pulmonary, reproductive and immunologic functions.
(b) Cocaine: Increases synthesis of norepinephrines and dopamine causing:</li>
<li>Euphoria.</li>
<li>Tachycardia, hypertension and arrhythmias. (c) Heroin: Addiction may result in:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Disseminated angitis.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Meningitis and brain infections.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Transmitted infections: AIDS, hepatitis ... etc. - Infective endocarditis.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Peripheral neuropathy.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-air-pollution">V) AIR POLLUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-air-pollution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pollutants may be bacteria, gases, particles or fibers. The inhalation of pollutants may cause:
(1) Acute or chronic inflammation, e.g. chronic bronchitis.
(2) Allergic reactions, e.g. bronchial asthma.
(3) Immunologic injury.
(4) Granulomatous reactions, e.g. pneumoconiosis.
(5) Mutagenic and tumour promoting effects may lead to neoplasia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: center;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Environmental</td><td style="text-align: center;">Chemical &amp; cultural factors</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Ionizing radiation</td><td style="text-align: center;">Air pollution</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Vitamins</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mode of action-effects manifestations &lt;br&gt; of radiation damage- neoplasms and radiation</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Rest C</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">A-D-K</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">C</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Rest C</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heredity-genes-disease">HEREDITY- GENES &amp; DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heredity-genes-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nucleus is the genetic factory; it contains a diploid number of chromosomes (46) i.e. 22 pairs of autosomes +1 pair of sex chromosomes.</p>
<p>A chromosome is 1 molecule of DNA (as a double helix). This may carry up to 50,000 genes &amp; its basic structure is the nucleotide (base pair + ribose +phosphate)</p>
<p>Gene is the unit of the chromosome responsible for synthesis of 1 specific protein which may be composed of 1-20,000 nucleotides (base pairs)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chromosomes-are-important-in">Chromosomes are important in:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chromosomes-are-important-in" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Cell division</li>
<li>Carry hereditary traits on genes</li>
<li>Have genes responsible for protein synthesis (structural proteins, hormones, receptor proteins, intracellular messengers and enzymes)
N.B.: Somatic cells are diploid</li>
</ol>
<p>Germ cells (ovum/sperm) are haploid (half the number of chromosomes)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="developmental-genetic-disorders">DEVELOPMENTAL &amp; GENETIC DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#developmental-genetic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="terminology">Terminology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#terminology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Developmental &amp; Congenital disorders: disorders due to events occurring just before birth which are not necessarily inherited e.g. exposure to radiation-viruses-drugs or spontaneous mutation during pregnancy</li>
<li>Inherited disorders: Are genetic disorders which are transmitted from 1 generation to another</li>
<li>Genetic disorders: Are diseases caused by abnormalities in genes or chromosomes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genetic-disorders">Genetic disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genetic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mutations">Mutations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mutations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mutation is a permanent change in the DNA which may occur spontaneously or due to external agents as radiation, chemicals &amp; viruses.</p>
<p>Mutations may affect germ or somatic cells.
1- Germ cell mutations: affect germ cells and result in hereditary diseases.
2- Somatic cell mutations: affect the tissue stem cell population or somatic non germ cell population. Such mutations may be responsible for:
A. Congenital disorders</p>
<p>B. Reversible growths i.e. hyperplasia-hypertrophy- congenital abnormality but not hereditary disorders.
C. Tumor cells (irreversible)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-mutations">Types of mutations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-mutations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Chromosome mutations:
A) Genome mutations: Loss or gain of the whole chromosome (numerical) monosomy or trisomy
B) Rearrangement of the genetic material which gives rise to visible structural changes in the chromosome.</li>
<li>Gene mutations: Partial or complete deletion of gene or more often affect single base. E.g. single point gene mutation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-mutations">Effects of mutations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-mutations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Abnormal proteins. &amp; Lack of the protein synthesis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-genetic-disorders">Types of Genetic Disorders:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-genetic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cytogenetic: Chromosomal ( number. and structural) disorders.</li>
<li>Single gene disorders: Mutant gene with large effect ( Mendelian disorders) &amp; single gene disorders with non classic inheritance.</li>
<li>Multifactorial inheritance: Influenced by both genetic and environmental factors.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-cytogenetic-hromosomal-abnormality">1. CYTOGENETIC HROMOSOMAL ABNORMALITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-cytogenetic-hromosomal-abnormality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Abnormalities of chromosomes may be either numerical or structural and may involve the autosomes, the sex chromosomes or both simultaneously. Numerical abnormalities represent about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> of all chromosome abnormalities.
A. Abnormalities in number of chromosomes:</p>
<p>1- Polyploid: Increased number of chromosomes by an exact multiple of haploid e.g.:
tetraploid loctaploid ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>8</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 / 8</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">4/8</span></span></span></span></span> sets of chromosomes i.e. extra diploid sets)
a- if it occurs in somatic cells, it produces hypertrophy
b- if it occurs in germ cells, it is incompatible with life.
2- Aneuploid Increased or decreased number of chromosomes, but not by a multiple of the haploid e.g. triploid ( 3 whole sets of chromosomes i.e. an extra haploid set
a- if it occurs in somatic cells, it leads to some types of neoplasia.
b- if it occurs in germ cells (gametes) as monosmy (less by 1 chromosome) or trisomy (more by 1 chromosome, trisomy21) e.g. Down's syndrome</p>
<p>3- Mosaicism: Presence of more than one population of cells with normal chromosome number and the other with extra or missing chromosomes due to mitotic errors e.g. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>45</mn><mi>x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>47</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45 x / 47 x x x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">45</span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mord">/47</span><span class="mord mathnormal">xxx</span></span></span></span></span> mosaic
B. Abnormalities in structure of chromosomes</p>
<ul>
<li>Accidental breaks with bad repair &amp; abnormal fusion as in spontaneous mutations or exposure to teratogens (irradiation-viruses-drugs)</li>
<li>Deletion: missing a part of chromosome</li>
<li>Duplication: A portion of the chromosome is duplicated resulting in extra genetic material</li>
<li>Translocation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> When a portion of one chromosome is transferred to another chromosome. Or when segments exchange places on 2 chromosomes)</li>
<li>Dysjunction with random fusion=breaking usually at centromere but with abnormal random fusion
C. Abnormalities in sex chromosomes: Turners syndrome &amp; Kleinefelters syndrome Syndromes Associated with Sex Chromosome Abnormalities
(1)Klinefelter's syndrome: Male with karyotype (47, xxy). The syndrome is characterized by eunuchoid built, infertility, atrophic testis and gynecomastia.
(2)Turner's syndrome: Female with karyotype (45, x). The syndrome is characterized by atrophic ovaries, infantile external genitalia, lack of secondary sex characteristics, amenorrhea and congenital heart disease specially aortic coarctation.
(3)47, xxx syndrome: Female showing normal physical and reproductive development. However there may be difficulty in auditory perception and receptive and expressive language skills.
(4)47, xyy syndrome: Tall male with no apparent abnormality in physical and reproductive development. There may be a risk of criminal behaviour.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-single-gene-disease-mendelian-disorders">2. SINGLE GENE DISEASE ( Mendelian disorders)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-single-gene-disease-mendelian-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Genes on chromosomes affect function i.e. the distribution pattern of genes is important for they act either by enhancing or suppressing neighboring genes. All are the result of expressed mutations in a single gene with large effect.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inherited-single-gene-disorders">Inherited single gene disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inherited-single-gene-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Autosomal dominant: The mutated gene is dominant to its allele. All offspring are affected (homozygous &amp; heterozygous) e.g. familial hypercholesterolemia, adult polycstic kidney, multiple exostosis and polyposis coli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Autosomal recessive: The mutated gene is recessive to its allele some offspring are affected (only homozygous) e.g. Thalassemia &amp; mental retardation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sex linked on chromosome <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>, usually recessive (carrier), appearing in males with the female acting as a carrier for the abnormal gene e.g. hemophilia &amp; Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Rarely if the abnormal gene is dominant, it will appear in both sexes.
N.B.: alleles are DNA sequences that code for a gene, but sometimes the term is used to refer to a non-gene sequence.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-metabolic-disorders-errors-of-metabolism">3. METABOLIC DISORDERS (Errors of metabolism)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-metabolic-disorders-errors-of-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are inherited disorders of single genes which code for enzymes.
Mechanism is like single gene abnormality but the result is defective enzyme synthesis</p>
<ul>
<li>Carbohydrates: glycogen storage disease</li>
<li>Lipids &amp; amino acids:lysosomal storage disease</li>
<li>Membrane transport enzymes:cystic fibrosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-multifactorial">4. MULTIFACTORIAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-multifactorial" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Multifactorial disorders require the interaction of environmental and genetic factors as diabetes mellitus and hypertension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genetic-cancer-syndromes">GENETIC CANCER SYNDROMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genetic-cancer-syndromes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease)</li>
<li>Multiple endocrine neoplasms (MEN)</li>
<li>Familial breast cancer</li>
<li>Familial adenomatous polyposis coli</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="priorities">PRIORITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Category A 80% of exam Category B 15% of exam Category C 5% of exam</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Topic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Subtopic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Genetic disorders</td><td style="text-align: left;">Terminology &lt;br&gt; Types of Genetic disorders (list only) &lt;br&gt; Rest C</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="techniques-used-in-surgical-pathologyservices">TECHNIQUES USED IN SURGICAL PATHOLOGYSERVICES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#techniques-used-in-surgical-pathologyservices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Surgical Pathology is that part of Anatomic Pathology concerned with the study of tissue and organ samples removed from patients, either by biopsy or through a surgical procedure, in an attempt to obtain diagnosis of a lesion or disease. The pathologist is therefore able to advise the attending physician as to the nature of the disease, the prognosis, and the need for additional sampling or exploration.
Cytopathology is the study and evaluation of cells present in smears, fine needle aspirates and body fluids. Analysis of nuclear and cytoplasmic characteristics permit diagnosis of various disease processes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-value-of-tissue-sample-in-variable-lesions">The value of tissue sample in variable lesions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-value-of-tissue-sample-in-variable-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Determine a tissue diagnosis where clinical diagnosis is doubt e.g. liver core biopsy in cases of cirrhosis of unknown etiology.</li>
<li>Ascertain whether benign or malignant e.g. gastric ulcer biopsy.</li>
<li>Ascertain extent of spread of disease.</li>
<li>In itself, the biopsy with excision of the lesion may be a form of local treatment e.g. excision biopsy of rodent ulcer.
N.B.: biopsy is a form of special investigation and should interpreted in the light of the clinical picture.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methods-for-tissue-sampling">Methods for tissue sampling:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods-for-tissue-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1- Excision biopsy: The whole lesion removal.
2- Incision biopsy: Part of the lesion is sampled.
3- Core needle biopsy.
4- Endoscopic biopsy.
5- Punch biopsy.
6- Frozen section: Examination of fresh samples.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-routine-specimen-manipulation">The Routine Specimen manipulation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-routine-specimen-manipulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Labeling: Each specimen must be labeled with the patient's name, hospital number, source of the tissue and site and side of the body.
b. Specimen Fixation: Universal precautions are to be exercised in handling and transporting all surgical pathology specimens. Proper and timely fixation is a critical step in tissue preparation for diagnosis.</p>
<p>There are five major groups of fixatives, classified according to mechanism of action:</p>
<ul>
<li>Aldehydes include formaldehyde (formalin)</li>
<li>Mercurials</li>
<li>Alcohols</li>
<li>Oxidizing agents</li>
<li>Picrates
c. Tissue Processing: Once the tissue has been fixed, it must be processed into a form in which it can be made into thin microscopic sections. The usual way this is done is with paraffin. Tissues embedded in paraffin, which is similar in density to tissue, can be sectioned at anywhere from 3 to 10 microns, usually 6-8 routinely. The technique of getting fixed tissue into paraffin is called tissue processing. The main steps in this process are dehydration and clearing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ancillary-diagnostic-techniques">Ancillary diagnostic techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ancillary-diagnostic-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Are techniques that aid in the diagnosis when routine methods fail to provide the answer</p>
<ul>
<li>Cyto/histochemistry: Is the light microscopic study of the chemistry of cells and tissues after treating them with special reagents</li>
<li>Immuno cyto/histochemistry: Immunohistochemistry (IH) is a technique for identifying cellular or tissue constituents (antigens) which may be normal tissue constituents or produced as a result of a pathologic process. IH techniques are based on the specificity antibody-antigen binding. The site of antibody binding is identified either by direct labeling of the antibody, or by use of a secondary labeling method.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="molecular-pathology-cytogenetics">- Molecular pathology &amp; Cytogenetics:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#molecular-pathology-cytogenetics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Molecular pathology entails the study of the biochemical based changes in a single nucleotide in genomic DNA resulting in a defective gene product, which may produce a lesion in some disorders as congenital diseases and cancer. The method used is Polymerase Chain Reaction Technology (PCR), which allows the analysis of DNA or RNA from any specimen by means of amplifying the length of DNA understudy a million times, and therefore can detect even minute amounts.</p>
<p>Cytogenetics: Involves the study of abnormal chromosomes and genes responsible for certain diseases by a process of karyotyping.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-cyto-histochemistry">A) Cyto/histochemistry<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-cyto-histochemistry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Is the light microscopic study of the chemistry of cells and tissues after treating them with special reagents. Each tissue type has characteristic features and preponderance of one particular substance characteristic of the tissue or cell</p>
<ol>
<li>Mucin stains: Alcian blue -PAS (peroidic acid-Schiff) - Mucicarmine</li>
<li>Fat stains:</li>
<li>Connective tissue stains: The trichrome stain helps to highlight the supporting collagenous stroma in sections from a variety of organs.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-immunohistochemistry">B) Immunohistochemistry<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-immunohistochemistry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Immunohistochemistry is the localization of PROTEINS in tissue sections by the use of labeled antibodies as specific reagents through antigen-antibody interactions that are visualized by a marker such as enzyme labels have been introduced e.g peroxidase and alkaline phosphatase. Since immunohistochemistry involves specific antigen-antibody reaction, it has become a crucial technique and widely used in many medical research laboratories as well as clinical diagnostics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages">Advantages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Remarkable sensitivity and specificity.</li>
<li>Applicability to routinely processed material even if stored to long time.</li>
<li>It is compatible with most of the fixatives currently in use and in cytological preparations and even previously stained sections.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methods">Methods:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There are numerous immunohistochemistry methods that may be used to localize antigens.</li>
<li>The selection of a suitable method should be based on parameters such as the type of specimen under investigation and the degree of sensitivity required.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251212-13120af1.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg">
(Fig. 25) Methods of Immunohistochemistry</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-direct-method">1- Direct Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-direct-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Direct method is one step staining method, and involves a labeled antibody reacting directly with the antigen in tissue sections.</li>
<li>This technique utilizes only one antibody and the procedure is short and quick. However, it is insensitive due to little signal amplification and rarely used since the introduction of indirect method.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-indirect-method">2- Indirect Method:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-indirect-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Indirect method involves an unlabeled primary antibody (first layer) which react with tissue antigen, and a labeled secondary antibody (second layer) react with primary antibody.</li>
<li>This method is more sensitive due to signal amplification through several secondary antibody reactions with different antigenic sites on the primary antibody.</li>
<li>The second layer antibody is labeled with an enzyme such as peroxidase, alkaline phosphatase or glucose oxidase.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-pap-method-peroxidase-anti-peroxidase-method">3- PAP Method (peroxidase anti-peroxidase method):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-pap-method-peroxidase-anti-peroxidase-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>4- Avidin-Biotin Complex (ABC) Method:
5- Labeled Strept Avidin Biotin (LSAB) Method:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="summary">Summary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Immunohistochemistry is a method of detecting the presence of specific proteins in cells or tissues and consists of the following steps:</p>
<p>1- Primary antibody binds with the specific antigen.
2- The antigen antibody complex is bound by enzyme conjugated secondary antibody.
3- In the presence of the substrate and chromogen, the enzyme form colored deposit a sites of antigen antibody binding.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-diagnostic-applications-of-immunohistochemistry">Examples of diagnostic applications of immunohistochemistry:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-diagnostic-applications-of-immunohistochemistry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Immunohistochemistry has assumed an increasingly prominent role in diagnostic breast pathology as it now frequently used in the evaluation of many epithelial proliferations of the breast.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="common-applications-include-the-use-of">Common applications include the use of:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-applications-include-the-use-of" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Myoepithelial markers (actin) to evaluate for stromal invasion.</li>
<li>Cytokeratin stains to detect metastases in lymph nodes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="immunohistochemistry-a-prognostic-as-well-as-diagnostic-tool">Immunohistochemistry: a prognostic as well as diagnostic tool:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunohistochemistry-a-prognostic-as-well-as-diagnostic-tool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The assessment of proliferating cell populations has been used to aid in the differentiation of benign from malignant neoplasms.</li>
<li>The assessment of proliferation markers and oncogenic determinants holds information regarding prognosIs.</li>
<li>For example: Ki-67, p53 protein, bcl-2, are useful in understanding the biology of certain neoplasms and may carry prognostic information that influences clinical management.</li>
</ul>
<p>Topic
Techniques</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="subtopic">Subtopic<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subtopic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
